loans.name: Maria Haydee

texts.es: Maria Haydee S. de 60 años de edad, reside en la Ciudad de Soyapango, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Vive junto a sus dos hijas, las cuales se dedican a estudiar en la universidad, lo cual llena de mucho orgullo y esperanza a Maria, ya que todos sus esfuerzos se ven reflejados en el bienestar de sus hijas las cuales se están forjando un futuro mejor. Maria posee una venta de ropa, la cual esta ubicada en el segundo nivel del mercado Sagrado Corazón, uno de los mercados con mayor afluencia de personas por estar ubicado en el centro de la capital salvadoreña. Desde hace 15 años que ella se dedica a este tipo de trabajo, razón por la cual cuenta con muchos clientes los cuales le hacen pedidos bastante grandes de ropa, para poder surtir negocios más pequeños como tiendas y otros. Es de esta manera como a través de los años Maria ha logrado sostener a sus dos hijas, las cuales han salido adelante gracias a los enormes esfuerzos de su madre, la cual siempre ha estado dispuesta  a sacrificarse por ellas. Con el deseo de poder mejorar su negocio, Maria solicita un préstamo a Integral, con el fin de poder surtir el negocio con faldas, blusas, pantalones, ropa para niños y adultos en muchos estilos. Todo esto lo hace con la esperanza de mejorar las ventas lo cual le traiga consigo muchos beneficios tanto para ella como para sus hijas.
texts.en:
Maria Haydee S. is 60 years old and lives in Soyapango City, located in San Salvador department. She lives together with her 2 daughters, who are studying at university. This fills Maria with pride and hope, as all her hard efforts can be seen in the well-being of her daughters, who are forging a better future. Maria has a clothing sale business, which is located on the second floor of the Sagrado Corazón market, a market frequented by affluent people due to its location in the centre of the Salvadorean capital. Maria has worked doing this for 15 years. She has many clients who request a large amount of clothes, to stock smaller businesses such as shops and others. It is this way that through the years Maria has been able to support her daughters, who have been able to move forward thanks to the enormous efforts of their mother, who has always sacrificed herself for them. With the wish of improving her business, Maria is seeking a loan from Integral, to be able to stock her shop with skirts, blouses, trousers, and children's and adult's clothing in many styles. Maria does all this in the hope of generating better sales, which bring as many benefits for her as they do to her daughters.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase large quantity of clothes

loans.name: Lout

texts.en: Mrs. Lout P. owns a store in front of her home where she sells breakfast foods to people who are her nearby neighbors. She earns around $7 per day. She lives with her one child and her husband in a rural area of Phnom Penh, the city of Cambodia. In order to help support the family’s expenses, Mrs. Lout P.’s husband is a local farmer and also works as a temporary employee. Lout P. will be using her first loan to decorate the outside of her food shop to attract her customers. With any money remaining from the loan, she will buy ingredients and other attractive furniture for her shop.

loans.use: To decorate the outside of her food shop.

loans.name: Sambo

texts.en:
Many Cambodian people earn a living by working in the garment industry. One of these citizens, Mrs. R., 29, works by sewing clothes in the garment industry, earning a suitable salary. She was married several years ago but she doesn’t have any children. Besides her current job, Mrs. R. also helps her husband to produce cement jars when she is not at work.

Her husband is a significant financial earner for the family, manufacturing jars and selling them to the middlemen who take the jars to retail. Recently, he has used up his stock of raw material. Mrs. R. is taking out a Kiva loan for her husband so he can resupply his stock by purchasing more cement for making jars.

loans.use: To purchase more cement for making jars

loans.name: Isabel Del Carmen

texts.es: Isabel del Carmen S. R. de 40 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Usulután, vive junto a su esposo José Ángel Gómez  el cual se dedica a trabajar.  Isabel se dedica a trabajar en su propia casa, vendiendo golosinas y medicinas. Ella es una señora muy emprendedora la cual trabaja arduamente por obtener más clientela y vender cada día más con el mayor de los deseos de poder vivir mejor junto a su esposo. Ella solicita un préstamo a Integral, para poder contar con el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad de medicinas y más golosinas como dulces, churros, y galletas, lo cual le permita contar con más clientela, ya que ella cuenta con 8 años de poseer este negocio, a través del cual obtiene ganancias aceptables, a pesar de contar con pocos productos. Es por eso que Isabel cuenta con el deseo de aumentar su inventario y de esta manera crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Isabel del Carmen S. R., 40 years of age, resides in the Usulután department. She lives together with her husband José Ángel Gómez, who works. Isabel works from home selling sweets and medicines. She is an empresarial woman who works very hard to obtain more clients and sell more each day, to be able to live better together with her husband. Isabel is seeking a loan from Integral to obtain the necessary capital to buy a larger quantity of medicines and other sweets such as lollies, churros and biscuits, which will allow her to have more clients. She has had this business for 8 years, during which time she has made acceptable earnings, despite having few products. It's for this reason that Isabel wants to increase her inventory and grow as a micro-businesswoman.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase medicines and sweets

loans.name: Marta

texts.es: Marta  A. D. Z. D. 42 años D. edad, resiD. en Santa Tecla, ubicado en el departamento D. La Libertad. Vive junto a su esposo, el señor Daniel Ramírez quien trabaja como comerciante, y así mismo junto a su hijo D. 16 años D. edad el cual estudia educación básica.  Marta posee un comedor el cual esta ubicado en su propia casa, en donD. se encarga D. elaborar desayunos y almuerzos, así mismo venD. diferentes tipos D. bebidas. Ella solicita un préstamo para poder comprar maíz, arroz, frijoles, azúcar, verduras y bebidas por mayor, D. manera que pueda surtir su negocio con todo lo básico y más necesario para mejorar sus ventas. Así mismo ella posee el deseo D. poder comprar un puesto en el mercado D. Santa Tecla, esto ya que en dicho puesto ella cuenta con la seguridad D. poder mejorar sus ventas, ya que hay muchas más personas tanto como clientes del lugar como personas que trabajan ahí. Todo esto lo hace con el deseo D. poder crecer más en su negocio y D. esta misma forma poder mejorar su calidad D. vida y la D. su familia. Marta demuestra ser una mujer con muchas metas, la cual esta dispuesta a alcanzar sobre todo por el bienestar D. su hijo.
texts.en:
Marta A. D. Z., 42, lives in Santa Tecla, located in La Libertad department. She lives together with her husband Daniel Ramírez, who is a storekeeper, and their son, 16, who is studying. Marta has a restaurant located in her home, where she makes breakfasts and lunches and sells different types of drinks. She is seeking a loan to purchase maize, rice, beans, sugar, vegetables and drinks in larger quantity, to stock her business with all the basic and necessary items to improve her sales. Marta also wants to purchase a stand in the Santa Tecla market, where she will be able to improve her sales, as there are many more potential customers who work around there. Marta does it all this with the desire of growing her business in order to improve her quality of life and that of her family. Marta has demonstrated to be a woman with many goals, most of which are for the well-being of her son.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grains, drinks and vegetables

location.town: Santa Tecla, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Kang

texts.en:
Mrs. T., 57, is a person on a low income who lives in a rural area of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, where she sells food to earn a living. She buys ingredients at the market and produces the food in her home. She starts selling food in the early evening and her buyers are people in her village. She was married, but her husband died. She has two daughters: one is a garment factory worker and the other assists her in selling food.

Mrs. T. has been trying to save up money in order to build a new house but her savings are still not enough to start the construction process. Therefore, she decided to request a loan to add to her savings in order to build a new house.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Srei

texts.en:
Mrs. Srei P. is a 32-year-old married woman who lives in Kandal village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows crops. Her husband, Mr. Phy Phon, is a fisherman who earns a small income to support his family. He is on the right of the picture.

Mrs. Srei P. is requesting a loan to purchase timber to fix up her house. She is the mother of three children, two of whom attend the local school while the youngest one is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To purchase timber for house repairs

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy H. is 51 years old and lives in Kampong Pou village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Choeun Sem, are farmers who own a one hectare field where they grow crops to earn a living for their family. They do not have enough money to support their farming activities. Thus, Mrs. Chanthy H. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline and to pay a laborer to plow.

This couple has seven children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory and two others are farmers who support their parents' farming while the other three are students in the local school. Her husband is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline and to pay a laborer to plow

loans.name: Jona's Group

texts.en: Jona C.'s main source of income comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in her community. She is 31 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the village of Balatacan, Tangub City. Jona has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Jona joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jona is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. Jona is the leader of a three member group accessing a loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Soaphorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Soaphorn E. is 46 years old and is a villager who lives in Tuol Krasang village in Kandal province. She currently stays at home and cooks and also cares for her children. Her husband, Mr. Sarvuth Oeun, is a soldier for which he receives a small salary to support his family. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

In order to increase income to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Soaphorn E. wants to start a new business as a motorcycle taxi driver. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for this purpose. This couple has five children, three of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory, another one is a laborer in a private company while the youngest one is three years old.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Rosemarie

Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. loans.name: Adora's Group

texts.en:

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Adora is married. Adora owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells daily use products such as sugar, salt, sardines, shampoo, soap & toothpaste. Adora has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Adora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Adora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Adora is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. loans.name: Saroeun

Mrs. Saroeun T. is requesting a loan to build a bathroom.

loans.use: To build a bathroom

loans.name: Bopha

In order to increase their income to improve her family's living standards, Mrs. Bopha M. wants to buy a cow for breeding, thus she decided to ask for a loan to support this purpose. This couple has a child who is too young to study or work. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Mrs. K. is a 24-year-old married woman and is a resident in the west of the capital, Phnom Penh. To earn a living, she works sewing clothes in a garment factory and earns a salary of $80 a month. Mrs. K. has a life partner in her husband who appears in the photo. He owns a workshop where he provides a haircutting service for a profit. The couple has a young child.

Mrs. K. finds it hard commuting to work or to anywhere else because she has no vehicle. She is therefore asking for a loan of $600 to add to her personal savings in order to buy a motorcycle for transportation purposes.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for transportation

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yorn C. is 53 years old and is a villager who lives in Thom IDL village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Phan Phai, are farmers who own a one hectare field for cultivating rice. They do not have enough money to support their crop farming. Thus, Mrs. Yorn C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline to support their farming.

This couple has six children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory and another is a laborer while two others are farmers who support their parents' farming and the other two are students at the local school. Mrs. Yorn C.'s husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao S. is 32 years old and lives in Thum village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Voeun Hong, are mushroom farmers who own a plot of land for growing crops to earn a living for their family. They do not have enough money to support their farming. Thus, Mrs. Mao S. decided to ask for a loan to buy mushroom spores and other supplies to support her mushroom farming. With this loan she hopes to increase income to improve her family's living standards. This couple has three children, one of whom is supporting their business while the other two attend the local school. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To buy mushroom spores and other supplies

loans.name: Nayani

texts.en:
Nayani is 29 years old and lives with her husband, two daughters and two sons. Her husband is a driver and he helps her in her business. She works hard and places her priority on operating her business.

Nayani's business involves preparing lunch packets containing rice and curry, which she has been doing for more than ten years. Currently, she prepares thirty lunch packets per day. There is strong competition in her area for selling lunch packets, but Nayani's husband helps her by delivering and selling them to customers at his place of work, which greatly helps the business.

Nayani is seeking a 35,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka which she will use to purchase new kitchen items. She hopes to expand her food delivery area and use the additional income to open her own food cafeteria.

loans.use: To purchase new kitchen items

loans.name: Nheth

texts.en:
Mrs. Nheth L. lives in Kor village in Kandal province. She is 42 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory, and the other two are students in the local school.

Mrs. Nheth L. stays at home, where she cooks and cares for her children. Her husband, Mr. Phea Pon, is a fisherman who earns a small income to support his family. Because her children work far from home, Mrs. Nheth L. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to work. Her husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Pirmahmad

texts.ru: Шарипов Пирмахмад проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст, 58 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сын предоставляет услугу такси. Сам Пирмахмад занимается перевозкой. Образование средне- специальное. По специональности водитель- шофер грузовых автомобилей. Опыт работы 15 лет. Его деятельность приносит доход. Кредит берет для ремонта машины.
texts.en:
Pirmahmad S. lives in the city of Dushanbe. He is 58 years old. He is married and has four children. His wife is a homemaker. His son drives a taxi cab. Pirmahmad does deliveries. He has a secondary specialized education and his profession is a truck driver. He has fifteen years experience. His business give him income and he is taking out the loan to repair his vehicle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair the vehicle

loans.name: Marilyn's Group

texts.en:
Marilyn R. is from the village of San Marcos. She is 23 years old. Marilyn is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marilyn R.'s Group.

Marilyn is single. To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a business selling clothing & shoe products in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jovelyn's Group

texts.en:
Jovelyn P. is from the town of Fugo Jones. She is thirty-one years old. Jovelyn is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jovelyn P.'s group.

Jovelyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jovelyn owns and operates a general store in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jovelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jovelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Jovelyn's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas of the country. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Emely's Group

texts.en:
Emely T. is from the village of Caliguian. She is fifty-five years old. Emely is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Emely T.'s Group.

Emely is married and has six grown children. To make a living, Emely owns and operates a general store in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Emely has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emely joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Emely is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase new items to expand product her offering. This will be Emely's third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Kaniz wants a loan to buy items (chairs, mirror) for her gent’s hair salon. Sugran wants a loan to buy video games for her family's game shop. 

Shamim is the wife of A. A.. She is also the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Lahore, a city famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. 

Shamim has a two-room brick house in which she has been living for the past 25 years. She has given birth to five children: four sons and one daughter. Her eldest son is twenty-eight years old; he couldn’t get an education because of the family's meager financial resources. He has decided to start his own business of cloth-selling so his other siblings can afford to go to school and get an education. He started this business when he turned twenty years old. 

Shamim also helps him by doing the embroidery on simple cloth which attracts the customers and it has become the source of his good earning. So she is applying for a loan to buy seasonal cloth and beads and colored thread to expand her son’s clothes-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and materials for cloth-selling business

loans.name: Annalyn

texts.en:
During her five years at ASHI, Annalyn has shown very good performance as a member, and, because of her solid performance, ASHI trusts her. Aside from maintaining an excellent performance in repayment, business, and attendance at center meetings, Annalyn has also cared for the needs of her children at home and in school.

Annalyn plans to utilize this loan of 20,000 PHP to expand and to support the maintenance of her general store as her family's primary source of daily income. This loan will be used for additional capital to pay for groceries for sale in her store, and she will use any remaining money to improve her small eatery business.

She hopes the loans from ASHI, KIVA's field partner, will support the education of her two children. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, and that it will provide for the educational needs of her children. Annalyn is very grateful to ASHI and KIVA for the continuous love and support she receives for her dreams.

Annalyn R. is a devoted mother to her two children. She is married to her loving spouse, Reynaldo, who is a driver, and she lives in the province of Binangonan, Rizal. Despite many challenges in their life, they never gave up fighting against the umbrella of poverty.

About ASHI:
As a microfinance institution that uses the Grameen methodology and as the first practitioner in the field, Ahon sa Hirap (ASHI)--which means "rise above poverty" in English--saw how these poor women mothers work hard to earn money to provide cash flow for their families and to give their children a better life. Because the microcredit ASHI is extending to these women is delivered directly to their villages and on the doorsteps of their houses, the loans from ASHI are giving these women hope that someday they will rise above poverty.

loans.use: To pay for groceries for sale in her store and to improve her small eatery business.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.ru: Тагоев Хасан проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 53 года. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Жена занимается домашним хозяйством. Сам Хасан более 20 лет занимается животноводством. Он откармливает и продает скот. В этом ему помогают дети. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Hasan T. lives in the Yavan region. He is 53 years old. He is married and has six children. His wife looks after the household. Hasan has been in animal husbandry for more than twenty years. He feeds and sells cattle. His children help him in this business. He is taking out the loan to buy large cattle to increase its count.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy large cattle

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Sajida wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Nasreen wants a loan to buy material (betel nuts, betel leaves) for her Pan Shop. (Pan is an Urdu word used for betel leaves in Pakistan.) Asia wants a loan to buy plastic baby toys for her toy-selling business. Shahnaz is the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all come from a city called Lahore, famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. 

Shahnaz is a 43-year-old woman. She is an uneducated lady because her parents couldn’t afford her education expenses due to lack of financial resources. She has a two-room brick house in which she has been living with her family for the past 22 years. She has given birth to three children: two boys and one daughter. Her sons work in a gas station on monthly wage.  Her daughter is 16 years old and reads in 9th standard.  Her husband's name is S. A. and he is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

Shahnaz is a very hard-working lady. She does embroidery on different items such as tablecloths and pillow covers and sells her embroidery at the market. She does this work to supplement their income. She is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s auto-rickshaw because it’s creating a problem and if it isn’t repaired soon the chances are its engine might seize up which would be a great loss. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Shahnaz is seated second from left holding a piece of embroidered cloth.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
As a mother with big dreams, Margie joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.) in 2007. ASHI is a microfinance institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since joining, Margie started selling ready-to-wear clothes, which has really helped meet her family's needs. Now on her fourth loan, Margie is requesting 17,000 PHP to pay for more inventory for her business. Specifically, she will use the loan to pay for blouses, shirts, kids' jackets, jeans, short pants, and other supplies.

Margie G. is a thirty-one-year-old woman with the determination and faith to get out from the spiral of poverty. She is a mother of four children. She is married to Sotero; a caretaker, and the salary of her husband is insufficient for their daily needs.

She hopes that, with the help of ASHI the KIVA field partner, she can reach her ambition to move out from under the umbrella of poverty, expand her business, and pay for the needs of her four children in school. One of her greatest dreams is to have a house and lot of their own.

About ASHI: 
As a micro-finance institution that uses the Grameen methodology, and as the first practitioner in the field, Ahon sa Hirap (ASHI)--which means "rise above poverty" in English--saw how these poor women mothers work hard to earn money to improve the cash flow for their family and to provide their children with a better life. Because the microcredit ASHI is extending to these women is delivered directly to their villages and on the doorstep of their houses, these loans give these women hope that someday they will rise above poverty.

loans.use: To pay for blouses, shirts, kids' jackets, jeans, short pants, and other supplies for her ready-to-wear clothing business

loans.name: Maka

texts.en:
Maka E. is currently in the business of selling local brew at home and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer to sell.  Maka is 36 years old. Her husband is a teacher. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Kalsoom Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Razia and Safia each want a loan to buy seasonal fruit for their fruit-selling business. Riaz wants a loan to buy wheat for her wheat-selling business. 

Kalsoom akhtar is a 38-year-old woman. She has a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for the past 25 years. She is the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Lahore, famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. 

Her husband's name is M. N. and he has a shoe-selling business. He sells specifically men's shoes in the market. He has been in this business for the past 15 years. Kalsoom has given birth to nine children: seven sons and two daughters. Her eldest son is eighteen years old and runs a cosmetics-selling business. The others are enrolled in school and are getting an education.

As you can see, they have a big family to care for so Kalsoom also offers her services as a seamstress. She sews clothes for her neighbors and earns income. She has been in this profession for the past 10 years. Her neighbors give her orders because of her good stitching. She is applying for a loan to buy cosmetics to expand her son’s cosmetics-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics to sell

She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine for designing.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. loans.name: Ruqaiya's Group

texts.en:
Parveen wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Gulzar wants a loan to buy electric supplies (wires, switches, and tube lights) for her electrical supply-selling business. Majidan wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. Ruqaiya is the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city named Lahore, a city famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. 

Ruqaiya is a 48-year-old married woman. She has a two-room house and has been living in it with her family for the past 40 years. Her husband's name is M. A. and he is a mason by profession. She is the mother of five kids: three sons and two daughters. Her eldest son is involved in a furniture-making business. The one after him does embroidery on clothes. Her elder daughter helps her by dealing with the customers. The others don’t do anything. She is applying for a loan to buy bedsheets in bulk to expand her bedsheet-selling business.

loans.use: To buy bedsheets to sell

She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Ester's Group

texts.en:
Ester C. is from the town of Pagrang-Ayan Ramon. She is thirty-eight years old. Ester is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Ester C.'s group.

Ester is married. To make a living, Ester owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and for sale. Ester has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

Ester has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. She used the previous loan to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Ester is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Ester's second loan taken from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand it.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Kawoto North Christine Kakande Group

texts.en: Christine K. is a hardworking businesswoman who is a forty-year-old widow with six children, two of whom are going to school. She is also looking after two of her siblings who go to school. She has been selling clothing for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase more clothes to sell. She is a determined businesswoman whose future hope is to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:

She has seven children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a maize flour store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. texts.en: Jesica M. is a 35-year-old single mother of two children who all go to school. She has three additional dependents, one of whom goes to school. She has been in the business of selling clothes since 2008. She is using the loan to purchase more clothes to sell. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose future hope is to obtain a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Jada

texts.en:
Jada F. is currently in the business of selling bread and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock onions to sell.  Jada is 30 years old and her husband is a peasant. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Deepani

texts.en:
Deepani is a 46-year-old married woman living with her husband and three children who are still studying. She and her husband process the business together, which is a tailoring shop.

Deepani started her business seven years ago. She first started with a Singer sewing machine but upgraded to a Juckey machine with her first loan from BRAC. With this loan, she plans to purchase a new overlock machine, which will increase the quality of her tailoring services.

Deepani is seeking a 30,000 LKR loan from BRAC to purchase cloth for her business and help pay for her new overlock machine.

In her business, Deepani and her husband work together cooperatively and she is hardworking. She has seen success because, with the help of her Juckey machine, her services have been of very high quality.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine and more cloth

loans.name: Aya

texts.en:
Aya V. is currently in the business of selling bread at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil and tomatoes to sell.  Aya is 20 years old and her husband is a driver. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: Vong S., aged 47, is married and resides with her four children in Takeo province, Cambodia. She is engaged in the agriculture sector as a farmer, earning an income of USD 0.5 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband (pictured) is a middleman involved in selling cows. He travels in his province every day to purchase cows from the villagers and earns an income of USD 1 per day. The family's standard of living has improved since Vong S. has had this business. She is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more cows for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, the Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy cows to sell

loans.name: Ufunuo Group

texts.en:
Amina R., age 48, is married with three children, ages 29, 24 and 12 years old. She has had a charcoal business since 2001. She works from 6 am to 8 pm daily and she is able to earn a monthly profit of about $104. 

This will be Amina’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first loan to increase her charcoal stock. She hopes for a new loan to go to the forest herself and collect the charcoal of her choice. 

Amina will share this loan with her loan group, Ufunuo, which totals 19 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. In the picture, Amina is behind in a red dress.

loans.use: To start going into the forest and collecting the charcoal herself

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes J. is currently in the business of selling bags of groundnuts (peanuts) and sim-sim (sesame) and is requesting a loan to buy stock of beans and maize flour to sell. She is 35 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.
