The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy stock of beans and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Khan

texts.en:
Khan O., aged 28, is married and resides with her three children in Takeo province, Cambodia. She is engaged in a business which produces fabric for cleaning cars, earning an income of USD 0.7 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband is employed to transport dirt to fill out people’s land, earning an income of USD 3.5 per day. Their standard of living has improved since O. has had this business.

She is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a new sewing machine to expand her current business and to produce more products for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: El

texts.en: El N., aged 53, is married and resides with her three children in Takeo province, Cambodia. She is engaged in the agriculture sector as a farmer, earning an income of USD 1 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband is a construction worker in the city, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day. Their standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses. N. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Jogoo Group

texts.en:
Grace K., 49, is married with three children aged 27, 22 and 16. She has a flour milling business which she started in 2006. She works from 9am to 8pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $88.

This will be Grace’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She hopes for a new loan to increase her stock by buying more maize.

Grace will share this loan with her loan group, Jogoo, which has 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the photo, Grace is in the front row in a white t-shirt.

loans.use: To buy more maize for milling

loans.name: Ing

texts.en: Ing N. is married and resides with her four children in Takeo province, Cambodia. She is engaged in the agriculture sector as a farmer, earning an income of USD 1 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband operates his motorbike as a driver in the city, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Their standard of living has improved since Ing N.’s husband has had this business. She is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a compartment attached to her husband's motorbike to expand his business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a compartment attached to the motorbike

loans.name: Khemisa

texts.en:
Khemisa L. is currently in the business of selling bread and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to buy a stock of fish to sell. Khemisa is 28 years old and married with a husband who is a driver. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy stock of fish to sell

loans.name: Rang

texts.en: Rang N., aged 31, is married and resides with his children in Takeo province, Cambodia. He has three children, one of whom is sent to a local primary school. He and his wife are engaged in the business of selling hand-made brooms, earning an income of USD 4 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Their standard of living has improved since Rang N. has had this business. He is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a motorbike to transport his brooms to sell. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Lweza South Nakifubi Devine Group

texts.en: N. Devine is a 45-year-old businesswoman. She is married with six children of whom more than one is going to school so she has three dependants. She owns a retail shop which she has been operating for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase shop items such as sugar, salt, soap, etc. for sale. Her future hope is to obtain a plot of land and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase shop items such as sugar, salt, soap, etc. for sale

loans.name: Luke

texts.en:
Luke E. is currently in the business of selling bread and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to buy a stock of onions to sell.  Luke E. is 43 years old and is widowed. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy stock of onions to sell

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Leng C., aged 52, is married and resides with her 16-year-old child in Takeo province, Cambodia. She is engaged in the business of producing and selling hand-made brooms in the city, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband is a middleman involved in buying and selling cows at the market, earning an income of USD 3 per day. He travels in his province every day to purchase cows from the villagers. Their standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses. Leng C. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase chickens to raise for sale. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy chickens to raise for sale

loans.name: Masolidi Nansubuga Rachael Group

texts.en:
N. Rachael is a hardworking business lady who is twenty-five years old.  She is married with three children, of whom two are going to school. 

She has been in the poultry business since the year 2006. She is using the loan to purchase feed, drugs, chicks, and so forth for her poultry business. She is a promising lady whose dream or future plan is to obtain a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase feed, drugs, chicks, and so forth for her poultry business.

loans.name: Anesia

texts.en: Anesia M. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old, married and has 5 adult children. Anesia owns and operates a business buying and selling bananas in the local community. Anesia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Anesia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anesia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anesia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chourb

texts.en:
Chourb R., age 28, is married and resides with his children in Takeo province, Cambodia. He has three children. He is engaged in the agriculture sector of grinding rice for sale, earning an income of 3 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. His wife (pictured) is engaged in a business of weaving Cambodian traditional products, earning an income of 2 USD per day.

Their standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses. R. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase more raw silk to produce more silk products for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: Buy raw silk to produce silk products

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Mary is 42 years old and is married to a soldier. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Masolidi Tenywa Olivia Group

texts.en:
T. Olivia is a hardworking businesswoman, thirty-five years old. She is married with five children schooling and has three dependents of whom one is schooling.

Olivia makes bricks and she has been making bricks for over eight years so far. She is using the loan to make more bricks for sale.

Olivia is a strong businesswoman whose future hopes are to obtain land, build a house, and improve upon the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To make more bricks for sale

loans.name: Elma

texts.en: Elma R. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 50 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Elma owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling ready-to-wear items like shoes, shirts and other items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Elma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Elma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chi

texts.en:
Chi N., age 42, is married and lives with her four children in Takeo province, Cambodia.

N. is engaged in a business weaving Cambodian traditional silk products, earning an income of 2 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is a farmer growing rice on his own plot of farmland, earning an income of 1.50 USD per day.

Their standard of living has been improved since N. has had this business. She is requesting a loan of 1,100 USD to purchase more raw silk to produce silk products. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more silk for her silk-weaving business

loans.name: Makele

texts.en:
Makele A. is currently in the business of selling tea on the street in the evening and is requesting a loan to stock more sugar and tea leaves. Makele, 45 years old and married to a teacher, is the mother of two children, both students. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more sugar and tea leaves

loans.name: Pacita's Group

texts.en:
Pacita A. is from the town of Aguinaldo Cordon. She is 53 years old. Pacita is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Pacita A..

Pacita is married and has 4 adult children. Pacita owns & operates a fruit and vegetable retail business. Pacita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Pacita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Pacita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Pacita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Pacita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Twegate A Tuhirwe Stella Group

texts.en: Stella T. , a 31-year-old hardworking businesswoman, is the married mother of three children, all going to school. For the past two years she has been selling spare bicycle parts and is requesting the loan to purchase additional spare parts from Kampala to sell to her customers. The extra capital will allow her to expand her business and earn better profits, bringing her closer to realizing her dream of fully educating her children.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts from Kampala to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Gunne

texts.en:
Gunne M., currently in the business of selling tea and bread, is requesting a loan to stock more sugar. Gunne, 22 years old and married to a policeman, is the mother of one child who does not yet go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rental purposes.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more sugar

loans.name: Meoun

texts.en:
Meoun M., age 59, is married and resides with his four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Meoun and his wife are engaged in a business buying mangoes for sale, earning an income of $3 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. Two of their children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of $2 each per day to partly assist the family’s expense. Their standard of living has improved since Meoun and his wife started this business, and he is now requesting a loan of $800 to purchase motorbike repair equipment to start a new business to generate a better income. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

Meoun's wife is pictured.

loans.use: To buy motorbike repair equipment

loans.name: Wasuk

texts.en:
Wasuk S., currently in the business of selling ice cream and bread, is requesting a loan to stock more bread to sell. Wasuk, 37 years old and married to an electrician, is the mother of two children, both students. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rental purpose.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bread to sell

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Kun S., age 48, is married and lives with her three children in Takeo province, Cambodia.

S. is engaged in a business selling vegetables and meat in her village, earning an income of 3 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is a soldier for the province, earning an income of 2 USD per day.

Their standard of living has been improved since S. has had her business. She is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to use for commuting

loans.name: Oun

texts.en:
Oun M., age 52, is married and lives with her three children in Takeo province, Cambodia.

M. is a farmer, earning an income of 2 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is employed at a non-governmental organization in the city, earning an income of 2 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since M. and her husband have had these businesses.

M. is requesting a loan of 600 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband  to use to commute to work. By doing so, she hopes that she will be able to cut back on public transportation expenses for her husband and save more money. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to use for commuting

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Pheng Y., age 29, is married and resides with her five-year-old child in Takeo province, Cambodia.

Y. is engaged in a business sewing clothes, earning an income of 3 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband (pictured) is a construction worker, earning an income of 3 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Y. and her husband have had these businesses.

Y. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase calves to raise for sale. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy calves to raise and sell

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly K., age 36, is married and resides with her two children in Takeo province, Cambodia.

K. is engaged in a business selling nylons, earning an income of 2.30 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband operates his motorbike as a driver in the city, earning an income of 3.30 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since K. and her husband have had these businesses.

K. is requesting a loan of 1,100 USD to purchase more nylons for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more nylons for sale

loans.name: Twegate A Nawaho Esther Group

texts.en:
N. Esther is a hardworking business lady, twenty-four years old, who is married with two children of whom one is going to school. More so, she is looking after one dependent  who is schooling, too.

Esther has operated a retail shop business for a year now. The shop is expanding and she is using the loan to purchase retail shop items such as sugar, salt, soap, flour, and so forth.

Esther is an encouraging business lady whose dream is to educate her children and work very hard for the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more sugar, salt, soap, flour, and so forth

loans.name: Soth

texts.en:
Soth C., age 26, is married and lives with her five-year-old child in Takeo province, Cambodia.

C. is engaged in the business of selling various kinds of groceries at home, earning an income of 1.30 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is employed as a repairman at a local factory in the city, earning an income of 3.30 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since C. and her husband have had these businesses.

C. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase more groceries to stock her store. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock her store

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok V., age 29, is married and lives with her two-year-old child in Takeo province, Cambodia.

V. is engaged in the business of sewing clothes in the city, earning an income of 2.30 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband operates his motorbike as a driver in the city, earning an income of 3.30 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since V. and her husband have had these businesses.

V. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase clothes to sell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Chek

texts.en:
Chek L., age 23, is married and resides with her one-year-old child in Takeo province, Cambodia.

L. is engaged in the business of weaving Cambodian traditional silk products, earning an income of 2 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is a security guard for a private company, earning an income of 2 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since L. and her husband have had these businesses.

L. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase more raw silk to produce more output of the famous silk products. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more silk for her silk-weaving business

loans.name: Twegate A Kyanshama Dorothy Group

texts.en:
K. Dorothy is thirty-three years old and is a married woman blessed with four children of whom two are going to school.

Dorothy is a farmer and has been in farming for over five years. She is using the loan to invest in her farm for a better harvest.

Dorothy is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To invest in her farm

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha owns a 2-hectare (5-acre) cornfield in Norala, South Cotabato. She has a good harvest on it and it really helps her family.

Editha started her farming business way back in 2007. Today she is requesting a loan of 15,000 Php from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy farm supplies.

Editha is 48 years old and has five children, her eldest child being 18 years old. She wants her children to finish their studies soon and that’s why she works hard on the farm to provide their needs as a family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Tsetsegmaa

texts.en: Tsetsegmaa is 57 years old and lives with her daughter and granddaughter in an apartment in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. During the day, she operates a clothing and small consumer products business at a counter. She sells men's and women's clothes and approximately 60 other types of products, including buttons, zippers, shoe polish and glue. Tsetsegmaa has been operating her business since 1993 and has gained much experience as a businesswomen. She is an honest and optimistic person. Tsetsegmaa says, “I am working hard to increase my working capital, profit and revenue as well as to keep average daily revenue no less than 50,000 tugrugs (~ 35USD).” She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~ 705 USD) loan to purchase additional inventory, including men's and women's clothing and other small products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Jose Vic

texts.en:
Jose combines rice farming with a duck raising business. He finds the combination hard to handle. He started these businesses in 2001. Today he manages a 1-hectare rice field and 500 ducks. He finds it difficult to find additional capital.

Jose, 30 years old, is from Norala, South Cotabato. He joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in 2008. Currently he is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy farm supplies and feed for the ducks. This would really help his business and family.

loans.use: farm supplies and feed

loans.name: Marilyn's Group

texts.en:
Marilyn T. is from the village of Centro 2, Angadanan, Isabela. She is 33 years old. Marilyn is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marilyn T..

Marilyn is married and has 1 school-aged child. Marilyn owns & operates a cosmetic retail business, directly selling products such as talcum powder, perfumes &  body lotions. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Marilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees. 
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Rosana, 31, is a rice farmer in Norala, South Cotabato. Her business is a big help to her family. It provides their daily food and helps them repay the amount borrowed from Community Economic Ventures, Inc.

Rosana is a mother of two children, the eldest 4 years old. She lacks capital to provide all the supplies needed for her farm, which is why she sought help from CEVI and asked for a loan of 15,000 PHP. This will really help her business venture.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Irène Flore

texts.fr: Née en 1965 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, D. Irène Flore est mariée à HOUENOU Filbert, un imprimeur. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés. Il y a près de deux ans que Irène Flore s'est installée à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Les différentes charges de la famille sont supportées par Irène Flore et son mari. Irène Flore n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis 26 ans, Irène Flore mène comme activité, la vente de tissus et des ustensiles de cuisine, de façon ambulante. Cette activité lui procure des revenus qui l'aident à subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Irène Flore s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Irène Flore désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et rehausser ainsi son activité, afin de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle. Compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose, Irène Flore sollicite un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1965 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, Irène Flore D. is married to Filbert HOUENOU, a printer. The couple has two children, both at school. Almost two years ago Irène Flore settled down in Agblangandan, in the town of Sème-Podji. The various family expenses are covered by both Irène Flore and her husband. Irène Flore attended primary school only. For the past twenty-six years she has had a business selling fabrics and kitchen equipment on a door-to-door basis. This business procures an income which helps her to provide for her needs and those of her children. Irène Flore gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market in Bénin. She would like to increase her stock and thereby expand her business, in order to respond better to customer demand. In view of the limited financial means which she has, Irène Flore is applying for a first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabrics and kitchen equipment (sets of bowls, basins etc.)

loans.name: Twegate B Kayesu Annet Group

texts.en:
Annet K. is a 22-year-old business lady. She is married with two children, of whom one is going to school, and she has two other dependents schooling too. She has been dealing in the clothing business for five years so far. 

She is using the loan to purchase clothes from different towns to bring to Kisekende for sale. She is adding stock, which is improving her business. Her future hope is to work very hard for the welfare of her family, especially the children.

loans.use: To purchase clothes from different towns to bring to Kisekende trading center for sale

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
Nelita owns a small resto store in Norala, South Cotabato. She found it hard to look for additional capital for her business until she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. Her store started to operate in 1994 and later, in 2008, she became a member of CEVI. 

Today she has requested a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos. She needs it in order to buy more groceries for her store. This will be helpful to her since she has five children she needs to support.

loans.use: Groceries

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann manages a sari-sari (variety) store and at the same time runs a 2-hectare rice field. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because it helps a lot in sustaining her businesses. With its low interest charge, it helps finance her businesses well.

She is 36 years old and living in Norala, South Cotabato. The eldest of her four children is 14 years old. She hopes for a brighter future for them.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Bud

texts.en:
Bud C., age 55, is married and resides with her children in the Takeo province in Cambodia. She has six children. She is engaged in a business of selling peanuts, earning an income of $2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Her husband is a motorbike repairman, earning an income of $3 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since C. and her husband have had these businesses. 

C. is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike with a compartment attached. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike with a compartment attached

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is an entrepreneur who does business in rice and pig farming. She manages a 3-hectares rice field and a piggery. She said that her business is going well because of the help of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She’s been a member of CEVI, a Kiva partner, since 2008. 

She is currently asking for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos to continually support her business. She supports four children in her family. She is determined to do her best in providing for the needs of her family.

loans.use: Feeds and farm inputs

loans.name: Geralyn

texts.en:
With pig farming and rice farming, Geralyn’s family is sustained. She is 29 years old and from Norala, South Cotabato. In the year 2000, she started these farming businesses. Today she manages a 4-hectare rice field and a piggery with 20 piglets. 

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to back up her business with additional capital. She requested 15,000 Philippine pesos to buy farm supplies and feeds.

loans.use: Feeds and farm supplies

loans.name: Elvira's Group

texts.en:
Elvira T. is from the village of Calamagui, San Pablo, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Elvira is the group leader of a 17-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elvira is married and has 3 school-aged children. Elvira owns & operates a general store where she sells daily-use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste. Elvira has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elvira joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elvira has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Elvira from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees.  

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen, 49, has 1-hectare rice field and a sari-sari store. Aside from that, she also raises pigs. At first, she borrowed money from other dealers to have capital but she only profits very little because of high interest. When Community Economic Ventures, Inc. came, it made it easier for her to secure additional capital and her business is progressing.

She is currently requesting a loan of 15,000 Php. This will allow her to buy farm supplies and groceries. She works as much as she can to support her family and her 3 children.

loans.use: farm supplies and groceries to sell

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: 53-year-old Edna borrows money from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to support her sari-sari store and 1-hectare rice field. She joined CEVI in August 2008 and her business is growing. This time she needs to purchase groceries and farm inputs. She requested a loan of 15,000 Php to use for the needs of her businesses. This will really help her in making progress with her businesses.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Twegate B Kyarimpa Asumpta Group

texts.en: K. Asumpta is a businesswoman of forty-two years old, she is widowed with five children, all schooling. She rears cows and she has been rearing cows for over seventeen years. She is using the loan to add more cows to her stock for expansion. She is a hard-working businesswoman whose dream is to invest for her children’s education.

loans.use: To add more cows to her stock for expansion

loans.name: Soth

texts.en:
Soth P., age 24, is married and resides with her children in Takeo province, Cambodia. She has two children. She and her husband are engaged in a business buying rice for resale, earning an income of USD 5 each per day to help cover the family expenses. They also raise pigs at home for another source of income as well. Their standard of living has improved since P. and her husband have had this business. 

P. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase a new motorbike with a trailer attached to transport the rice to sell at the market. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike to transport rice for sale

loans.name: Jaber

texts.en:
J. is a 25-year-old man and an employee of the Palestinian National Authority where he receives a very simple salary. J. applied for a loan from FATEN to cover a part of his marriage expenses as none of his family members could help him. His father and brother are the only other working members of his family and their salaries can cover only their living expenses.

J. loves his job and doesn't want to change since he believes in what he does and that his job is important to keep the city disciplined and in order.

J. appears in FATEN's office in Tulkarem branch.

loans.use: Marriage expenses

loans.name: Hurelbaatar

texts.en:
Hurelbaatar is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hentii province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent, in a yard that belongs to his relatives. His wife is a government worker earning 160,000 tugrugs (~ 112 USD) per month. Hurelbaatar operates a gold and silver goods business. He makes silver bowls, men's and women's silver belt buckles, and saddles with silver or gold decorations. 

Hurelbaatar has been operating his business since 1991 and has steadily expanded the business and become more experienced. He operated his business from his home until December 2009 when he began to rent a counter at the Ochmanlai trading center. Currently, his average daily revenue is 20,000 – 25,000 tugrugs (~ 15 - 20 USD), and his total monthly revenue exceeds 1,000,000 – 1,500,000 tugrugs (~ 705 – 1055 USD). Sometimes customers buy Hurelbaatar's products on credit, but they always pay the money back on time. Hurelbaatar has a loyal customer base because of his excellent service and experience of 19 years. Furthermore, he has been planning to expand his business in the future. 

Besides his gold and silver business, Hurelbaatar has operated a vegetable trading business since 2007. He planted 2.5 tons of potatoes on his land and sold all of them. Hurelbaatar is a very hard-working person who has a great business mind. His business is very important for him and he says, “I have been operating my gold and silver goods business for a long time, and I love my job. People like to buy my products, because I am dedicated to my craft.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~ 1407 USD) loan to purchase more silver and other materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for silver and gold-working

loans.name: Devika

texts.en:
Devika is a 39-year-old married woman living with her husband, two children, and Devika's mother. Her husband is a mechanic and her two daughters are still studying.  Devika has a tailoring business that she has been running for three years.  She is known to be a hard worker and independent in running her business on her own.

Devika is seeking a 30,000 LKR loan from BRAC in order to buy cloth for her tailoring business.  

In the future, she hopes to give higher education to her children and to pay their tuition.

loans.use: to buy new cloth for her business

loans.name: Twegate B Nakasoma Leonsia Group

texts.en: N. Leonsia is a hard-working business lady of twenty-five; she lives with her spouse and they are blessed with two children of whom one is schooling. She has one dependent, also schooling. She has had a banana plantation and goats for over four years. She is using the loan to purchase more goats and any remainder for her banana plantation for better production. She is encouraging and her dream is to work for the welfare of her children.

loans.use: To purchase more goats and use any remainder for her banana plantation

loans.name: Jumoke

texts.en:
Jumoke is 45 years old, married and has 3 children aged 10, 12, and 13. Her husband is a trader and they all reside in Lagos state, Nigeria.
 
Jumoke has a shop; she sells drinks to her costumers at wholesale and retail prices. She has been in this business for 15 years now. She buys directly from the company sales representative. She hopes to expand her business by buying more drinks to sell and to have another shop. 

She is asking for a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more drinks to sell to increase her profit. She promises to pay back by the due date and she says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Pheouk

texts.en:
Pheouk S., age 53, is widowed and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has two children. She is engaged in the agriculture sector, growing vegetables for sale, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover family expenses. The family is also assisted financially by one of her children who is employed as a housekeeper at a hotel, earning an income of USD 3 per day. 

Their standard of living has improved since S. has had this business. S. is requesting a loan of 600 USD to purchase a motorbike for her child to commute to work. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for her daughter to commute to work

loans.name: Hoy

texts.en:
Hoy V., age 39, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has six children. She is employed as a teacher at a public primary school in the province, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who is a farmer growing rice, earning an income of USD 5 per day. 

Their standard of living has improved since V. and her husband have had these businesses. V. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase pigs to raise and fish for sale. This is her third loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva. V. is pictured in front of her classroom at school.

loans.use: buy pigs to raise and fish to sell

loans.name: Odion

texts.en:
Odion sells groceries and drinks at retail prices. She has been in this business for three years. She is 39 years old and is married with three children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their household.  She is a hard working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.

She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and a generator. She says thank-you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and a generator

loans.name: Kamu Kamu B Nasade Specioza Group

texts.en: N. Specioza is thirty-four years old, married with two children schooling and two other dependents of whom one is schooling, too. She is dealing with clothes and sells soft drinks since she has a fridge in her shop; she has run her business for over five years. She is using the loan to purchase clothes and drinks (sodas, passion fruit, etc) for sale. She is a hard-working businesswoman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and drinks (sodas, passion fruits, etc) for sale.

loans.name: Dy

texts.en:
Dy S., age 38, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is engaged in a business of selling wooden furniture, earning an income of $5.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband, who sells firewood, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since S. and her husband have had these businesses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more firewood and furniture to sell. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: Buy firewood and wooden furniture for sale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 64 years old, married and has 5 children.  Her youngest child is 25 and is doing fine. She is a trader; she sells fruit juice, bottled water and drinks at her shop in front of the house where she and her family live in Lagos. She started this business 28 years ago. 
She manages the business with her husband who is a retired officer. 

She is requesting a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more drinks, fruit juice, and bottled water to sell to increase her profits. This will enable her to expand her business and sell wholesale and retail in the future. She thanks Kiva for their wonderful support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, fruit juice, and bottled water to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther sells ice cream and sachet water (water in plastic bags) at retail prices. Children in her community love her because she sells varieties of ice cream. She has been in this business for 5 years. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She needs a loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more bags of sachet water to sell.

Esther is married with 3 children. She is 35 years old. She says thank-you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of sachet water to sell

loans.name: Rowena's Group

texts.en:
Rowena S. is from the village of Remus, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 24 years old. Rowena is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rowena is married and has 2 young children. Rowena owns and operates a livestock business, raising pigs for breeding. Rowena just started this business a few months ago.

In 2009, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rowena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Rem

texts.en:
Rem P., age 28, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has three children. She is engaged in a business of producing and selling traditional Cambodian cakes and desserts, earning an income of $2.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

The family is also assisted by her husband, who is a construction worker in the town, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since P. and her husband have had these businesses. 

P. is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase a plot of farmland to produce more rice products for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: Buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Kamu Kamu B Nampewo Edith Group

texts.en:
Edith N. is 31 years old and a businesswoman. She is married with two children schooling and has two additional dependents staying with her. 

She has had a retail shop for over 10 years. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, and so forth, for resale as well increasing her business stock. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, and so forth for sale as well increasing her business stock

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mrs. M. is 40 years old and the mother of two children. One of them is married and lives independently and other one is single, living in the family home. M. currently works as an internal staff member for a private company, earning a suitable salary. M. has another financial contributor in her husband named Phoeun, age 48, who is a local cultivator. 

In the past, M.’s husband also hired a cow to help with plowing his farmland during the farming season. He wants to cut out this fee; he discussed this with his wife and they have decided to ask for a loan in order to purchase a pair of cows to facilitate the field-plowing.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of cows to facilitate the field-plowing

loans.name: Ne'ma

texts.en:
Ne'ma is a 22-year-old woman and the mother of two girls and two boys. Her husband Basil is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority and has a very simply salary which barely covers big family expenses, so she decided to rent a shop and start a small supermarket.

A lot of clients come to Ne'ma's supermarket so Ne'ma requested a loan from FATEN to expand it and have a larger amount of goods to answer the demand.

Because Ne'ma comes from a conservative family her husband Basil appears in the picture above.

loans.use: Improving the supermarket

loans.name: Kamu Kamu D Nakasi Winnie Group

texts.en: N. Winnie is an encouraging businesswoman of thirty-three years old, a single mother of three children, all going to school. She is looking after one orphan (girl) who is schooling, too. She runs a restaurant business which she has been operating for over twelve years. She is using the loan to purchase restaurant items such as a variety of food like bananas, maize flour for 'posho', rice, cassava, sweet potatoes, Irish potatoes and so forth to prepare food for her customers. She is a hard-working businesswoman whose dreams are to expand her restaurant business, build a house, and educate the children.

loans.use: To purchase restaurant items such as  bananas, maize flour, etc.

loans.name: Neoun

texts.en:
Neoun L., age 30, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is engaged in a business of selling fruit, earning an income of USD 4 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who is employed to look after motorbikes at a tourist place in the town, earning an income of USD 4 per day. 

Their standard of living has improved since L. and her husband have had these businesses. L. is requesting a loan of 600 USD to purchase more fruit for sale and wood to repair their house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, Kiva's partner. (L. is pictured cooking lunch with her husband.)

loans.use: buy more fruit to sell and wood to repair their house

loans.name: Célestin

texts.fr: Né en 1970 à Allada dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin, T. Célestin vit depuis 11 ans au quartier Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Célestin est marié à ADJIDOKOUN Virginie, une ménagère. Le couple a trois enfants à charge, dont deux sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents à Agla. Le couple supporte ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Célestin exerce comme activité, la vente d'appareils électroniques (hauts parleurs, DVD, radios, télévisions, des cadres, etc.) à Godomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Célestin s'approvisionne au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin. Dans l'optique de renforcer son activité et d'équiper sa boutique de nouveaux appareils de sonorisation, en vue de mieux répondre aux exigences de la clientèle, Célestin sollicite pour la première fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Allada in the "département" (administrative district) of Atlantique in Bénin, Célestin T. has lived for 11 years in the Agla neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Célestin is married to Virginie ADJIDOKOUN, a housekeeper. The couple have three children in their care, two of whom are their own children. All the children are at school and live with their parents in Agla. The couple cover the various family expenses between them. For around ten years Célestin has been selling electronic appliances (loudspeakers, DVD players, radios, televisions, antennas etc.) in Godomey in the municipality of Abomey Calavi. Célestin gets his supplies in Nigeria, a neighoring state of Bénin. With a view to strengthening his business and getting new sound system appliances for his shop, in order to satisfy his customer demands more readily, Célestin is applying for the first time for a loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of loudspeakers, DVD players and other sound system appliances

loans.name: Lolita's Group

texts.en:
Lolita Q. is from the village of Cabisera 27, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 50 years old. Lolita is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lolita Q..

Lolita is widowed and has 5 school-aged children. Lolita owns & operates a livestock business, raising pigs for fattening and sale. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Lolita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Lolita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Kamu Kamu D Nakafuma Robinah Group

texts.en: N. Robinah is a wonderful business lady and the group representative. She is twenty-seven years old, a single lady with three children of whom two are going to school, and she has six dependents of whom two are going to school, too. She runs a business roasting chickens for sale. She has been doing this business for over eleven years. She is using the loan to add capital to her business by purchasing plenty of chickens to roast for her customers. She is a hard-working business lady whose dream is to prosper.

loans.use: To add capital to her business by purchasing plenty of chickens to roast

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort sells local gin at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She is a widow with three children. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family. She hopes for a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase more local gin to sell. She hopes to expand her business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more local gin to sell

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Yun S., age 37, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is engaged in the agriculture sector, farming, fishing, and raising animals at home, earning an income of USD 4 per day to help cover family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who always helps his wife in the current businesses, earning the same amount of income. 

Their standard of living has improved since S. and her husband have had these businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to buy pigs to raise. With the remainder, she wants to repair the roof of her house before the rainy season arrives. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: buy pigs and repair the roof of the house

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Mrs. C., 40, gets clothing items from the factory and prepares them as sets of clothes for a fee. She can earn around US$ 5 per day, which currently covers the family’s expenses. She has a partner in her husband who owns a car that he uses to provide a taxi service. 

Because her husband's taxi is old and often needs repairs, he cannot attract many customers. He has noticed that lately his income has declined, as well. C. is asking for a loan of US$ 700 to mend/refurbish an old taxi. The loan will allow her husband to attract more customers and thereby increase the family’s income.

loans.use: To mend/refurbish an old taxi

loans.name: Fokaben Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Fokaben, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 47 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Siemana, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de l’argile.
Ces femmes du groupe Fokaben sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre précédents.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, des sacs d’argile blanche. Elles s’approvisionnent le plus généralement à  Barouéli et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Barouéli et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée exclusivement de femmes qui restent les seules consommatrices de cette matière.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women in the Fokaben group are all married, average 47 years of age, have an average of three children and live in extended traditional families in the village of Siemana, in the prefecture of Barouéli, in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met each other through relatives, and trade in clay. The women of the Fokaben group are on their fifth group loan, having repaid without incident the four previous loans. This new loan will be used to buy bags of white clay. They get most of their supplies in Barouéli and sell on the market in Barouéli and in surrounding fairs, for cash, on a retail basis, and on credit, to a customer base made up exclusively of women, who are the sole consumers of this material. They envisage making an average monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA each which will be used for daily family expenses, with the balance been reinvested in their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of white clay

loans.name: Srimathi

texts.en:
Srimathi is a 34-year-old married woman living in Kekanadura, Matara with her husband and three children who are still studying. Her husband is an army officer.

Srimathi has a small business making string hoppers, which are a form of long thin rice noodles, which she sells to local stores and food cabins. Every morning she wakes up early to make the food to be sold to the shops, and she has been doing it for four years now.

When Srimathi’s husband is not busy with military duties, he assists her in the business. Her children help her as well when they have the time. She has a very good location for her business, as she supplies food next to some government offices so the nearby businessmen purchase breakfast and dinner very often.

Srimathi has requested a 45,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to purchase new equipment for her food production business.

In the future, Srimathi hopes to pay the rental fee for her rented paddy field and to pay her children’s tuition fees using earnings from her business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for food production

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth sells VCDs at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She is 26 years old and married with two children. She is a hardworking woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She has been in this business for a year. She hopes to expand her business. Ruth hopes for a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more VCDs to sell. She says a very big thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Abdou Ganiou

texts.fr: Cet homme est un père de famille, il a 02  enfants et sa femme est une coiffeuse, pour subvenir aux charges quotidiennes de sa famille, il s’est lancé dans le commerce de détail de pneus. Il a une clientèle très  grande. Il s’approvisionne au marché local du port de Lomé. le stock dont il dispose actuellement ne lui permet pas de satisfaire ses clients raison pour laquelle il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter  une vingtaine de pneus.
texts.en:
This man is the father of two children and his wife works as a hairdresser. To meet daily family responsibilities, he took up the business of selling tires at retail. He has a large client base. He gets his supplies at the local market at the port of Lomé. His current stock does not allow him to meet the demand of his clients; he is therefore requesting a loan from WAGES to buy about about 20 tires.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy tires

loans.name: Kamu Kamu A Bagutatira Rehema Group

texts.en:
B. Rehema is the representative for this group loan. She is a hardworking, 45-year-old businesswoman who is single and blessed with six children, four of whom attend school. She also looks after four grown-up dependants.
Rehema has owned a restaurant for over seven years. She is using her loan to purchase foodstuffs for the restaurant (such as bananas, maize flour for posho, rice, cassava, sweet potatoes and Irish potatoes, etc.) and sauce ingredients (meat, chicken, fish, vegetables, beans, and so forth) to meet customer demand. Rehema is an active businesswoman whose dreams are to educate her children and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs and ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Oluwakemi

texts.en:
Oluwakemi, 30 years old, owns a boutique. She sells shoes, clothes, bags and more. She uses the profit made from her sales to help her husband keep their home. She is happily married with three children. She has been a member of LAPO microfinance for some years with a good record.

Oluwakemi wants to buy more of her goods to sell. This will attract discount that will generate more profit for the growth of the business. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more shoes, clothes and bags to sell. Her dream is to order her goods on time and meet her customers' demands. She says thanks to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes, clothes and bags to sell

loans.name: Godwill

texts.en: Godwill is 40 years old and married with eight children. His children are excelling in school and this makes him happy. He sells beef at the market and his business is doing fine. He has been in this business for five years. He hopes to expand his business. He hopes for a loan of N140,000 to purchase more beef to sell. He appreciates all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more beef to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda P. is from the village of Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Erlinda owns and operates a business providing general clothing services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Erlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 10th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: 07.05.03 Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en: Tinh L. T. (19) is a 56-year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa. She is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 07.05.03 H. Hoa Group. Tinh is married and has four adult children. She owns and operates a business raising cattL. for saL.. She has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month. In 2003, Tinh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase calves to raise and sell. Tinh is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will again be used to purchase calves to raise and sell. The loan will be her 6th from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. N. T. Hiep (13) is a 54-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 2. N. T. Truong (5) is a 28-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her service-based business. 3. L. T. Sam (37) is a 51-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 4. H. T. Phuc (18) is a 62-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Tinh L. T. (19) là 56 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa. Tinh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 07,05,03 (07,05,03 H. Hoa). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán. Tinh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 4 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Tinh kiếm được khoảng 1,500,000 VND. Vào 2003, Tinh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Tinh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. N. T. Hiep (13) là 54 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. N. T. Truong (5) là 28 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. 3. L. T. Sam (37) là 51 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. H. T. Phuc (18) là 62 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase calves to raise and sell

loans.name: Sidoine

texts.fr: G. Sidoine est née le 22 Novembre 1982 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Sidoine vit depuis 15 ans à Cocotomey, dans la communne d'Abomey Calavi. Mariée à GONSAVES Salomon, un transitaire, Sidoine  est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé. Sidoine a un autre enfant à sa charge. Sidoine assure avec son mari les différentes charges familiales. Sidoine a très peu fréquenté, et a appris la coiffure. C'est cette activité que Sidoine exerce depuis une dizaine d'année et qui lui permet de se prendre en charge. Parallèlement à cette activité, Sidoine vend des mèches, des bijoux et divers autres produits de beauté dans son atelier situé à Cococodji, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Sidoine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché inernational du Bénin. Sidoine a déjà bénéficié une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Sidoine sollicite un deuxième prêt pour rehausser le niveau de son activité et satisfaire plus sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Sidoine G. was born November 22, 1982, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Sidoine has lived in Cocotomey, in the village of Abomey Calavi, for 15 years. Married to Salomon Gonsaves, a shipping agent, Sidoine is the mother of one child who attends school. Sidoine has one other child in her care. Together, she and her husband meet the different family responsibilities. Sidoine attended very little school, and she learned hairstyling. This is the type of work Sidoine has been doing for about 15 years and it allows her to meet her needs. Along with this work, she sells hairpieces, jewelry and various other beauty products at her shop in Cococodji, in the village of Abomey Calavi. Sidoine buys her products in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. She has already benefitted once before with a loan through ALIDé, a loan which she has repaid. Sidoine is requesting a second loan to increase the level of her business and to satisfy her customers better.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy hairpieces and jewelry

loans.name: Saketh's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four people who are villagers in Preaek Bak village in Kandal province. Mrs. SaKeth T. is the group leader. She has been selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purpose. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Thon Mouv, is a fisherman who can find some fish to sell to support his family. They have a problem because they do not have enough supplies for fishing. Thus, in order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. SaKeth T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat for fishing. This couple has eight children. One child is a laborer, one is a fish seller, four are enrolled in a local public school, and the others are too young to go to school or work.

loans.use: To buy a boat for fishing

loans.name: Kisindizi A Nambere Rose Group

texts.en: N. Rose is a hardworking businesswoman, 32 years old who is staying with her spouse. They are blessed with five children. Four of the children are schooling. She is a farmer and she has been carrying out farming activities for over 14 years. She cultivates crops like maize, beans, sugar cane, tomatoes, vegetables, and so forth for sale. She is using the loan to plow her farm, purchase fertilizers, seeds, insecticides, and so forth for the good of her crops. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to build rental houses.

loans.use: To plow her farm and buy fertilizer, seeds, insecticides, etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of SODABI liqueur

loans.name: Amida

texts.en: Amida A. is 27 years old. She was born in Sokodé, in the center of Togo and now lives in the Agoé district of Lomé. She is married to a technician and has one child. Mrs. A. purchases grocery products from the Grand Marché in Lomé, and then sells the products outside of her home. She began this business in 2006 and is now requesting her first loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to purchase two sacks of rice, two boxes of powdered milk, and dried gombo, a fruit used in a popular Togolese dish served with smoked fish.

loans.use: To purchase rice, powdered milk, and local fruit

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia A. is from the village of Tipan, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old. Lydia is widowed and has three adult children. To make a living, Lydia owns & operates business raising pigs for sale. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lydia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Lydia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business
