loans.name: Otgonhishig

texts.en: Otgonhishig is 46 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Hentii province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband, Adiya, is a government worker earning a salary of 400,000 tugrugs (~ 282 USD) per month. During the day, Otgonhishig operates a baked goods and clothing trading business in her province. She started baking in 2002, and operates her baking business seasonally. Otgonhishig produces and sells special baked goods for the Mongolian Lunar New Year celebration, and pastries. In addition, she has been operating a clothing trading business since 2008, and currently her daily revenue averages 35,000 – 45,000 tugrugs (~ 30 USD). Otgonhishig has gained much experience in previous years and has been planning to expand her clothing trading business and to leave the business to her daughter. She is a very hard working person and has many plans for the future. Otgonhishig says, “Even though big bakery workshops have opened in my home province, I have not lost my loyal customers and I am very happy about that.” She is requesting a 1,500,000-tugrug loan to purchase more inventory for her clothing trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Leonida's Group

texts.en:
Leonida D. is from the village of Research Minante 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 53 years old. Leonida is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Leonida is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Leonida owns & operates a tailoring business in the local community. Leonida has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Leonida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Leonida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim V., 40, has been a local farmer for years. Besides his farm work, he catches fish in and around Tunle Sap Lake for his wife to sell at the market. V. is married with six children, one of whom is married and lives separately. To help meet the family's daily expenses, one of V.'s sons works as a construction worker. V. is very experienced in fishing; through this, he is able to give his family a comfortable life. Recently the amount of fish he catches has been decreasing because some of his accessories are broken. Thus, V. has requested a loan to mend his broken tools as well as buy new tools for his fishing trade.

loans.use: To mend his broken tools as well as buy new tools for his fishing trade.

loans.name: Segundina

texts.en:
Segundina C. is a 60-year-old woman living in the town of Brgy. Tabunan, Bago City, Negros Occidental.  She is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Segundina owns & operates a sari-sari store selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Segundina has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Segundina joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Segundina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from NWTF. Segundina is now requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be her fifth loan from NWTF.  Segundina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Owouvodé

texts.en: Owouvodé O. E. S. K. is 42 years old. She lives in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo with her husband, who works as a taxi driver, and her four children. Mrs. K. sells corn and beans in the Assiyéyé market in Agoé. She is requesting her first loan from WAGES, which she will use to purchase 10 sacks of corn and 12 sacks of beans. This loan will ensure that Mrs. K. will be able to keep up with the competition in this busy market location.

loans.use: To purchase corn and beans

loans.name: Mrs. Yoeng Leab Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has 11 people who live in Boeng Kraom village in Kandal province. Mrs. Yoeng L. is the village bank president. She has been selected by all the members. They will use a loan to do something that can improve their living conditions. She and her husband, Mr. Saroeurn Mai, are farmers who own more than two hectares of land to grow rice and vegetable to sell in the market to support their family. They have a problem because their field is far from an irrigation system. Thus, in order to improve rice and vegetable production, Mrs. Yoeng L. decided to ask for a loan to buy gasoline for doing farming. She is a mother of three children. All her children are studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy gasoline for doing farming

loans.name: Hadisa

texts.ru: Сафолова Хадиса проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст, 39 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Муж работает в Горэлектросети в качестве контролёра. Сын на заработках в России. Сама Хадиса занимается торговлей. Она продает продукты необходимые хозяйству. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Hadisa S. lives in the city of Dushanbe. She is 39 years old, married and has 4 children. Her husband works as a controller at the municipal electric company. Their son works in Russia. Hadisa is involved in retail sales. She sells household-essential products. She is requesting the loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

She is using the loan to purchase seeds, such as maize and beans, and to cultivate sweet potatoes, bananas, Irish potatoes and so forth. She is a promising and hardworking lady whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.name: Nalani

texts.en:
Nalani is 50 years old and is a married woman living in Kekanadura, Matara, with her husband and four children -- three sons and one daughter. This family owns two businesses: carpentry and spice making. One son is helping in the businesses while the others are studying.

Nalani has a business selling spices to customers in her town. She is seeking this loan in order to purchase additional spices because during the New Year's festival season in April, there is a much higher demand for spices. She has been working in this business for six years.

Nalani has asked for a 15,000 LKR loan to buy spices for the festival season rush of business. She hopes to use some of the additional income for increased spending in the family that comes with the season. In the future she hopes to provide more nutritious dietary options for her family.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy more spices to process and sell

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy G. lives in the town of Brgy Sagasa, Ma-ao, Bago City.  She is married and has four school-aged children.  To make a living, Nancy owns & operates a sari-sari store selling both food & daily use products in the local community.  Nancy has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 18,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2001, Nancy joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Nancy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from NWTF. Nancy is now requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be her 17th loan from NWTF. Nancy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her two children still in school.

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.name: Odinaka

texts.en: Odinaka is a businessman. He sells motor spare parts at retail prices. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is married with two children. He is requesting a loan of N120,000 to purchase more motor parts to sell. He hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor parts to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita A. is from the village of P. Gumamela Pob., Sinacaban. She is 34 years old. Teresita is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Teresita raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be also be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the second loan taken out by Teresita from PMPC, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: J. Rafol's Group

texts.en: Juanita R. is from the village of Bolibol, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old. Juanita is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Juanita is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, she raises a coconut crop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting coconuts for sale. Juanita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years. In 2004, Juanita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanita has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Juanita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to pay for services to increase her crop yield. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Juanita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase her crop yield

loans.name: Palangan's Group

texts.en:
Ivy P. is from the village of Villalin, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She is 24 years old. Ivy is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Ivy is married and has three children which is now in kindergarten . To make a living, Ivy owns and operates a hog-raising business. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Ivy has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. 

In 2006, Ivy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ivy has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Ivy is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Ivy from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC: 
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Mary Glo's Group

texts.en:
Mary Glo M. is from the village of Antagan 1st. She is 32 years old. Mary Glo is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Mary Glo M..

Mary Glo is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Glo owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and for sale. Mary Glo has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mary Glo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Glo is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase piglets to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mary Glo from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
56-year-old Rachael owns a shop. She sells groceries like biscuits, milk, drinks and more to her customers. She is married and they are blessed with three children. They all live in Lagos State, Nigeria. Rachael plays a supportive role in the home with the proceeds from her business. She assists her husband in feeding, clothing and paying school fees for the children. Her dream is to see her shop grow into a bigger shop and to give the children the best education.  

Rachael is requesting a loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. This will call for more customers and increase profit, which will lead to expansion of the business. She says thanks to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Akouto Christine

texts.en:
Akouto Christine G. sells fabrics and firewood for a living. She lives in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo, with her husband and child. 

Mrs. G. supplies her business from the Grand Marché in Lomé, Mali, and northern Togo. She is now facing a lack of stock and is requesting her first loan from Kiva partner WAGES to replenish her supply. She has been running this business for the last five years, and it is with great hope that she will have continued success for the five years to come.

loans.use: Purchase fabric and firewood

loans.name: Kibati K Kiiza Florence Group

texts.en: Florence K. is a businesswoman of 45 years old. She is married and has ten children, of whom seven are in school, and also takes care of three dependents, who are in school too. Florence K. is a farmer, cultivating fresh foods for sale. She has been in farming for four years so far. She is using this loan to purchase chemicals for her crops and also to hire more laborers for her farm. She is a determined and hard-working businesswoman, whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals for her crops and hire more laborers for her farm.

loans.name: Thamara

texts.en:
Thamara is a 38-year-old married lady living in Kekanadura, Matara area, with her husband and three daughters. Her husband is an army soldier and her children are still studying.

Thamara has a cinnamon garden in which she grows cinnamon to supplement the family's income to help pay daily expenses. She started her business four years ago. Her husband helps her when he is free during his vacation time. Thamara is hardworking and aims to do everything related to the business with strong dedication.

Thamara has asked for a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka. She plans to buy new cinnamon plants and expand her cinnamon garden.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy more cinnamon plants

loans.name: Florizel

texts.en:
Florizel V. is from the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 36 years old. Florizel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Florizel owns & operates a general store selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Florizel has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Florizel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florizel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Florizel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Florizel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Sikiru

texts.en:
Sikiru sells shoes at retail prices in Ibadan, Oyo State. She loves this business because of the profit she makes. She hopes to own a shoe factory in the future. She is 40 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more shoes to sell. 

Sikiru says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.ru: Сафаров Бахром проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 34 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Образование высшее "Педогог". Кроме того работает водителем такси. Опыт работы 7 лет. Этот вид деятельности приносит доход. Кредит берет для ремонта автомашины, чтобы предоставить безопасную услугу.
texts.en:
Bahrom S. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 34 years old, married and has 3 children. He has a higher education as a teacher. Besides this, Bahrom works as a taxi driver. He has 7 years of experience in this field. This type of business brings in income. Bahrom is requesting the loan for car repairs in order to provide safe service.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car repairs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mwongo Nakiwolo Rehema Group

texts.en: Rehema N. is 39 years old. She is married, with three children all going to school, and she is looking after two dependents, of whom one is going to school too. She has been running a retail shop business since the year 2000. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as cooking oil, sugar, salt, tea leaves, and so forth for sale. She is using the loan to expand her retail shop business by increasing her stock. She is a hard-working businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as cooking oil, sugar, salt, tea leaves, and so forth for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of "pagnes"

loans.name: Akouwa

texts.en: Akouwa B. lives and works in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo. She is married to a taxi driver and has one child. Mrs. B. sells groceries and beauty products. She began this business in 2004 and is requesting her second loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to purchase rice, cooking oil, powdered milk and other products needed to keep her shelves stocked. The continued growth of Mrs. B.’s business will not only benefit her, but her entire family.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries and beauty products.

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel B. is from the village of Poblacion 1, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Liezel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Liezel owns and operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Liezel has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Liezel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liezel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Liezel is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en: Jargalsaihan is 37 years old and lives with his daughter in Tuv Province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in an apartment. His daughter, Altantsetseg, is 13 years old and attends a local secondary school. Jargalsaihan graduated as a carpenter in 1992, and he operates a carpentry business in his town. Jargalsaihan manufactures wooden furniture, such as doors and roof rings for gers. He has been operating his business since 1995, and has gained much experience. He operates his business on the weekends, and works as a machinist at the local heating utility during the week. Jargalsaihan has been planning to purchase automatic equipment which will make it easier for him to manufacture his products. He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~705 USD) loan to purchase large amounts of raw materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for his business

loans.name: Abosede

texts.en:
Abosede sells foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. Her customers are usually friends, neighbors and residents. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She loves this business because she is able to help her husband with meeting the basic needs of the family.  

She is 38 years old and married with two children. Her children are doing well in school. Her husband sells beef and he also supports the home. She is requesting a loan of 120,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Yean

texts.en:
Yean R. is a 33-year-old fish trader who sells fresh fish in a local busy market located in the capital, Phnom Penh.

R. is responsible for four teenage kids who are going to the secondary school. Also she receives income from her husband who works as a temporarily laborer in the construction sector.

R. is applying for a loan to help improve her fish-selling trade.

loans.use: To help improve her fish-selling business

loans.name: Baljinnyam

texts.en:
Baljinnyam is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Govi-Altai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Baljinnyam operates a meat-trading business with his wife in his home province. He has been operating his business since 2004, and has steadily expanded the business. He has a loyal customer base and has been cooperating with small restaurants. He purchased a plot of land with a yard and a new car for his family with his business profits.

The most important thing to Baljinnyam is being able to provide for his children's education. He says, “I would like to provide a good education for my children. I have been planning to support my children when they study in a university.”

Baljinnyam is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of meat before prices rise.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of meat

loans.name: Genelyn

texts.en: Genelyn G. is from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Genelyn owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Genelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Genelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Setar-E-Zeba Group

texts.en:
Zeba Gull is the group leader of Setar-e-Zeba Group. She is resident of Kabul, Afghanistan, and runs a bakery in her house. She is a hardworking woman and responsible and is glad that through her business she can support her five children.

Zeba Gull works in her bakery from 6:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. and bakes bread for her neighbors that live in the same area as she does.

With the Kiva loan, she wants to purchase flour and firewood for her bakery and would like to expand her business. She hopes to make her business large and to have a shop instead of working in her home.

loans.use: To buy flour and firewood for her bakery

loans.name: Azees

texts.en:
K. sells colorful sarongs at retail prices to her customers who are usually friends, neighbors and residents. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

K. is 35 years old and is married with three children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the home.

K. loves her business because of the profit she makes. She is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: A. Aminetou

texts.en:
Aminetou M. is 39 years old. She is married and has five children.

Mrs. M. has been selling charcoal since 2003. This will be her second loan from WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock. Specifically, she will purchase fourteen large sacks, twenty medium-sized sacks, and ten small sacks of charcoal. She will then divide the charcoal in these sacks into individually-sized portions and sell them out of recycled tomato tins. This new supply will ensure that she has enough charcoal to satisfy her neighbors’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Wilson's Group

texts.en: Wilson T. is from Barangay Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 49 years old and is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Wilson is married and has three school-aged children. He owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over nine years and earns approximately 45,000 PHP during harvest season, which is every five months. In 2009, Wilson joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Wilson is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his second from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is successful and hardworking. She is 45 years old and married with four children. She lives in Lagos where she runs a business selling of foodstuffs like rice, beans, garri (a couscous-like grain made from grated cassava) and drinks. She started this business sixteen years ago and she is itching for business expansion.

Mary is requesting the loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell to make more profit. This will improve her business and her standard of living. She appreciates all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of grocery products

loans.name: Omolola

texts.en:
Omolola sells cooking utensils to make a living in Ibadan. Her customers are usually women and young girls. She loves this business because of the opportunity it gives her to interact with her customers.

Omolola is 30 years old and is married with two children. Her husband sells foodstuffs to support the home.

Omolola is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more kitchen utensils to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kitchen utensils to sell

loans.name: Rorn

texts.en: Rorn T. is 28 years old and her husband is 35. They are good parents who are very responsible towards their three children, all of whom attend school. This humble couple currently earn their income by catching and selling fish. They get up while the sky is still dark to go fishing on Tunle Sap Lake, where the fish are plentiful. The family wants to increase the quantity of fish they catch, but they need some more essential equipment to do this. Therefore, Rorn T. is applying for a loan to be used to buy more fishing equipment.

loans.use: To buy additional fishing equipment for their fishing ventures.

loans.name: Balamna

texts.en: Balamna H. is 39 years old. Her husband is in the navy and they have two children. Mrs. H. works from home selling beans and corn. She has been running this business since 1998 and has recently requested her second loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to purchase 10 sacks of corn and 12 sacks of beans. With this loan, Mrs. H. will be able to contribute towards her family’s expenses while simultaneously fostering growth in her business.

loans.use: Purchase of corn and beans

loans.name: Enhsaihan

texts.en: Enhsaihan is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, in a yard which belongs to his mother-in-law. He uses his car to operate a taxi service. He takes local residents to and from various points in his province. Enhsaihan has been operating his business since 2006, and each year he repairs and renovates his car. Starting in 2010 he will take local residents from Ulaangom, the capital of Uvs province, to Hovd soum, the capital of Hovd province. His business has been expanding, and his wife plans to work in his business in the future. Enhsaihan is focused on the future and would like to purchase his own plot of land with a yard. He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~ 1055 USD) loan to buy an additional car for his taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Micheal

texts.en:
Micheal sells medicines at retail prices to his customers who are usually friends, neighbors and residents. He hopes to expand his business in the future. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers.

Micheal is 35 years old and is married with five children, his eldest child being 19 years old. His children are still young and they attend school. Micheal’s wife sells foodstuffs to support their home.

Micheal is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en: Jane T. is from the village of San Antonio, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 55 years old and is the group leader of a twelve-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Jane is married and has three adult-aged children. She owns and operates a business providing tailoring services to the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. Jane plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Chhoeung

texts.en: Mrs. S. is 34, and married. She has been catching fish in the river since before she was married and now her husband works with her. This is a great season; almost all of the fishermen are very happy that they can catch a lot of fish. But S. doesn't have the necessary nets and traps with which to fish, which is why she is requesting a loan via Kiva’s partner, HKL, to buy the required equipment..

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and traps.

loans.name: Furkat

texts.ru: Сатаров Фуркат проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 30 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Живет вместе с родителями. Отец разводит скот. Брат занимается продажей мяса. Сам Фуркат более 6 лет занимается животноводством. Имеет небольшой коровник. Разводит скот у себя дома. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Furkat S. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 30 years old, married and has 2 children. His wife is a homemaker. He lives together with his parents. Furkat's father breeds livestock, and his brother sells meat. Furkat has been involved in animal husbandry for over 6 years. He has a small cowshed and breeds livestock at home. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing automotive paints

loans.name: Madoujou Betché

texts.en: Madoujou Betché T. is married with two children. She lives in the Agoé region of Lomé, Togo and sells grocery products in a local market. She began this business in 2004 and is asking for her third loan from WAGES. She will use it to resupply her stock of groceries by purchasing 12 barrels of cooking oil, 15 sacks of rice, 2 cases of milk, and 8 cases of spaghetti.

loans.use: Purchase of cooking oil, rice, milk and spaghetti

loans.name: Djamshed

texts.ru: Ахмедов Джамшед проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 22 года. Женат, имеет одного ребёнка. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Джамшед имеет среднее образование. Подрабатывает строительными работами. Кроме того занимается животноводством. Откармливает и продает скот. В этой области уже 2 года. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Djamshed A. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 22 years old, married and has one child. His wife is a homemaker. Djamshed has a secondary education. He does construction work. Besides this, he is involved in animal husbandry. He fattens and sells livestock. Djamshed has been in this field for 2 years. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr: Née en 1953 à Avrankou dans le département de l'Ouémé, M. Célestine vit depuis 31 ans environs à Fidjrossè Kpota à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Célestine est mariée à ASSE Innocent et est mère de cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Mais un seul des enfants est à sa charge. Célestine vit ensemble avec son mari à Fidjrossè Kpota. Célestine n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses charges, Célestine mène comme activité la vente de poissons et de crevettes fumés à son domicile. Célestine prépare et vend également de l'akassa (aliment local fait à base de maïs). C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Célestine s'approvisionne. Célestine exerce cette activité depuis trente ans et a déjà obtenu trois crédits auprès de ALIDé. Célestine a bien remboursé les trois crédits. La clientèle de Célestine s'accroît au jour le jour et elle n'arrive plus à faire face à toutes leurs demandes. Célestine sollicite pour ce faire, un quatrième prêt en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1953 in Avrankou, in the department of Ouémé, Célestine M. has lived in Fidjrossè Kpota in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, for about 31 years. Célestine is married to Innocent Asse and is the mother of five children who have all been educated. Only one, however, is in her care. Célestine lives with her husband in Fidjrossè Kpota. She did not attend school. To meet her responsibilities, Célestine sells smoked fish and shrimp from her home. Célestine also prepares and sells akassa (a porridge made from cornmeal, a local staple). She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Bénin. She has done this kind of work for 30 years and has already received three loans through ALIDé. Célestine repaid all three loans. Her clients are growing in number by the day and she is no longer able to meet their demands. Célestine is requesting a fourth loan in order to build up her business and better meet the demands of her clients.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase fresh fish and sacks of corn for the preparation of akassa

loans.name: Miss. Leanghong Chim Village Bank Group

texts.en: Miss. Leanghong C. is the leader of a twelve-person loan group in Preaek Ta In, Kandal province. She was elected by all the members who will use the loan for different purposes. She is a fisherwoman who is part of a three-person household. She tries to work hard fishing but still makes veR. little income, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets and pig food to start a new business breeding pigs. In this way, she hopes to increase her income in the coming year.

loans.use: To buy some piglets to raise

loans.name: Nazira Group

texts.en: Rahesa is the leader of the Nazira group. She lives with her husband in a five-member household in Kabul's District 11, Afghanistan. She needs the loan for her husband who sells second-hand clothes and wants to expand his business to better support his family. Rahesa is hopeful for this kind of loan process in Afghanistan.

loans.use: buy clothing for his second-hand clothes business

loans.name: Gnima Elisabeth

texts.fr: Gnima Élisabeth D. est une femme de 26 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants en charge. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 6ans et demi et été 13 fois de suite bénéficiaire de crédit et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Elle est détentrice d'une boutique où elle vend divers produits tels que du riz, du sucre, de l'huile végétale etc. Elle participe financièrement à la prise ne charge familiale.
texts.en:
Gnima Elisabeth D. is 26 years old, married, and the mother of five dependent children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois for six and a half years and already obtained loans 13 times, without ever having any issues with repaying them. She keeps a shop in which she sells various products such as rice, sugar, vegetable oil etc. This way she is able to contribute to the family budget.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthening her business

loans.name: Cécile Edwige

texts.fr: G. Cécile Edwige est née le 22 Novembre 1977 et vit depuis 15 ans environs à Fidjrossè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Cécile Edwige est mariée à GLELE Paul, un plombier et est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Fidjrossè. Cécile Edwige vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la maison. Cécile Edwige n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Cécile Edwige vend divers produits (conserves de tomate et de sardine, lait, vinaigrette, pâtes alimentaires, petits pois, mayonnaise, allumettes, savons, etc) à son domicile. A côté de cette activité, Cécile Edwige vend également des chaussures et des tissus. Cécile Edwige s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, et aussi à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cécile Edwige exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d'année. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Cécile Edwige sollicite un autre prêt pour investir beaucoup plus dans son activité afin d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire et se faire encore plus de revenu.
texts.en:
Cécile Edwige G. was born 22 November 1977 and has lived the past 15 years in the Fidjrossé area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Paul GLELE, a plumber, and is the mother of two children, both attending school. Cécile Edwige has only attended primary school herself. The family lives together in Fidjrossé. Cécile Edwige helps her husband and shares with him the different household expenses. To meet her needs and those of her children, Cécile Edwige retails various products from her home (canned tomatoes and sardines, milk, salad dressing, pasta, peas, mayonnaise, matches, soap, etc.). As a secondary activity she also sells shoes and pieces of fabric. She gets her supplies from Lomé in Togo, and also from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Cécile Edwige has been in business for about ten years. She is a regular client of ALIDé, who reimburses her loans correctly. She is now requesting another loan to invest more in her activity to increase her turnover and consequently her earnings.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products (pasta, canned food, milk, sugar, soap, toothpaste, etc.)

loans.name: Kijjamunsi Women's Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
G. Deborah, shown at the top left in a small photo, also appears in the big photo and she is the leader of her lending group. She is 53 years old and married with four children: two at the University while two are out of school. She also helps to take care of seven grandchildren and orphans.

Debra has operated a retail shop in Mabuye for ten years and she is able to make 200,000/= as monthly profits. She works so hard to ensure that she is self-sustaining as well as to have a better life for herself and her family.

Debra is a very hardworking and honest lady and she needs a loan to be able to restock her retail shop with more goods. She will be able to buy more sugar, salt, cooking oil and other goods for expansion.

In the group photo, Nakintu Faridah, standing third from the right, is a part of the group although in recess. Hence she is not one of the members that are seeking a loan.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt, cooking oil and other items for increased stock

loans.name: Mrs. Nhong Nheong Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Nhong N. is the elected leader of a sixteen-person loan group in Preaek Ta In village in Kandal province. She breeds fish and her husband is a construction worker and farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to feed his family. Since her business is goI. well, she wants to expand and so is askI. for a loan to buy fish food to breed more fish. The couple has three children — one a fish seller, and the others still in school.

loans.use: To buy fish food to breed fish

loans.name: Good People Group

texts.en:
Mai F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Good People. She is 48 years old, married, and has four children aged 4 to 27. Mai did not have the opportunity to go to school.
For the past 25 years, Mai has been running her restaurant at the Red Light community in Paynesville, Liberia. She prepares her food very well and talks to customers in a nice manner, which keeps them returning. She plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 26,000 LRD group loan to purchase additional food for her restaurant. Her goal is to expand her business and improve her family's living conditions.
In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mai is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional food for her restaurant

loans.name: Thiêm's Group

texts.en:
T.êm T. N. is a 43-year-old woman living in Xuan Non, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. She is married with one child. Like most of the peopL. here, farming is T.êm’s only source of income. She not only grows rice but also raises pigs T. scratch out a living. T.êm’s husband does not get involved in these activities since he is an employee working far from home. The total monthly income of the whoL. family is quite low, just about 2,000,000 VND per month.
In 2006, T.êm joined Kiva partner, SEDA, T. gain access T. financial resources. Her loans, which have been used largely T. buy pig food, have always been repaid punctually. For her next loan, she would like T. borrow 4,142,000 VND T. invest in her business, particularly T. buy six piglets and improve the piggery. Hopefully, this investment will turn a profit so that her family is abL. T. afford T. buy more household appliances.
Other borrowers in T.êm's group are shown below:
Lan Thị Tô is 28 years old and currently owns a small food shop. She wants T. take out a loan of 4,142,000 VND T. expand her business.
Nga Thị Ngô is a 33-year-old farmer. She needs T. borrow 5,014,000 VND T. buy food for fish and pigs.
Hiền T. Thị Lê is a 33-year-old fruit seller. She also wants T. borrow 5,014,000 VND T. invest more in her business.
Kim Thị Hoàng is a 28-year-old butcher. She would like T. take out a loan of 5,014,000 VND T. finance her business expansion plan.
Lần Thị Lê is 31 years old. Her family owns a forge shop and she is requesting a loan of 5,014,000 VND T. invest in that business.
Thanh Thị Vũ is a 38-year-old micro-businesswoman. She is requesting a loan of 5,014,000 VND T. make an investment.

loans.use: To buy six piglets and improve her piggery

loans.name: Kinta

texts.fr: Kinta Y. est âgée de 44 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 6ans. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 7 ans et demi et a 15 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit. Son nouveau prêt lui permet de développer un petit commerce de viande de porc et d'huile de palme. Elle est très expérimentée dans ce domaine d'activité pour l'avoir mené depuis plus de 5ans, ce qui lui à procuré des revenus financiers lui permettant de construire un habitat pour sa famille et de prendre en charge la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Kinta Y. is 44 years old, she is married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of the “Banc Villageois” for seven and a half years and has received 15 consecutive loans. Her new loan allows her to develop a small retail business of pork meat and palm oil. She has a lot of experience in this type of activity having managed it for over five years. This business has provided her with a financial income allowing her to build a home for her family and to take care of her children’s school fees

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen and promote her retail activity

loans.name: Dong's Group

texts.en:
Đồng Thị Hoàng was born in 1959. Presently, she is living in X. Non, Dong Anh, Hanoi with her husband and her two children. The elder son has been employed and the younger one is still at school. Unsurprisingly, she farms to scratch out a living but that only source of income does not meet her needs. Sometimes Dong also has a part-time job as an assistant builder to aid her husband in his work. All those jobs generate a total monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND per month. Noticeably, six years is such a long period that she has been identified with SEDA program. More importantly, she has never been late to pay off her debts. In this credit cycL., she keeps on being willing to take out a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy equipment and tools.

Along with her, there are also four other peopL.: 

 Hiên Thị Nguyễn is 27 years old. She wants to take out a loan of 4,142,000 VND to raise pigs and cows. 

 Hương Xuân Thị Nguyễn is a 34-year-old farmer. She needs to borrow 4,142,000 VND to buy more piglets to raise. 

 Thúy Thị Lê is 28. She also wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND to invest more in raising chickens. 

 Oanh Thị Nguyễn is 33 years old. She would like to take out a loan of 5.014.000 VND to finance her plan to raise pigs.

loans.use: To buy equipment and tools

loans.name: Mrs. Savoen Bor Village Bank Group

texts.en: There are 13 people living in Preak Ta Thok village in Kandal province who make up the village bank loan. Mrs. Savoen B. is the village bank president; she has been selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. She is a pig breeder in her house and her husband is a white wine maker who can earn some income to support his family. In order to increase her income to improve her family's standard of living, Mrs. Savoen B. decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. She is the mother of four children. One of the children is too young to school or work, and the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy bags of charcoal and corn

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: Antoinette M. a 45 ans elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants en charge. Elle est membre de Banc villageois depuis 9 ans et a une bonne expérience avec le crédit pour en avoir bénéficié 18 fois de suite. Elle est vendeuse de fruits et en particulier des bananes. Elle achète son produits en gros pour revendre au détail dans son quartier. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Antoinette M. is 45 years old and the mother of seven children. She has been a member of the “Banc Villageois” for nine years and has had a good experience with borrowing. She has received 18 consecutive loans. She sells fruits and especially bananas. She buys her products wholesale and sells them retail in her neighborhood. Her profit will allow her to take care of her family.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop her fruit selling activity

loans.name: Massolomani

texts.en: Massolomani T. is 32 years old. She was born in Sokodé and now lives in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo. She is married to an industrial mechanic and has one child. Mrs. T. sells a variety of grains, corn, and ground manioc. This ground and dried manioc, called “cossette,” is used in the preparation of “la pâte,” a starchy paste accompanied by sauce and meat. Mrs. T. purchases her supplies in the Grand Marché of Lomé and then sells the products from her boutique in Agoé. She began this business in 2002 and is now requesting her second loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to resupply her stock of grains, corn, and cossette in order to better serve her customers.

loans.use: To purchase grains, corn, and ground manioc

loans.name: Odil

texts.ru: Яхёев Одил проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 50 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Дети работают на стройке. Сам Одил занимается животноводством. Он разводит скот у себя дома. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Odil Y. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 50 years old, married and has 5 children. He has a secondary education. The children work at a construction site. Odil is involved in animal husbandry. He breeds livestock at home. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Channy Soy Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has 10 people who live in Preak Ta Thok village in Kandal province. Mrs. Channy S. is the village bank president, selected by all the members. They each will use the loan for a different purpose. She is a pig breeder and a white wine maker to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Channy S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. She is a widow who lives with three children, all of whom are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding

loans.name: Saleem Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Nazia wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her animal-selling business. Sakina wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. Saleem akhtar is the group leader for the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. 

Saleem is a kind-hearted, good-natured woman. She runs a sewing business. She learnt this skill from her mother and it has given her rewards in a shape of money now. She does this work to supplement the income of her husband. Her husband's name is I. A. and he runs a pan shop in the community. (Pan is an Urdu term which is used for betel leaves.)  He has a good reputation among his customers. He deals with them with respect. Saleem is applying for a loan to buy items (betel nuts, betel leaves) to expand her husband’s pan shop.

loans.use: To buy material for her husband's pan shop

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 26-year-old, ambitious Palestinian plastic artist. He started this hobby at a very young age and decided to have it as a profession in the last two years, as his paintings were selling very well.

Ahmad would like to organize an exhibition of the last two years works, so he applied for a loan from FATEN to buy the necessary material to complete his collection and rent a gallery hall.

Ahmad tells us that he has enjoyed painting since he was a young boy and loves his paintings that are above and behind him in the picture.

loans.use: Purchasing equipment for a painting exhibition

loans.name: Zarmina Fozia Group

texts.en: Zarmina is a member of Zarmina Fozia group. She lives in the 11th District of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is 31 years old and married with two children. She has a beauty salon and is busy working there seven days a week. She needs new designs of cosmetics and new furniture for her beauty salon and would like to develop her business. She hopes to be a successful beautician and to be famous in her area as well. She is glad for this process and would like to admire it as well.

loans.use: To purchase new cosmetics and furniture

loans.name: Nou's Group

texts.en: This loan group has five members, all of whom live in Preaek Bak village in Kandal province. Mrs. Nou K. was elected leader by the members, each of whom  will use this loan for a different purpose. Nou K. and her husband are farmers who own a half-hectare of land on which they will grow vegetables to sell, which is how they support their family. It is time to plant their crop but they need money to buy corn and sesame seed, which is why they are applying for this loan. The couple has three children, all of whom are in school.

loans.use: To buy corn and sesame seed

loans.name: Farzana's Group

texts.en:
Sardaran wants a loan to buy used handsets for her mobile phone shop. Zarina wants a loan to buy paint for her paint-selling business. Farzana is the group leader for the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. Farzana feels herself blessed that she was born in a holy place. 

Her husband's name is M. M. and he has a fruit-selling business. He purchases fruit from the fruit markets and sells in the various places on his cart. He has been in this business for over fifteen years. Farzana is a housewife but she also helps her husband by arranging the fruit on his cart. She does this work every morning. Her husband earns approximately Pak Rs. 20,000 every month. Currently, he need a loan to complete the large order which he has received from the fruit shops, therefore Farzana is requesting a loan of Pak Rs. 20,000. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruit to complete the orders

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Awa S. est une femme de 32ans et mère de 5 enfants en charge. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 2ans et demi. Elle a été 5 fois de suite bénéficiaire de crédit et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Et est détentrice d'une boutique où elle vend du riz, du sucre, de l'huile végétale etc. Avec les bénéfices qu'elle réalise elle participe à la prise en charge familiale et au payement de la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Awa S. is a 32-year-old woman, mother of five children. She has been a member of the “Banc Villageois” for two and a half years. She has received five consecutive loans and never had a problem paying them back. She has a shop where she sells rice, sugar, vegetable oil etc… With the profit she earns she contributes to cover the family’s expenses and the children’ s school fees.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen and promote her activity

loans.name: Antoinette Clémence

texts.fr: D. M. Antoinette Clémence est née le 12 Octobre 1963 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Antoinette Clémence est mère D. six enfants qui sont tous scolarisés, mais un des enfants n'est plus à sa charge. Antoinette Clémence ne vit plus avec son mari ; elle vit donc seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les différentes charges D. la famille. Antoinette Clémence s'est installée depuis six ans environs à Fidjrossè Kpota à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Depuis une trentaine d'année, en vue d'assurer un bien être à ses enfants et D. subvenir à ses besoins, Antoinette Clémence vend divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, conserves, sucre, savons, papiers hygiéniques, lait, etc.) à son domicile. Antoinette Clémence s'approvisionne à Cotonou. C'est une ancienne cliente D. ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Antoinette Clémence désire renforcer un peu plus son activité et mieux satisfaire ses clients. C'est ce qui l'amène à solliciter auprès D. ALIDé, un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Antoinette Clémence D. M. was born 12 October 1963 in Ouidah, a historic city in Benin. She is the mother of six children, all of whom have had schooling, but one of the children is no longer under her care. Antoinette Clémence lives no longer with her husband; she lives alone with her children and is their sole support for family expenses. She settled six years ago in the Fidjrossè Kpota borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. For the last thirty years, seeking to ensure the well-being of her children and meet her own needs, Antoinette Clémence has been retailing various products from her home (pasta, canned goods, sugar, soap, toilet paper, milk, etc.). She gets her supplies from Cotonou. Antoinette Clémence is a regular client of ALIDé, and reimburses correctly her loans. She wants to bolster her business and increase customer satisfaction, which is why she is requesting another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products (pasta, canned goods, sugar, soap, toilet paper, milk, etc.).

loans.name: United Women Group

texts.en:
Helena K. leads a group five borrowers called United Women. She is 55 years old, single and has four children who range in age from 28 to 36 years old. When younger, she did not have the opportunity to go to school. For the last 30 years, Helena has made a living running a general goods store at the Red Light Community in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells good-quality merchandise and is very friendly, which keeps her customers coming back. She plans to use her portion of this 54,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy additional goods, such as peanuts and pepper, to sell. Her goal is to expand her business and improve her family's living conditions.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Helena is the one holding the sign.  Gertrude K. is in the inset on the  lower left.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Channy Leng Village Bank Group

texts.en: The eight people applying for this group loan live in Preaek Bak village in Kandal province. Mrs. Channy L. is a village bank president who has been elected to lead this group by its members. She owns a general store which serves the village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it and has applied for this loan to buy more groceries to sell. Her husband, Mr. Song Meng Theng, owns a motorbike which he uses to transport fish and thereby earn extra income for the family. The couple has two children who are too young to go to school or work.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Kigando Tubingye Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
T. Zefulino, shown at the top left in a small photo, also appears in the group photo and he is the leader of his group in Kyenjojo. He is 47 years old and married with five children aged 17 to 5 years. He also takes care of a sister.

Zefulino has operated a business selling produce in Kigando trading centre for five years and he says that the business is doing well. He is able to make 30,000/= as profits every week and he hopes to have good quality products as well as to have a fully-stocked store always.

Zefulino hopes to have a stable and self-sustaining family and this is why he needs a loan to be able to purchase more stock like maize grains, beans and rice for increased stock and hence more sales.

Zefulino is a friendly and determined man with a strong drive to succeed.

loans.use: To buy more produce like maize grains, beans and rice

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Muniran wants a loan to buy items (biscuits, sweets) to sell. Zubaida wants a loan to buy crockery for her catering business. Ramzan wants a loan to buy fruit for her fruit-selling business. Bashiran wants a loan to buy books (syllabus, religious ones) for her book shop. Naseem is the group leader of these above-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. 

Naseem's husband's name is M. S. and he is a butcher by trade. He runs a butcher shop in the market where he sells meat of goats and cows. He has fifteen years of experience in this work. Naseem is a very hard-working lady. She runs a grocery shop in the community. She does this work to supplement their income. She is applying for a loan to buy animals (goats) to expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy animals for butcher shop

loans.name: Mrs. Sarin Yan Village Bank Group

texts.en: The 10 people who have applied for this loan live in Preaek Bak village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sarin Y. is a village bank president who has also been chosen to lead this group by its members, each of whom who will use his or her portion of the loan to improve their family's living conditions. Mrs. Sarin Y. owns a general store in local village and her husband, Mr. Lat Seng, is a motorbike taxi driver. Since her business is growing, she wants to expand and has applied for this loan to buy more groceries to sell. She has one child, who is studying in local public school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Léonie

texts.fr: D. Léonie est née le 18 Juin 1969 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a près de 20 ans que Léonie s'est installée au quartier Fidjrossè Kpota à Cotonou. Léonie est mariée à DJIBRILLA Ismaïla, et est mère de cinq enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Léonie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Fidjrossè Kpota. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Léonie a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Léonie exerce comme activité, la vente d'ustensiles de cuisine, de façon ambulante. Léonie vend également des tissus par le système de distribution. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Léonie achète ses produits. Léonie exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans. Aujourd'hui, Léonie sollicite l'appui financier de ALIDé, pour renforcer son activité et mieux répondre aux exigences de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Léonie D. was born 18 June 1969 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She settled 20 years ago in the Fidjrossè Kpota borough of Cotonou She is married to Ismaïla DJIBRILLA, and is the mother of five children, of which some have had schooling. Léonie herself interrupted her schooling at secondary level. She lives with her children and her husband in Fidjrossè Kpota, and shares family expenses with him. To meet her different expenses, Léonie has been running a retail business for kitchen utensils, as an itinerant vendor. She also sells pieces of fabric through the distribution system. She gets her products from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Léonie has been running her business for the past 15 years. She is now requesting financial support from ALIDé to strengthen her activity and better respond to customer demand.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy kitchen utensils (iceboxes, sets of bowls, basins, pans, etc.)

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Khalida wants a loan to buy cans of paint to sell. Shahnaz wants a loan to buy vehicle-repair tools for her motor workshop. Jamila is the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Borewala, a city famous for its shrines. 

Jamila is a widow. Her husband died of a heart attack four years ago. She did everything possible for his health but all was in vain. She completely lost herself after his death but she recovered herself for her children. Now her elder son supports the family. He is a painter and paints windows and doors on order. Jamila is applying for a loan to buy items (paint brushes, tins of paint) to increase the income of her son.

loans.use: To buy materials for her son's painting business

loans.name: Ramatoulaye

texts.fr:
Ramatoulaye Traoré est âgée de 53 ans, célibataire et mère d’un enfant, elle vit dans la grande famille traditionnelle à Bougoula Ville, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ramatoulaye Traoré  est une couturière de profession qui  achète des balles des draps, rideaux et de napperon afin de les modifier pour pouvoir les revendre  et cela depuis maintenant plus de vingt ans. Elle mène son activité à domicile où elle possède sa propre machine à coudre. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de  six ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son neuvième prêt individuel et tous les prêts ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 8 colis de napperon, 8 balles de rideau et 4 balles de drap. Elle s’approvisionne sur place auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente très généralement  au comptant, à crédit à une clientèle composée des femmes.
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ramatoulaye Traoré is 53 years old, single and mother to one child. She lives in a large traditional family in Bougoula Ville, the central town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Ramatoulaye is a seamstress by profession and she buys bundles of sheets, curtains and tablemats in order to alter them and resell them; she has been doing this for more than twenty years. She carries out this activity from home where she has her own sewing machine. In order to satisfy her ever increasing customer base, she decided to join the mincrofinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, over six years ago. After several group loans with an association of women in her neighborhood, she is now on her ninth individual loan and all the previous loans have been repaid correctly. With this loan she is planning to buy eight parcels of tablemats, eight bundles of curtains and eight bundles of sheets. She gets her supplies locally from wholesalers, and she sells generally for cash and on credit to a customer base made up of women. She is expecting to make a monthly profit of 250,000 FCFA which will be used essentially to expand her business, contribute to family expenses and pay the interest on her loan; the rest will be invested in her activity.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sheets, curtains and tablemats

loans.name: Mr. Hoeung Seng Village Bank Group

texts.en: The 10 people who have applied for this loan live in Preaek Bak village in Kandal province. Mr. Hoeung S. is a village bank president who has also been selected by all the members to lead the group. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose. Mr. S. is a farmer who owns a hectare of land on which he grows vegetables to sell, which is how he supports his family. He is a widower who is raising eight children, one of whom is a construction worker. Another is a grocer, two are farmers, and the others are enrolled in the local public school or still too young to attend school. Mr. S. has applied for this loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide for his farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Rahmatullo

texts.ru: Якубов Рахматулло проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 54 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Образование средне- специальное "Фермер". Кроме того занимается животноводством. Он в основном откармливает и продает скот. В этой области более 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа скота, чтобы увеличить их количества.
texts.en:
Rahmatullo Y. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 54 years old, married and has 2 children. He has a secondary-specialized education as a farmer. Besides this, he is involved in animal husbandry. Rahmatullo primarily fattens and sells livestock. He has been in this field for over 10 years. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of livestock in order to increase its quantity.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Diélika

texts.fr:
Âgée de plus de 47 ans, Madame Diélika T.  est mariée et mère d’un  enfant (un garçon). Elle vit  dans une famille polygame avec son époux, sa co-épouse et leurs enfants  à Sanoubougou I (Kapel Kourou), un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école, Diélika s’est très vite initiée  à une activité génératrice de revenus notamment  à l’achat et  à la  vente des légumes  et des tubercules (pomme de terre, patate douce et igname) il y a de cela dix ans. Elle mène son activité au niveau du marché de fruits et  légumes au pied de la colline Mamelon non loin du grand marché de Sikasso. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 7 ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son sixième prêt individuel individuel.
