Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 35 sacs de pomme de terre et 20 sacs d’igname, 3 sacs de patates douces. Elle achète ses marchandises en gros sur place auprès des producteurs avant de les revendre en détail au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle  diverse et variée.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 300.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Over 47 years old, Mrs. Diélika T. is married and has one child (a boy). She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, his other wife and their children in Sanoubougou 1 (Kapel Kourou), one of the peripheral neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Since she did not have the chance to progress at school, Diélika very quickly established an income-generating activity, notably the purchase and sale of vegetables and tubers (potatoes, sweet potatoes and yams), ten years ago. She carries out this activity at the fruit and vegetable market at the foot of the Mamelon hill, not far from the big market in Sikasso. Wishing to satisfy her ever increasing customer base better, she decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, seven years ago. After several group loans with a women's association in her neighborhood, she is on her sixth individual loan. With this loan she is planning to buy 35 sacks of potatoes, 20 sacks of yams and three sacks of sweet potatoes. She buys her goods wholesale and locally from producers before reselling them retail for cash and often on credit to a diversified customer base. She expects that with this loan she will make a monthly profit of 300,000 FCFA which will be used essentially to expand her business, contribute to family expenses and pay the interest on her loan; the rest will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase tubers

loans.name: By God's Grace Group

texts.en: Esther T. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called By God's Grace. She sells lapa (a wax-printed fabric popular in many parts of Africa) at the Red Light Market on the outskirts of Liberia's capital, Monrovia. Esther plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 36,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more lapa fabric for resale. Esther is 45 years old, married, and has seven children whose ages range from 8 to 24 years old. Her youngest children attend elementary school and the oldest have attained a senior high education. Esther herself was never able to go to school, as she says her parents refused to let her go. Esther has had her lapa fabric business for about 8 years now and she says she started small. Her business has grown but she says it's difficult because there are many other lapa sellers nearby, so competition is stiff. She says she tries to distinguish herself from her competitors by buying lapa fabric of high quality with fine designs. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Esther is the one holding the sign. Comfort D. is inset at lower left. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy more lapa (wax-printed fabric) for resale.

loans.name: Wajeha Rahimi Group

texts.en:
Khialy Gull is the daughter of S. A. and is the woman who is the leader of Wajeha Rahimi Group.  She has been involved in sewing dresses (tailoring) for more than 3 years. She lives in a household of 5 members, including her husband. Now she wants to buy a new machine for her younger daughter and some necessary things for her tailoring business, thereby supporting her husband and all her family members.

She is happy with this loan process. She plans to open a shop for her husband in the next 2 or 3 years. She would like to thank Kiva and AFS (Ariana Financial Serves Joint Stock Company) for this fantastic process of small loans in her country. She would like to be a good businesswoman in the future.

loans.use: She wants to buying a new machine for tailoring

loans.name: Bilquis' Group

texts.en:
Bilquis is a wife of M. A. and they both live in a city named Lahore, a city famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the market. He has six years of experience in this business. Bilquis is an active lady. She manages her household work and takes care of the children. She has given birth to two children: one son and one daughter. Both are enrolled in school and are getting an education. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries to diversify her husband’s grocery shop into a store.

Bilquis has three other ladies in her loan group. Kosar Parveen wants a loan to buy tins of paint to sell. Khursheed wants a loan to buy vehicle repair tools for her motor workshop. Nasreen wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Djoumai

texts.en:
Djoumai O. is 41 years old. She lives in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo and works in the nearby markets. She sells yams, beans, corn, and dried manioc and began this business in 2007. This will be her first loan with WAGES and she will use it to resupply her stock.

Mrs. O. plans on purchasing 3 sacks of beans, 3 sacks of corn, 3 sacks of dried manioc, and using the remainder of the loan to buy yams. She is married to a taxi driver and has three children.

loans.use: Purchase of yams, beans, corn, and dried manioc

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used clothes.

loans.name: G. K. Gray Group

texts.en:
George G. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called G. K. G. Group.  He is single, and has five children who are 2, 4, 9 12 and 14 years old.  George is a high school graduate. For six years, George has been selling cassava leaves at the Waterside Market, which is the biggest market in Monrovia. He says that people buy from him because he is friendly. George plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cassava leaves.  His dream is to send his children to school, build a house and attend college. In the photo that accompanies this profile, George is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more cassava leaves.

loans.name: Yusup

texts.ru: Курбонов Юсуп проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 51 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сын на зарабатках в России. Сам Юсуп более 10 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит крупно- рогатый скот для перепродажи их на мясо. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Yusup K. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 51 years old, married and has 4 children. His wife is a homemaker. His son works in Russia. Yusup has been involved in animal husbandry for over 10 years. He breeds cattle to resell it for meat. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mina Saheda Group

texts.en: Bebe Zahra is a member of Mina Saheda group. She lives in the 11th District of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives in a household of six members. She is a tailor who sews all kinds of clothes, both small and big sizes. She needs the loan to purchase a new sewing machine because she has problem with the old one. She hopes to expand her business and to open a shop of tailoring to attract more clients and to support her childern get better education.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her business

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a young man from Gaza city in Gaza strip. He is married and the father of Fotoun, 4 years old, and Iyad, 3 years old. Mohammad is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority and works as a taxi driver after his working hours.

Mohammad pays for his taxi from its income, but since he has only a few payments left, he decided to take a loan from FATEN to pay them off all at once.

Mohammad stands next to his car in the picture above.

loans.use: Purchase a Taxi car

loans.name: Saira's Group

texts.en:
Tahira wants a loan to buy construction supplies (sand, cement and bricks) for her construction supply-selling business. Kalsoom wants a loan to buy medicines for her medical store. Sugran wants a loan to buy an electric sewing machine for her sewing business. Amna wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shama parveen wants a loan to buy plastic toys for her toy-selling business. Saira is the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all come from a city called Borewala, famous for its shrines in Pakistan. 

Saira's husband's name is M. R. and he is a mechanic and runs his own motor-workshop. His shop is located in the center of the market where it's the busiest place for customers. He has ten years of experience in this business.  Saira is applying for a loan to buy repair tools for her husband’s motor-workshop.

loans.use: To buy repair tools for motor-workshop

loans.name: Blanca Esther

texts.es:
La señorita Blanca de 28 años de edad es comerciante, se dedica a la venta de ropas argentinas y nacionales a comercios de la zona, es proveedora mayorista de la ciudad de Villarrica, la mayoría de las prendas de vestir son para damas, exclusivas y delicadas como blusas de licras, vestidos, jeans y otros. Empezó gracias a la ayuda económica de su madre la señora Prudencia de 57 años de edad, ella cuenta con un puesto de  ventas de productos de consumo masivo en el mercado municipal de la cuidad.
  
Blanca esta conforme con la actividad que realiza sueña con tener su propio negocio ya que actualmente su venta lo realiza desde su casa.Ella solicta el crédito para la compra de mercaderías como Blusas de licra, pantalones, jeans, vestidos y otros.
texts.en:
Blanca is 28 years old and sells Argentine and domestic clothing within her zone. She is the largest provider in Villarrica. Most of her articles are women's clothing, such as delicate blouses, dresses, jeans, etc. She began thanks to the help of her 57 year-old mother, Prudencia who has a stall in the city marketplace. Blanca is happy with her work but she would like to have her own stall. At the moment she sells from her home. She is asking for this loan in order to buy blouses, pants, jeans, dresses, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Plunkor Group

texts.en:
Asatu S. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Plunkor Group.  She is 35 years old, married, and has five children who range from nursery school to 10th grade.  Asatu was never able to attend school herself. For over 15 years, Asatu has been selling milk in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She says that she provides her customers with good quality milk, which keeps them coming to her for business. Asatu plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more milk. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Asatu is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more milk.

loans.name: Shazia's Group

texts.en:
Nazia wants a loan to buy items (cosmetics, hair dryer) for her beauty salon. Nasreen wants a loan to buy fruit for her fruit-selling business. Tajan wants a loan to buy wood and nails for her furniture-making business. Naghma naz wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Shazia is the wife of N. M. and the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. 

Shazia's husband runs a canteen in a local school where he sells the home-made items (e.g., kababs and French fries). Shazia helps her husband by preparing the food for his canteen. They both get up early and help each other. Their earning help them to cover the expenses of their household. Shazia is applying for a loan to buy materials (potatoes, cooking oil and spices) to expand their canteen business.

loans.use: To buy material for canteen business

loans.name: God's Blessing #2 Group

texts.en:
Tamey Q. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God's Blessing #2.  She is a seamstress and plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 24,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more materials for tailoring, such as fabric, thread, and other items.

Tamey is 42, single, and has three children aged 5, 10, and 12 years old.  Her kids are all in elementary school.  Tamey, a high school graduate, also helps care for two siblings.

Tamey has been a seamstress for about 12 years and has a stall at the Red Light Market.  Red Light, located in Paynesville on the outskirts of Liberia's capital, Monrovia, is the country's largest marketplace.  She says she started her trade by apprenticing, and then opened her own business with starter capital of about $100 U.S.

Tamey says that the main challenge she faces in business is a good one -- customer demand is high and she has difficulty keeping up with orders.  She says her customers like her because she sews well and completes orders in a timely manner.  Tamey hopes that if her business continues to be a success, she will be able to afford to buy more sewing machines to expand her business.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Tamey is the one holding the sign.  William F. is inset at the lower left.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy more fabric, thread, and other items for tailoring.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Diarra

texts.fr: Diarra est une femme de 61 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants en charge. Depuis 2ans et demi elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DIANNAH-MALARY où elle a 5 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit. Elle est vendeuse d'huile de palme et de pain de singe. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de prendre en charge sa progéniture et d'assurer le payement de leur scolarité.
texts.en:
Diarra is a 61 year old wife and mother of 4 children for whom she is responsible. For two and a half years, she has been a member of Banc Villageois de DIANNAH-MALARY, where she has successfully borrowed and repaid 5 previous loans. She sells palm oil and monkey fruit from Baobab trees. Diarra's income enables her to support her children and pay their school fees.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen and promote her business

loans.name: Lamrana

texts.en:
Lamrana J. is married and has five school-going children. She trades in assorted foodstuffs such as gari (a couscous-like grain made from grated cassava), cooking oil, rice, etc. She started this business some twenty years ago from funds she got from her husband. To-date, Lamrana is still in the business of selling local foodstuffs.

Lamrana is requesting a loan to buy more local foodstuffs so as to generate enough income to educate her children and complete her building project. She is very much dedicated to her business.

loans.use: To buy more local foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Manuel Angel

texts.es:
El Señor Miguel Ángel N. de 24 años de edad trabaja como comerciante revendedo, se dedica a la compra y venta de mercaderías varias. El mismo trabaja con sus hermanos, Norma N. de Peralta de casa san Miguel y  el señor Papi N. de comercial Katia quienes le dan su vehiculo para la venta de los productos ya sobre pedidos.

El mismo recorre la zona de Independencia para las solicitudes de pedidos para luego llevar los productos sobre pedidos.

El señor Miguel solicita un crédito a la Fundación Paraguaya para capital operativo(compra de calzados deportivos, sabanas, ropas de todo tipo, lencerias) dicho préstamo al retirarse agradeció por darle la confianza y el buen servicio.
texts.en:
Mr. Miguel Ángel N. is 24 years old and works as a resale vendor, he sells and purchases various goods. He works with his brothers Norma N. de Peralta de casa san Miguel and Mr. Papi N. of the store Katia, who give him a vehicle to sell products already on order. He also covers the Independence zone for order requests in order to later carry the products on order. Mr. Miguel requests a loan at the Foundation Paraguaya for working capital (purchase of athletic shoes, sheets, all types of clothing, lingerie), the loan will be withdrawn thanks to the trust and good service given to him.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Hopkins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Acquisition of athletic shoes, clothing of all types, sheets, towels, lingerie

loans.name: Evening Light Group

texts.en: Joel F. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called the Evening Light Group. He is 32 years old, single and has a daughter who is 5 years old. For five years, Joel has been selling used clothes in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He says that people buy from him because he is friendly. Joel plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more used clothes. His dream is to send his daughter to school and to build a house. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Joel is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase addtional used clothes

loans.name: Iqbal's Group

texts.en:
Gulshan wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Azra and Parveen each want a loan to buy clothes for their clothes-selling businesses. Shamshad wants a loan to buy repair tools for her motor workshop. 

Iqbal is a citizen of a city called Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She is also the group leader for the afore-mentioned ladies. Her husband's name is A. and he runs a grocery shop in the community. He has been in this business for the past 2 years. His clientele base is just limited to kids because of the limited variety of items in his grocery shop. But now he wants to increase his products so he will be able to improve his client base and earn more. Iqbal is applying for a loan worth Pak Rs. 15,000 to diversify her husband’s grocery shop into a grocery store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr: Fatoumata F. est âgée de 35 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DIANNAH-MALARY depuis 4ans et demi et a eu de très bonnes expériences avec le crédit pour en avoir bénéficier 9 fois de suite et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Elle est propriétaire d'un petit restaurant où elle ne vend que le petit déjeuner. Et parallèlement elle vend des tissus teintés. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de participer à l'éducation des enfants.
texts.en:
Fatoumata F. is 35 years old, she is married and the mother of three children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois of Diannah-Malary for four and a half years and has had very good experience with the loans. She obtained nine successive loans and never had any issues with reimbursing it. She is the owner of a small restaurant where she serves only breakfast. In addition, she sells dyed fabrics. Her income allows her to help contribute to the cost of her children’s education.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen and promote her restaurant busines

loans.name: Shavkatdjon

texts.ru: Джураев Шавкатджон проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 37 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Образование средне- специальное "Бухгалтер". По специальности работал 5 лет. Кроме того занимается торговлей. У него магазин, где он продает продукты питания. Этим видом бизнеса занимается уже 3 года. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Shavkatdjon D. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 37 years old, married and has 3 children. He has a secondary-specialized education as an accountant. Shavkatdjon spent 5 years working in that field. He is also involved in retail sales. He has a store, where he sells food products. Shavkatdjon has been involved in this business for 3 years. He is requesting the loan in order to expand the merchandise selection.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding merchandise selection

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Madame Aminata S. est une sociétaire  de la caisse de  l’U-IMCEC de baye Laye. Elle habite dans la même  localité. Madame S. a commence à s’activer dans la vente d’huile de palme. Ensuite elle s’est orientée  vers le commerce de thioub  venant du Mali et parfois de tissus wax. Elle a une expérience  de 5 ans dans cette activité. Aussi c’est une activité qu’elle a choisi par amour et par nécessité  car son mari est en  retraite et elle est dans l’obligation de trouver des ressources pour soutenir  ses enfants financièrement. Par conséquent  elle sollicite un crédit de 200 000 frs dans le but de faire une commande de thioubs  au mali par l’intermédiaire de sa fille commerçante  qui voyage très  souvent pour acheter des marchandises. Les périodes  de fête  comme la tabaski et la Korite lui procurent  beaucoup de bénéfices  ce qui lui permet  de satisfaire ses besoins personnels ainsi que ceux de sa famille. Cela lui permet aussi de prendre en charge ses frais médicaux  car elle est tres maladive.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aminata S. is a member of U-IMCEC of Laye bay. She lives in the same area. Mrs. S. started in the business of selling palm oil. Next she started selling thioub (dyed cotton cloth) from Mali and sometimes wax cloth (a high quality pagne cloth). She has 5 years of experience in this business. It is also a business that she chose for love and for necessity, as her husband is retired, and it is up to her to make money to financially support her children. Thus, she is seeking a 200,000-franc loan to be able to order thioubs in Mali through her daughter, who is a trader and often travels to buy goods. Holidays like the Tabaski (or Festival of Sacrifice) or the Korite bring her a lot of business, which allows her to meet her personal needs, as well as those of her family. It also allows her to take care of her medical expenses, since she is very sickly.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to strengthen her working capital

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
El comite Kuña Gaupa es una asociación D. mujeres con ganas D. salir adelante mediante el esfuerzo y el trabajo que las mismas unidas relizan.
Cada un D. las integrantes ademas D. trabajar en forma conjunta con las demas socias, tiene un actividad independiente..
El comite recibe capacitación D. asesoras D. la Fundación Paraguaya en cuanto al manejo D. negocios, elaboración D. presupuestos y planificación D. actividades..

La Señora Olga Lidubina G. D. es una D. las integrantes, ella es soltera, tiene 1 hijo, un varón D. profesión Estudiante cursando el 6to Curso D. 17 Años D. edad.

La Sra. Olga es una mujer muy activa, hace 20 años que se desemP. como Artesana, su rubro principal siempre fue la Artesanía, al igual que toda su flia.

Con el crédito ella adquirirá materiales que como telas, hilos D. colores y D. varios tipos(lana. finos, grueso, D. bordar, para tejidos),  estos son materia prima que podrá mejorar los trabajos en artesanías que ella produce y al mismo tiempo, producirá en mayor cantidad para satisfacer la gran demanda y D. esta forma incrementar sus ingresos. 

Olga es una mujer que colabora ayuda a su comunidad, es muy solidaria, ella logró que que muchas señoras se unan al grupo D. esa forma las mismas tuvieron la oportunidad D. acceder a un préstamo.
texts.en:
The “Kuña Gaupa” Committee is an association of women with a desire to get ahead through hard work in their businesses. Each is involved in her own activity, as well as being involved with the group. The group receives mentoring from “Fundación Paraguaya” and they learn how to run a business, creating revenue, and planning. Olga is one of the members. She is a single mother with one 17 year old son who attends school. Olga has been a very active artisan for the past 20 years and would like to use the money from this loan to buy supplies such as fabrics, thread of various colors and types (yarn, fine thread, thread for borders, thread for sewing, etc). These supplies will allow her to improve her artisan work as well as enable to produce more items to satisfy demand and improve her income. Olga is very helpful within her community and was instrumental in forming this group and providing its members with the opportunity for obtaining loans.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: United Business Friends Group

texts.en:
Anthony Z. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Business Friends.  Anthony sells basic foodstuffs and other home products -- "dry goods" in Liberian English -- and plans to use his 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more stock for his business such as bouillon cubes, salt, and sugar.

Anthony is 35 years old, married, and has four children aged 1, 4, 11, and 13.  He says some of his children are in elementary school.  Anthony himself is a high school graduate and wanted to continue his education but couldn't due to a lack of money.

Anthony's two-year-old business is located on Gobachop Road in Paynesville, a town on the outskirts of Liberia's capital, Monrovia.  He says he started his enterprise with the help of family and friends, but feels that the location of his business isn't very good.  He hopes to be able to move his business to a place where there's more foot traffic and customers so that things will improve.  Anthony wants to be able to make enough money to continue to pay for his children's school fees.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Anthony is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy basic foodstuffs such as bouillon cubes, salt, and sugar.

loans.name: Mohamed Alpha

texts.en:
Mohamed Alpha K. is married and has seven children, of whom three are school-going. He is 38 years old.

Mohamed entered the trading world as a petty trader selling articles such as Sudrex (pain relieving and fever reducing tablets), cream, Vaseline, paste, brushes, etc. Having raised some substantial amount of money he then switched from the sale of articles to textiles materials. He now owns a shop close to a popular cotton tree. He has ten years experience in business. 

Mohamed is therefore seeking a loan to buy more stock so as to generate more income. He intends to open a savings bank account that he will use to educate his children and eventually construct a dwelling house.

loans.use: To buy more textiles to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy used clothes to resell.

loans.name: San Antonio Group

texts.es:
El comité “ San Antonio” se conformo gracias al deseo de sus integrantes de generar  mas  ingresos  para  sus hogares y ayudar al sustento de la casa . 
Cada una utilizá  su crédito para diversas opciones de compra dependiendo de la actividad  a que se dedica.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Laura A. quien tiene una carnicería donde trabaja diariamente con su marido quien le ayuda constantemente. Ellos venden carnes de todo tipo y la clientela se encuentra satisfecha por la buena atención que ellos brindan.
La carnicería lo tienen en su casa en un salón, ahí tienen instalada su carnicería, y en esta ocasión solicita el crédito para la compra de carne(vacuno, pollo, cerdo) en gran cantidad para satisfacer la demanda actual.
texts.en:
The San Antonio Committee was formed thanks to the desire of its members to increase their incomes and help sustain their households. Each one will use their loan for different things, depending on the businesses they run. One of the members, Laura has a butcher shop. Her husband helps her run it and he helps her constantly. They sell all types of meat and the customers are happy with the service they give. The butcher shop is located in a special area of their home. They are asking for this loan in order to buy meats (beef, chicken, pork) in large quantities in order to meet customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Meats

loans.name: Soko Akutiyemina

texts.en: Soko Akutiyemina T. is a 64-year-old pharmacist in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. Born in Malikiya village, Kambia district, northern Sierra Leone, Soko is married to a nurse and they have seven children. Two of their children are in college and five are now working and living on their own. Soko has been running a private pharmacy since 2001, the year that he resigned from government service. He is seeking a loan of SLL 3,000,000 in order to invest in his business. He will use this loan to buy drugs wholesale to add to his current stock.

loans.use: Buy medicines wholesale to add to his pharmacy inventory

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Pictured here is Rebecca M.. The 38-year-old was born in Sawuliya village, about five miles from Makeni. She has 4 children and her husband is a farmer. Rebecca’s children are attending school – one is in secondary school, two are in primary school and the last is in nursery school. 

For three years now, Rebecca has been running one of the most popular restaurants in Makeni. She sells cooked rice, meat, fish, and vegetables. She also sells 'acheke' (fast food made out of cassava roots) and soft drinks. 

Rebecca is seeking a loan of SLL 4,000,000 for the first time from SMT/Kiva lenders in order to further develop her business. With this loan, she will buy cooking materials like rice and palm oil. She will also use part of the loan to rebuilt part of her restaurant that had a fire accident some months ago. She will buy thatch grass to roof the building.

loans.use: Buy cooking materials like rice and palm oil and thatch grass to roof her restaurant

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Pictured here is Isatu S., a local entrepreneur in the city of Makeni, northern Sierra Leone. Isatu is seeking a loan of SLL 2,500,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders in order to expand her business. The 45-year-old Isatu S. is a widow with two children. She was born in Lunsar, a small town situated on the highway between Makeni and Freetown. 

Isatu sells firewood, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), rice and many other locally produced goods. She has been a businesswoman for over eighteen years now. With this loan, Isatu will expand her business by buying a lorry-full of firewood, gallons of palm oil, and bags of rice.

loans.use: Buy a lorry-full of firewood, gallons of palm oil and bags of rice

loans.name: Issa's Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at one of the primary schools in Makeni. Their school was built by missionaries in 1991 to help educate orphans in and around Makeni City. The school has a total of eighteen staff members and 300 pupils.

Teachers are among the least paid workers in Sierra Leone. Because of this, many of them find other alternative means of making a living. Some engage in businesses or agriculture and others organize extra classes for the pupils (though that is a practice the government is trying to abolish). Teachers therefore seek a loan in order to embark on meaningful projects and then out of their monthly salaries, they gradually repay the loan.

Issa K. (second from left) is the headmaster of this school. He is approximately forty-five. He was born in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. He is married to a businesswoman and they have six children – five in secondary school and one in primary school. Mr. K. has been a teacher for over twenty-seven years now. He will use this loan to pay school fees for his children. 

(Attached to this photo are some snapshots of borrowers who were not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Moyad

texts.en: Moyad is a 44-year-old married man with a high school education from Nablus. He is living with his wife and four children; two of his children are in school and the others are in college. In 2006, Moyad started his own business manufacturing refrigerators. What distinguishes his business from others is that the refrigerators contain a one-year warranty, unlike other companies. He is hoping that throughout this loan he will be able to buy all the materials needed to improve his refrigerator manufacturing. His future plan is to enlarge his factory in order to be able to manufacture a larger amount of refrigerators.

loans.use: For refrigerator manufacturing and maintenance

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en: This is Rugiatu K., a small-scale businesswoman from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. The 39-year-old Rugiatu K. is married to a teacher and they have two children. One of her children is in Junior Secondary school II and the other is in class II. For over seven years now, Rugiatu has been selling medicines. She has applied for a loan of SLL 3,000,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders in order to improve her business. She will use the loan to buy more medicines to add to her pharmacy inventory. She will buy medicines such as Penoplex (two cartons), Dexorange (five cartons), Nigel (three cartons), Penadol (five cartons), Chloroquine (three cartons) and ORS (five cartons).

loans.use: Buy medicines wholesale to add to her pharmacy

loans.name: Know Yourself Group

texts.en:
Thomas Z. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Know Yourself. He is 41 years old, married, and has three children aged 5, 9, and 11. His youngest child is in kindergarten and the other two attend elementary school.

Thomas himself had to stop his education when he was a high school student, and says though he wanted to finish high school and perhaps go to college or university, he couldn't due to a lack of money and support.

His business is selling used shoes, and he says he plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more stock.

When Thomas started his four-year-old business, he sold used clothes, but since he has switched to selling used shoes. He sells from a table at the Red Light Market in Paynesville, a town on the outskirts of Liberia's capital Monrovia. Red Light is the country's largest marketplace.

Thomas says that a problems he faces is that at times the imported, used stock he buys isn't of very high quality and it can be difficult to resell it. But he says since he treats his customers well, they keep coming back. He hopes that one day he'll be able to grow his business to the point where he can move to a proper storefront.

In the photo Thomas is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP

  The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy more used shoes for resale.

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona P. is from the village of Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 69 years old and a widow with 4 adult-aged children. To make a living Chona sells home products such as shampoo, noodles, and other household items. She has operated her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Chona joined PMPC to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chona is requesting her fifth loan from PMPC, for 20000 PHP, which she will use as additional capital for her business. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her business.

loans.name: Adelaida's Group

texts.en:
Adelaida D. is from the village of Punta Miray, Baliangao. She is 45 years old. Adeleida is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Adelaida is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living Adelaida harvests and sells ocean-caught fish in the local community. Adelaida has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Adelaida joined PMPC to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelaida has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Adelaida is requesting her 11th loan from PMPC, for 10,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase a fishing boat. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 


Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda N. is from the village of Camating, Tudela Mis. Occ.. She is 49 years old. Yolanda is married and has 3 school-aged children.

To make a living Yolanda sells personal home products to tourists and local community members. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Yolanda joined PMPC to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC which she used to to purchase additional products to sell. Yolanda is requesting her third loan from PMPC, for 4000 PHP, which she will use for the same purpose. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Pedrito

texts.en:
Pedrito A. is from the village of Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. He is 56 years old. Pedrito is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Pedrito owns a retail flower and candle business in the local community. Pedrito has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Pedrito joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedrito has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Pedrito is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Pedrito from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Iyad

texts.en:
Iyad is a young man from Jabalia in Gaza strip. He owns a small shop which is the only one in its area. Iyad is married and a father of 4 children.

Iyad applied for a loan from FATEN to expand his shop and add more goods to it as well as purchasing a refrigerator for the purpose of presenting different types of frozen food he sells.

Iyad has no other source of income and would like to improve the stands in front of his small shop in the picture above to keep supporting his family and cover life expenses.

loans.use: To expand his shop's inventory and buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Edith's Group

texts.en:
Edith R. is from the village of Dicoyong, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 43 years old. Edith is the group leader of a five member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Edith is married. To make a living, Edith owns a business in the food sector which engages in the production and sale of any kind of food, most especially  "snacks".  Many of her customers are her neighbors. 

Edith has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2008, Edith joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edith has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Edith is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Edith from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy products for her business.

loans.name: Rabacca

texts.en:
Rabacca sells groceries at retail prices to her customers, who are usually friends, neighbors and residents. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She loves this business because she is able to support her husband in meeting the basic needs and necessitates of the family.

Rabacca is 36 years old and is married with four children. Her children are doing well in school. Her husband works and he also supports their home.

Rabacca is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Malicse's Group

texts.en:
Maria M. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old. Maria is the group leader of a five member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Maria is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Maria owns and operates a "sari-sari" (general retail store) business which sells a variety of different products in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Maria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Maria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Maria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Kikko Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
S. Ramathan, shown at the bottom right in the small photo, also appears in the big group photo as their leader. He is 30 years old and married with five children aged 10, 8, 6, 4 and 2 years and all in primary with the youngest in the nursery section. Ramathan also helps to take care of six orphans.

Ramathan has a cosmetics business as well as selling produce in Kame valley market for eight years. From his business transactions, even though he lacks enough capital, he is able to make profits that enable him reinvest in his business as well as pay school fees for his children and dependents.

Ramathan ensures that he has quality products from both his businesses. His dream is to ensure that he has enough stock for both his businesses.

loans.use: To restock his cosmetics and produce-selling businesses

loans.name: God's Children Group

texts.en:
Patrick K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God’s Children. He is 33 years old, married, and has two children who are 3 and 11 years old.

For five years, Patrick has been selling DVDs in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He says that his business is conveniently located, which appeals to customers.

Patrick plans to use his portion of the group loan to buy more DVDs. His dream is to improve his standard of living.

In the photo Patrick is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. 

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more DVDs to sell.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 50 years old and is married with five children. Her children are doing well in their businesses and family life.

Margret sells bags of charcoal at retail prices to her customers in Ibadan, Oyo State. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. She is also happy because, during the rainy season, her sales of charcoal will increase. She hopes to be a major distributor of bags of charcoal in her community in the future.

Margret is requesting a loan of N40,000 to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: A. Romero's Group

texts.en:
Arsenia R. is from the village of Tubod, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old. Arsenia is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Arsenia is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living Arsenia operates a "sari-sari" general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Arsenia has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Arsenia joined PMPC to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arsenia successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Arsenia is requesting her second loan from PMPC, for 6000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Maria Eugenia Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Paraguarí, Km, se reunieron unas mujeres con ganas de conformar un comité para acceder al préstamo, de ahí que coordinaron la reunión para interiorizarse sobre el programa, quienes aceptaron pues era una oportunidad para aumentar su capital de trabajo y recibir capacitación para crecer como persona, ellas son muy humildes quienes nunca antes han recibido ningún tipo de apoyo crediticia.
El comité lleva por nombre María Eugenia, quienes se encuentran en el tercer ciclo integrada por 17  sacrificadas y luchadoras mujeres, quienes se esfuerzan a diario para mejorar la calidad de vida de ellas y de sus respectivas familias. Todas las integrantes son señoras muy activas, quienes han invertido sus préstamos en sus respectivas actividades.
Una de ellas es la señora Valentina S. quien es una señora muy humilde, tiene 5 hijos y madre separada, ella para mantener a sus hijos se dedica  a la venta ambulante de varias cosa dependiendo de la hora del día, por ejemplo a la mañana vende comestibles y café con pan, luego vende golosinas, medias, frutas, y en horas de la siestas nuevamente comestible. Ella esta conforme con su trabajo ya ayuda a que todos sus hijos asistan a la escuela y alcanza también para la alimentación. 
El crédito que solicita es para la compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de comestibles (carne, condimentos, pastas, panificados) y otras mercaderías para vender como golosinas(chocolate, caramelos).
texts.en:
A group of women with a desire for access to loans have united in the city of Paraguarí, Km. There they were taught about and accepted the program, which gave them the opportunity to increase their working capital and grow as individuals. They are humble women who have never before had access to credit. The committee is called “María Eugenia” and is in its third cycle. It’s made up of 17 women willing to fight and sacrifice daily in order to improve their lives and the lives of their families. All of the women are active in their businesses and have invested the money from their loans into their respective businesses. One of the ladies, Valentina, is separated and has five children. In order to support her children, she sells various things on foot. She sells different things depending on the time of day, for example in the morning she sells food, coffee and bread. Later she sells snacks, hosiery, and fruit, and later food once more. She is satisfied with her work and [the income] allows her children to attend school and also allows her to pay for food. She is asking for this loan in order to buy ingredients (meat, condiments, pasta, baked goods) and other items to sell as snacks (chocolate, caramel).

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de comestibles (carne, condimentos, pastas, panificados) y otras mercaderías para vender como golosinas(chocolate, caramelos).

loans.name: Woodtu Group

texts.en:
Joseph J. is the leader of a group of five borrowers named Woodtu. Joseph’s business is making and selling concrete blocks and columns used for construction. He plans to use his portion of the group loan to buy more cement and steel rods for his business.

Joseph is 51 years old, married, and has five children whose ages range from 1 to 9 years old. His school-age children are either in kindergarten or elementary school.

Joseph’s business is located at View Point in the Red Light Market. Red Light is Liberia’s largest marketplace, and is located in Paynesville on the outskirts of the capital Monrovia. He started his business nine years ago with some friends.

Joseph says the biggest challenge he faces in business has been a lack of capital to buy more raw materials for his business. He takes pride in his work and says his customers keep coming back because the finished cement blocks and columns he sells are high quality. He hopes that he can grow his business so much that one day he’ll be able to open a factory.

In the photo Joseph is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy cement and iron rods to make concrete blocks and columns.

loans.name: Takku Liggey Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement Takku Liggey est la sous branche de l’Association des Femmes pour le développement de l’entreprise (AFDE) présente dans la caisse de Médina Fall une caisse de U-IMCEC Thiès. 
 Cette association, l’AFDE,  est une organisation de femmes commerçantes de petite échelle travaillant dans Thiès, une ville environ 70 Kms de Dakar. L'association a été fondée en 1993 par vingt femmes entrepreneurs pour augmenter leur pouvoir d'achat par le biais  d’une tontine (système de financement tournant dans lequel chaque membre cotise périodiquement une somme convenue et qu’on verse à tour de rôle aux différents membres). 
Cette politique ne permettant pas de financer au même jour tous les membres, elles décidèrent d’adhérer à l’IMCEC afin de s’octroyer du crédit sans des demandes de garanties. C’est ainsi que les membres sont divisés en  sous groupe de 5, avec une présidente désignée et une trésorière pour chaque sous groupe. Ces sous-groupes, qui portent le nom de Takku Liggey dans la caisse Médina Fall, peuvent être le même pendant de nombreuses années, mais changent souvent de membres selon le financement des besoins et d'autres considérations.
 L'AFDE organise des réunions de membre mensuellement où tous les sous groupes et branches sont conviés et dirige une coopération pour ses membres, en leur permettant d'acheter du riz et d'autres produits à de meilleurs prix.
 L'AFDE est dirigée par une Présidente du nom de Madame Mame Diarra MAR et une trésorière Madame Ndeye Ndella D. toutes habitantes de Thiès. 
Ainsi, le sous groupe Takku Liggey N°28 est à sa tête Madame Mame Bousso M. âgée de 29 ans. Cette femme mère de 4 enfants est une commerçante ambulante depuis 2 ans. Elle place à ses clients des pagnes, draps, perles et de l’encens. Elle a été influencée dans ce métier par un ami de son père qui l’encourageait et l’aidait à écouler ses produits en dehors de Thiès. Cependant pour ce crédit, elle compte s’approvisionner en produits (encens, perles, draps) pour renforcer son activité. Elle partage ce sous groupe avec :
-	Madame Khoudia S., la trésorière, vendeuse depuis un an de perles (bine-bine), draps, encens qu’elle a hérité de sa maman.
-	Madame Awa T. qui vend des produits de lessive
-	Madame Khady D.  qui s’active dans le commerce d’arachide, niébé (haricots), bissap….
-	Madame Awa F.  qui s’active également dans la vente de perles (bine-bine) encens et autres.
texts.en:
The Takku Liggey group is a sub-branch of the Women's Association for Business Development (l'Association des Femmes pour le Développement de l'Entreprise - AFDE) present in the Médina Fall savings institution, which belongs to the U-IMCEC (a Senegalese association of mutual savings and loans institutions) in Thiès.The AFDE is an organisation of women running small businesses in Thiès, a small town which lies around 70 kilometers from Dakar. The association was founded in 1993 by 20 female entrepreneurs in order to increase their purchasing power by means of a "tontine" (a revolving fincance system whereby each member contributes an agreed amount periodically and this is passed on in rotation to different members). Since this policy does not allow all members to get funding at the same time, they decided to join the IMCEC in order to obtain a loan without being asked for guarantees. For this reason the members divided into sub-groups of five, with each of these sub-groups designating a president and a treasurer. These sub-groups, which all carry the name Takku Liggey in the Medina Fall savings institution, can retain the same members for numerous years, but often the members do change because of financing needs and other considerations. The AFDE organises members' meetings on a monthly basis where all sub-groups and branches are convened, and it also runs a cooperative for its members, allowing them to buy rice and other products at preferential prices. The AFDE is led by a president, whose name is Mrs Diarra MAR and a treasurer, Mrs.Nedeye Ndella D., both residents of Thiès. The sub-group, Takku Liggey No. 28 is run by Mrs. Mame Bousso Baye, who is 29 years old. This woman, who has four children, has been a door-to-door saleswoman for two years. She sells pagnes (West African colourful fabric), sheets, pearls and incense to her customers. She has been influenced in this trade by a friend of her father who encouraged her and helped her to sell her products outside Thiès. With this loan she is planning to get supplies of products (incense, pearls, sheets) in order to strengthen her activity. She participates in the sub-group with: - Mrs. Khoudia S., the treasurer, who sells "bine-bine" pearls, sheets, and incense which she has inherited from her mother - Mrs. Awa T., who sells washing powder - Mrs Khady D., who is active in trading peanut, niébé beans and bissap (a refreshing drink made from hibiscus flowers). - Mrs. Awa F., who also sells "bine bine pearls, incense and other items.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen their different activities

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Rebecca H. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God is Able. She is 36 years old, married, and has six children who range from 10 to 18 years old. She was never able to attend school because of a lack of support. 

For over 10 years Rebecca has been selling rice and oil at the Old Road Market near downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She says that her manner of interacting with her customers is very friendly, which keeps them coming to her for business.

Rebecca plans to use her portion of the group loan to buy more rice and oil. 

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Rebecca is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more rice and oil.

loans.name: Inna

texts.en:
Inna O. is married with one child. She owns a business where she sells artificial flowers and funeral wreaths. She started this business 10 years ago. Excellent client service and large variety bring in many clients.

In Ukrainian culture there is a time in spring to remember the dead. Most people go to the cemeteries and put artificial flowers or wreaths by the graves of their relatives. Thus spring is a high season for Inna.

Inna would like to borrow 18,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. Inna's business goal is to start several more retail locations.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 40 years old and is married with four children who are doing well in school. She hopes to give them a quality education.

Joy sells drinks, groceries and tailoring materials at retail prices to her customers in Ibadan, Oyo State. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. She is also happy because during the high season her sales will increase. She hopes to own a supermarket in her community in the future.

Joy is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es:
Roberto   tiene   30 años de edad,  vive  con su señora  Nélida Ovando tienen   un  hijo  y viven en casa  propia.
Desde  muy  joven  se dedicó a trabajar arduamente  para  poder  llevar  un mejor  nivel  de  vida, se inició como  vendedor ambulante de una  empresa  particular. En ese  trance conoció a su compañera actual, fueron  progresando  de a poco  hasta que llegaron a   a  reunir capital para formar  su  propia  microempresa.
Hoy  día  trabaja en grande y  le da trabajo a varias  personas  humildes  de la zona, es  muy  luchador y  sueña  con  que su  hijo  sea  una  persona de  bien  y llegue a  ser alguien en la vida.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de vaqueros, termos, sábanas, cacerolas, asaderas, remeras, etc.
texts.en:
Roberto is 30 years old and lives with his wife, Nélida Ovando, and their son in their own house. He has worked extremely hard from a very young age to improve his standard of living. He started out as a street vendor with his own business. While working under difficult conditions he met his now wife, and together they started making progress, bit by bit, until they were able to put together enough capital to form their own small business. These days he has a lot of work, and he provides employment to many people in his area that are in need. He is very much a fighter and hopes that his son will be a good person and that he will grow up to be someone. He is applying for a loan to buy jeans, Thermos flasks, sheets, pans, grills, T-shirts and other merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Alcira

texts.es:
La Sra Alcira nacio el 8 D. septiembre D. 1944 en Obra GranD. en VallegranD.(La provincia VallegranD. se ubica en la región Sur Occidental a 241 kilómetros del departamento D. Santa Cruz D. la Sierra. Tiene una población D. 26.027 habitantes y una superficie D. 6.414 kilometros cuadrados. Está ubicada a una altura media D. 1.970 metros sobre el nivel del Mar.

VallegranD. se caracteriza por su topografía accidentada con valles, montañas y varias serranías.

Su clima es templado, poco variable y su principal producción es la Agricultura y sus campos son apropiados para el cultivo D. especies D. flora ornamental). 

La Sra. Alcira tiene 4 hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar esta casada con el Sr. francisco, los dos se dedican a la agricultura.
 
Hace 20 años que adquirio una pequeña parsela en villa florida a 10km D. San Luis camino a la Pampa D. Coscal, hace 20 años tambien que se dedica a la agricultura en esa zona y nunca habia sacado credito D. otra institucion es la primera ves que saca financiamiento y vino a Emprender por referencias D. un vecino que tambien se dedica a la misma actividad que la Sra Alcira, ella es muy trabajadora ya que tiene 4 hijos que mantener se levanta a tempranas horas D. la mañana, el dinero del credito es para la compra D. semillas para la siembra D. Papa ya que es temporada D. siembra, y despues D. cosecharlas lo comercializa en el mercado D. la zona la Sra Alcira tambien siembra otros productos como Maiz, Poroto, etc.

La Sra Alcira esta agradecida con Emprender por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Alcira was born on the 8th of September, 1944 in Obra GranD., VallegranD.. The province of VallegranD. in located in the south west region, 241 kilometres from the department of Santa Cruz D. la Sierra. It has a population of 26,027 inhabitants and a landmass of 6,414 square kilometres. It is located at a mean height of 1,970 metres above sea level. VallegranD. is characterised by its hilly topography of valleys, mountains and various mountain ranges. It has a mild, stable climate and its primary production is agriculture. Its fields are used for the cultivation of ornamental flowers. Alcira has four school-aged children and is married to Francisco. Both of them work in agriculture. 20 years ago, Alcira aquired a small parcel of land in Villa Florida,10km from San Luis, on the way to Pampa D. Coscal. At the same time, she started working in this area in agriculture. Alcira has never taken out a loan at another institution and this is the first time that she is asking for a loan with Kiva. She went to Emprender (Kiva's field partner) after it was recommended to her by a neighbour who works in the same field as her. Alcira is very hardworking and as she has four children to raise she gets up in the early hours of the morning to start work. The money from this loan will be used to purchase seeds to sow potatoes as it is now sowing season, and after harvesting them she will sell them in the local market. Alcira also sows other vegetables, including corn and beans. Alcira is grateful to Emprender for the trust they have placed in her in approving this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds to sow potato

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en:
Adeola O. sells medicines at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more medicines to sell.

Adeola is 27 years old and is married with a child. Her husband sells motorcycle spare parts at retail prices to support their home. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: The Blood Of Jesus Group

texts.en:
Cecelia S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called The Blood of Jesus. She is 40 years old, married, and has 7 children whose ages range from 4 to 19 years old. She says two of her kids are in high school and the other five are in elementary school.

For 11 years Cecelia has been selling bananas at the J. Compound in Paynesville, a town on the outskirts of Liberia's capital Monrovia. She intends to use her portion of the group loan to buy more bananas to sell.

Cecelia started her business with only 500 LRD -- about $7 U.S. at today's exchange rate -- and says that one day she'd like to be able to start growing bananas as well.

She says that some of her biggest challenges in doing business is that her stock spoils if it goes unsold and that rats sometimes nibble away at her inventory at night.

In the photo Cecelia is the one holding the sign and Sarah G. is the inset at lower right.

About LEAP

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy bananas to sell.

loans.name: Takku Liggey N°30 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupement Takku Liggey est la sous branche de l’Association des Femmes pour le développement de l’entreprise (AFDE) présente dans la caisse de Médina Fall une caisse de U-IMCEC Thiès. 
 Cette association, l’AFDE,  est une organisation de femmes commerçantes de petite échelle travaillant dans Thiès, une ville environ 70 Kms de Dakar. L'association a été fondée en 1993 par vingt femmes entrepreneurs pour augmenter leur pouvoir d'achat par le biais  d’une tontine (système de financement tournant dans lequel chaque membre cotise périodiquement une somme convenue et qu’on verse à tour de rôle aux différents membres). 
Cette politique ne permettant pas de financer au même jour tous les membres, elles décidèrent d’adhérer à l’IMCEC afin de s’octroyer du crédit sans des demandes de garanties. C’est ainsi que les membres sont divisés en  sous groupe de 5, avec une présidente désignée et une trésorière pour chaque sous groupe. Ces sous-groupes, qui portent le nom de Takku Liggey dans la caisse Médina Fall, peuvent être le même pendant de nombreuses années, mais changent souvent de membres selon le financement des besoins et d'autres considérations.
 L'AFDE organise des réunions de membre mensuellement où tous les sous groupes et branches sont conviés et dirige une coopération pour ses membres, en leur permettant d'acheter du riz et d'autres produits à de meilleurs prix.
 L'AFDE est dirigée par une Présidente du nom de Madame Mame Diarra MAR et une trésorière Madame Ndeye Ndella Diouf toutes habitantes de Thiès. 
Ainsi, le sous groupe Takku Liggey N°30 regroupe 5 femmes qui font la même activité. Elles vendent du charbon de bois et du bois de chauffage sous le contrôle du service des Eaux et Forêts afin de ne pas contribuer à la dégradation de la nature disent-elles. Ce prêt leur permet de développer leur activité et de renforcer par la caution solidaire leur solidarité. C’est un sous groupe dirigé par Madame Tabara D. âgée de 50 ans et mère de 7 enfants. Cette dame connait bien son domaine et capitalise une expérience de 6 ans. Elle est dans ce groupe avec Madame la trésorière Anta Guène, Madame Ndeye Ndella L., Madame Ouzine L. et Madame Khady B..
texts.en:
The Takku Liggey group is a sub-group of the Association des Femmes pour le Développement de l’Entreprise (AFDE), which is represented in the Medina Fall branch of U-IMCEC in Thiès. The AFDE is an organization of women in small-scale commerce working in Thies, a city about 70 km from Dakar. This association was founded in 1993 by twenty women entrepreneurs to increase their purchasing power by way of a tontine (a revolving credit system in which each member periodically pays a suitable amount and which funds its various members by turns). This policy does not allow every member to be financed on the same day. The members decided to join IMCEC in order to award loans without guarantee requirements. Thus, the members are divided into sub-groups of five, each with a designated president and a treasurer. These sub-groups, which are called Takku Liggey in the Medina Fall branch, can be the same for several years but often change their members according to the financing of needs and other considerations. The AFDE organizes member meetings each month, when all the sub-groups and branches are invited. It facilitates cooperation for its members, enabling them to buy rice and other goods at better prices. The AFDE is lead by a president by the name of Ms. Mame Diarra MAR and by a treasurer, Ms. Ndeye Ndella Diouf , both residents of Thiès. Thus, the sub-group Takky Liggey n° 30 regroups five women in the same business. They sell charcoal and firewood under the control of the Water Affairs and Forestry department to avoid contributing (as they say) to the degradation of nature. This loan allows them to develop their activity and reinforce solidarity through their group deposit. The sub-group is led by Ms. Tabara Tiagne, 50 years old and mother of seven children. This lady knows the business and has an accumulated six years’ experience. She is joined in this group by the Treasurer Ms. Anta Guène, Ms. Ndeye Ndella L., Ms. Ouzine L. and Ms. Khady B..

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Obtain charcoal and firewood supplies

loans.name: Julio

texts.es:
Julio trabaja como transportista de carga (papa, chuño – es papa que ha sido procesada de diferente manera -, carne de cerdo) la esposa es comerciante de carne de cerdo por kilo; estas dos actividades son sus principales fuentes de ingreso con que cubren la manutención de sus dos hijos. Vive en la zona Rio Seco de la ciudad de El Alto.
 
El crédito lo destinará a comprar un motor para su movilidad para continuar trabajado.
 
Es el segundo crédito con IMPRO, el buen comportamiento de pago le permite aprobar otro préstamo solicitado por Julio.
texts.en:
Julio works transporting cargo. He transports potatoes, “chuño” (potato that has been processed in a different way), and pork. His wife is a merchant who sells pork by the kilo. These two activities are their primary sources of income, which support their two children. They live in the Rio Seco area of the city of El Alto. The loan is to buy a motor for his vehicle in order to keep working. It is his second loan with Impro. His good payment history allows for approval of Julio’s requested loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a motor for his vehicle, which he uses to transport cargo

loans.name: Eugénie

texts.fr: Née en 1960 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, K. Eugénie est mariée à AFFANOU Kuassi Marcel, un pêcheur. Eugénie est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit à Fiégnon à Cotonou. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Eugénie n'a pas été à l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Eugénie vend des poissons fumés de façon ambulante. De façon secondaire, Eugénie vend du maïs et de la farine de manioc. C'est au port de pêche à Cotonou que Eugénie  achète ses poissons. Eugénie mène cette activité depuis 15 ans environs et a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Eugénie voudrait agrandir son activité et satisfaire davantage sa clientèle. C'est ce qui amène Eugénie à solliciter auprès de ALIDé, un quatrième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Eugénie K. is married to Kuassi Marcel AFFANOU, a fisherman. Eugénie is the mother of five children, all having attended (or still attending) school. Eugénie herself has not attended school. The family lives in Fiégnon in Cotonou.
