The couple shares the various family expenses. To meet her needs and those of her children, Eugénie sells smoked fish as an itinerant vendor. She also sells corn and cassava flour as a secondary activity. She buys her fish at the fishing port in Cotonou. Eugénie has been in business for about 15 years and has already been granted three loans from ALIDé, all of which have been repaid in full. She would like to expand her activity and increase customer satisfaction, which is why she is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fresh fish

loans.name: Sarah Sackor Group

texts.en:
Missionmah R. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Sarah Sackor Group. She is 58 years old, married and has six children who range from 25 to 40 years old.  She did not have the opportunity to go to school.

For more than 3 years, Missionmah has been running her doughnut business at the Old Road Market in Monrovia, Liberia.  Missionmah prepares her doughnuts well and takes the doughnuts around to customers which keeps them buying from her.

Missionmah plans to use her 14,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 56,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more flour, sugar and oil for making doughnuts. Her goal is to improve her business and buy land for her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Missionmah is the one holding the sign. Naomi D. is inset at lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more flour, sugar and oil for making doughnuts.

loans.name: Evelio Gregorio

texts.es: Evelio Gregorio es un hombre muy trabajador él tiene 35 años. Su actividad económica es la venta y producción de semilla jícaro. Hace más de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio, el inicia por sus padres ellos fueron los que le enseñaron a Evelio a ganarse el pan de cada día, además tiene a sus 2 hijos de los cuales tiene que hacerse cargo. Además este delicioso productos que vende es muy demandado por sus clientes, ya que la elaboración de este en refresco es muy delicioso. El sueña con terminar de construir su vivienda para dejársela a sus hijos. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima para la elaboración de sus productos.
texts.en:
Evelio Gregario, age 35, is a very hard-working man. He sells and produces the seeds of the calabash gourd. He has been in this business for over ten years. He started because of his parents. They were the ones who taught Evelio to win his daily bread. Also, he has two children that he has to support. This delicious product that he sells is in much demand by his customers. When used to make beverages it is very delicious. He dreams of finishing the construction on his house in order to leave it to his children. The requested loan is to buy raw material to make his products.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 47 and lives with his wife and six children; all his children are in college. He has been selling bicycle spare parts since 1990 in his home town and his business has really improved. He has gained much experience in the previous twenty years and his business is very important to him. He uses his earnings to educate his children and support his family. 

Michael had previously taken out a loan of 140,000 Kenyan shillings which he used to expand his business and which he successfully repaid. He is a very hardworking person and he has many plans for the future. He plans to buy a lorry to transport his supplies in the future. He has requested a loan of  20,000 shillings from Faulu Kenya to buy more spare parts for sale.

loans.use: To buy bicycle spare parts for resale

loans.name: Abigeal

texts.en:
Abigeal is 40 years old and is married with four children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband is a barber and he also supports their home. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She hopes they become graduates in the future. 

Abigeal sells groceries at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to grow her business and so she is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Fumi

texts.en:
Fumi has a computer centre where she renders computer services to her customers. She hopes to own a computer school in the future where she will teach young girls and boys how to use the computer.

Fumi also sells stationery at retail prices. She has been in these businesses for a long time and she uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers. She is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more stationery to sell. She loves this business because of the profits she makes.

Fumi is 38 years old and is married with two children. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a 46 year old married man with four children in school.  He has been farming for fifteen years.  He does dairy farming as well as growing tea and vegetables for commercial use.  He sells his farm produce to area residents and transports some to other provinces in the country.  Since he became a member of Faulu Kenya, he has been able to buy a cow which has increased his production.  

He has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to top up to his savings and buy a pick-up to ease transport.  He hopes to buy a lorry in the future.  George has big dreams for the future, he dreams of becoming the main supplier of vegetables in his area and owning a shop for selling animal feed.

loans.use: To buy a pick-up for transporting farm produce

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bakkiliza Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
At the bottom left in the small photo is Fatumah M. who is profiled in the description.  Fatumah also appears in the big group photo. She is a buoyant 21 year old who has ventured early into business.

At her young age, Fatumah, by conventional standards, should still be in school. However, she decided to go against the societal grain. As such, she took root in a hair salon business almost two years ago in Kireka, Mukono district.

Being single has, in a way, played into Fatumah’s hands, in that she has had no major responsibility to bear so far and, as such, she has built on her business experience. In the course of time, she has given her business the quality time and devotion it needs.

Since the inception of her business, Fatumah has managed to steadily sustain her finances. On a monthly basis, her financial gains amount to 140,000 shillings. She credits her suave business skills as one factor which has kept her above the competition.

Notwithstanding her successes, Fatumah envisages an even brighter future for herself if she can obtain a loan to sustainably expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more stock like hair weaves, braids and hair chemicals for her salon

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en: Edwin is a 26 year old single man. He runs a general merchandise shop where he sells sugar, soaps, cooking fat, and maize flour to earn a living. He is also employed on a farm.  He works very hard to be able to meet his expenses and to be able to take care of his aged parents. He hopes to expand his business and improve his living standards in the future.  He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to add to his stock of maize flour, sugar and cooking fat.

loans.use: Inventory for general store

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: Née en 1964 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, M. Antoinette est mariée à ASSOTO Théophile et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais parmi les trois enfants, un n'est plus à la charge de Antoinette. La famille vit au quartier Abokicodji à Cotonou. Antoinette vient en aide à son mari en assurant avec lui les différentes charges des enfants. Pour y arriver, Antoinette vend du pain et divers produits (conserves, lait, pâtes alimentaires, papiers hygiéniques, etc.)à son domicile. Antoinette se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits, qu'elle a bien remboursés. Antoinette voudrait renforcer son activité et augmenter le stock de ses produits, afin de mieux répondre à la demande des clients et se faire plus de revenu pouvant l'aider à soutenir son mari dans le ménage. C'est pour cette raison que Antoinette sollicite un cinquième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1964 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Antoinette M. is married to Théophile ASSOTO and is mother of three children, all having attended (or still attending) school. One of the three children is no longer under her care. The family lives in the Abokicodji neighborhood of Cotonou, and Antoinette assists her husband with the various children-related expenses. To make ends meet, Antoinette sells bread and various products from her home (canned goods, milk, pasta, toilet paper, etc.). She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. She is a regular client of ALIDé, having already been granted four previous loans, all reimbursed in full. She would like to strengthen her activity and increase her stock supply, in reaction to customer demand. She also wants to generate more income to help her husband with household expenses. This is why she is requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bread and various products (canned goods, milk, pasta, toilet paper, etc.)

loans.name: Carmen Rosa

texts.es:
Carmen Rosa tiene 28 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a sus padres en el caserío Granja Sasape, una zona rural del distrito de Túcume, de la provincia de Lambayeque, ubicado a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace cuatro años tiene instalada en su domicilio una bodega en la cual ofrece a sus clientes todo tipo de abarrotes y articulos de primera necesidad. Este negocio le brinda los ingresos que necesita para solventar sus gastos personales y apoyar al mantenimiento de su familia, por lo que siempre se esfuerza al maximo para sacarlo adelante, brindando productos de calidad y ofreciendo un buen trato a sus clientes.

El negocio goza de buena acogida debido a que la zona en donde vive queda lejos del mercado mas cercano y los vecinos no cuentan con los recursos suficientes para ir hacia alla todos los dias. Por este motivo Carmen Rosa desea ampliar su negocio para captar mas clientes y aumentar sus ingresos, para lograr este objetivo ella se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad.

Carmen Rosa es una joven emprendedora y que gusta mucho de la labor que realiza, en su comunidad la consideran una joven de confianza. Ella ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución demostrando puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Carmen Rosa is 28 years old and single. She lives with her parents in the rural community of Granja Sasape in the Túcume district of the Lambayeque province. It is located one hour from the city of Chiclayo. Four years ago she set up a convenience store in her house. She sells her customers all types of groceries and basic needs items. This business provides the needed income to pay her personal expenses and helps to support her family. That is why she always puts forth maximum effort to get the business ahead. She offers quality products and good service to her customers. The business has been well received because the area where they live is far from the nearest market. The neighbors do not have sufficient resources to go that far everyday. That is why Rosa wants to expand her business, gain more customers, and increase her income. In order to reach her objective she is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a loan for 1,000 PEN. She will buy groceries and basic needs items. Carmen Rosa is an enterprising young woman who really likes the work she does. In her community she is considered to be a trustworthy young person. She has worked with our institution before, and she has demonstrated punctuality and responsibility with her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic needs items and groceries to expand her business

loans.name: God Gift Group

texts.en:
Thelma G. is the leader of a group five borrowers called God Gift. She is 40 years old, married, and has three children who are between 2 and 18 years old.  She was not able to continue her education through 8th grade.  For 5 years, Thelma has been running her dry fish business at the Old Road Market in Monrovia, Liberia.

She sells fish at a reasonable price and talks to customers in a friendly manner which keeps them returning. Thelma plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase additional fish. Her goal is to grow her business and send her children to school.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Thelma is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy fish for resale

loans.name: Rosine

texts.fr: Née en 1965 à Adja au Mono, Y. Rosine vit depuis 25 ans environs à Xwlacodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rosine est mariée à EFIO Jean-Marie, et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges des enfants. Rosine n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a environs 15 ans que Rosine mène comme activité, la vente de farine de manioc à son domicile. Parallèlement à cette activité, Rosine vend également de "sodabi" (boisson alcoolisée locale) à son domicile. Rosine s'approvisionne à Adja. Rosine a bénéficié une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Rosine sollicite un deuxième prêt, afin d'augmenter le volume de son activité et d'accroître ses sources de revenus. Ce qui lui permettra de mieux répondre à ses clients et aussi aux exigences de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in 1965 in Adja in the Mono area, Rosine Y. has been living for the past 25 years in the Xwlacodji area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Rosine is married to Jean-Marie EFIO, and is the mother of three children, all having attended (or still attending) school. Rosine herself has not attended school. The couple shares the various child-related expenses. For the past 15 years Rosine has been selling cassava flour from her home. As a side business Rosine also sells “sodabi” (a local alcoholic beverage) from her home. She gets her supplies in Adja. Rosine was already granted one loan from ALIDé, which was repaid in full. She is now requesting a second loan to expand the volume of her business and extend her sources of income. This will allow her to respond to customer demand and also to her family’s expectations.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of cassava flour

loans.name: Jesus Es Prosperidad 4,5 Group

texts.en:
Cornelia is the coordinator of her group Jesus es Prosperidad (Jesus is Prosperity), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Santiago, an urban area known for tobacco and beef production,  where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her three children.

Cornelia is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling polo shirts, accessories and skirts by purchasing her merchandise in the main markets and then selling it in her community at a profit. She will use the profits to purchase the daily needs of food and clothing for her children, as well as saving towards building a successful business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Shirts, skirts, accesories

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty K. is 32 years old and married to Stephen Kiprop. They live in Kabarnet town and have four children, Cynthia, Elsi Chebet, Elly and Cathy, who are aged between 10 years and 4 years old.

Betty operates a salon in Kabarnet town and the resident of this town are her clients. She started the salon eight years ago and she gets a monthly profit of Kshs 35,000 from this business. Betty also owns a household utensils shop from which she gets a profit of Kshs 28,000 per month.

This is the only MFI from which she has borrowed funds after a friend introduced her to Kadet Ltd. Betty has borrowed a loan of Kshs 80,000 which she will use to purchase stock for the salon business, with things like shampoo, hair weaves, hair oils and others. If this loan boosts her business, she will plough back the profit into it so that it will expand.

Betty dreams of having a big business and a stable source of income. She describes herself as hard-working.

loans.use: To purchase stock for the business

loans.name: Franco

texts.en:
Franco A. is a 35 year old businessman, married with three children. He is married to Alice, a civil servant with the government. He runs a retail shop in Virhembe, a low cost residential area in Kakamega town. Franco has been running this business for 17 years and sells mainly foodstuffs and household goods.

Franco learned about KADET through a friend and is not new to KADET Ltd since he is taking his fifth loan. Franco always maintained a good repayment history in the previous loans and that is why he has been considered for this loan.

He hopes to use the money to purchase more stock of foodstuff, calling cards, firewood and paraffin for sale.

In the long run, he hopes to expand his business to wholesale and buy a pickup vehicle for delivery of sales like firewood. He also intends to buy a maize grinding machine (poshomill) since he has demand for that business in his locality.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuff for sale.

loans.name: San Roque Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad Paraguari, se reunieron un grupo de mujeres con el objetivo de conformar un comité y de esa manera acceder al préstamo que ayudaría a mejorar la actividad que las mismas realizan.
El comité lleva por nombre San Roque, cuya denominación se debe al nombre del barrio al cual pertenecen, actualmente se encuentran en el sexto ciclo con calificación excelente integrada por 19  sacrificadas señoras, quienes ponen el mayor de sus esfuerzos para mejorar la calidad de vida de ellas y de sus respectivas familias. Todas las integrantes son mujeres muy luchadoras, quienes han invertido sus préstamos en sus respectivas actividades.
La señora Dionisia F. es una de las integrantes, la misma se dedica al negocio de ventas de productos de uso doméstico.
Ella es una señora muy trabajadora, atiende su negocio y ademas realiza todas las labores de la casa, su marido es albañil y constantemente realiza trabajo de construcción y ayuda bastante también a la familia.
texts.en:
In the city of Paraguari, a group of women met with the aim of forming a committee and thereby accessing a loan that will help improve their business activities. Their committee, San Roque is named after the neighborhood they belong to. Currently they are in the sixth cycle of excellent ratings, the group is composed of 19 women who have sacrificed a lot and put most of their effort into improving the quality of life for themselves and their families. All of the women members are fighters, who have invested their loans in their respective business activities. Mrs. Dionisia F. is one of the members, her business sells domestic household products. She is a hard worker, she tends to her business and also takes care of all the household duties, he husband is a mason and works in construction and also helps their family a lot.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Hopkins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of products for a bakery, dairy, meats, canned goods

loans.name: Taofeek

texts.en:
Taofeek sells tires to make a living in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger. He has been in this tires business for a long time and he is well known in his community.

Taofeek is 41 years old and is married with four children. His children are excelling in school and this gives him joy. He is requesting a loan of N150,000 to purchase more tires to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tires to sell

loans.name: Mulago Development Group

texts.en:
N. Susan, the lady that appears at the bottom right in a small photo also appears in the big photo as the group leader. The two ladies in the other small photo are also a part of the group.

Susan is a married 30-year-old with two school-going children. She has two years experience and entrepreneurial skills in operating a boutique. Her business, at present, generates her nearly 72,000 Ugandan shillings in a week. Her work station can be found in Nasuuti, Mukono district.

The one factor that has struck that success chord in her business has been her caring and welcoming customer care skills. She plans on redeveloping her business into a leading boutique franchise in Mukono in the near future. Her blueprint plans, she says, will be brought to an implementation stage, after she obtains this loan.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her boutique

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul Kipkoech K. is 40 years old and married to Mercy Chepkoech, who is 26 years old. Paul has been blessed with children: Enock, Kibet, Diporah and Chepngetich. Paul describes himself as dedicated and hardworking.

Paul operates an electronics shop which he has been doing for the last four years. From this shop, Paul makes an average profit of 9,500 Kenyan shillings (KES) and an extra 10,000 KES from other sources. Mr. K.’s business is situated along Kabarnet Eldoret road and most of his customers are Kabarnet residents.

Paul was introduced to KADET by a staff member during a marketing session. He has borrowed 50,000 KES of which he will use 5,000 KES to purchase 100 chicken layers, 6,000 KES to purchase chicken broilers, 30,000 KES to purchase materials for construction of a poultry house, and the remaining 9,000 KES will be used to purchase layers and broilers mash and feed. If this loan boosts his business, Mr. K. intends to purchase a plot of land, on which he hopes and dreams to later construct his own house and rental houses. Mr. K. wants to educate his children to the highest level possible and to have a better standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase chicken layers and broilers

loans.name: God Is Love Group

texts.en: For more than 15 years, Jiblee T. has been selling foodstuffs such as peanuts and flour in the Free Port Community, adjacent the seaport of Monrovia, Liberia. She is 48 years old, married, and has four children, ages 30 to 36 years old. She did not continue her education through 6th grade due to a lack of support from her parents. Jiblee talks to her customers in a friendly manner which keeps them returning. She plans to use her 14,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 36,000 LRD group loan to purchase more peanuts and flour to bake bread. Her goal is to improve her business and buy land to construct a house for her family. Jiblee is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "God is Love". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Jiblee is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more peanuts and flour

loans.name: Angelita

texts.es:
Angelita es una madre de familia de 45 años de edad y vive junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el caserío La Pava, una zona agrícola del distrito de Mochumí, en la provincia de Lambayeque; ubicada a una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales desde hace más de cuatro años. Ella cría aves de corral en un ambiente destinado para este propósito que se encuentra situado en la parte posterior de su domicilio; los animales que mas cría, debido a que tienen mayor acogida, son los pavos. Angelita nos comenta que tuvo que empezar a dedicarse a esta actividad porque su esposo, al igual que la mayoría de hombres de la zona, se dedica a trabajar como obrero en labores agrícolas y los ingresos que percibe no son suficientes para solventar los gastos familiares.

Ella desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más aves para engordarlas y venderlas a los negociantes que visitan la zona regularmente. Por este motivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Angelita es una mujer alegre, trabajadora y muy entregada a su familia. Ella ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad en sus pagos por lo que se le considera una cliente excelente.
texts.en:
Angelita is a 45 year old mother of a family who lives with her husband and her children in a La Pava, an agricultural zone of Mochumí district, Lambayeque province, located 1 1/2 hours from the city of Chiclayo. For more than 4 years she has raised and sold animals. She raises poultry in a corral constructed for the purpose in the back part of her house. The poultry she favors, because of high demand, is turkeys. Angelita commented that she had to start dedicating herself to this activity because her husband, like the majority of men of the zone, works as an agricultural laborer and the income he receives is insufficient to cover family expenses. She wants to expand her business by buying more birds to fatten and sell to business people who visit the zone regularly. With this motive, she decided to ask Edpyme Alternative for a loan of 1,500 New Sols to help her achieve her objective. Angelita is happy, hard-working, and very committed to her family. She has worked before with our institution and has demonstrated punctuality and responsibility in her payments, for which reason we consider her an excellent client.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING POULTRY TO EXPAND HER BUSINESS

loans.name: Florah

texts.en:
Florah C. was born in 1962. She is married to Mr. John Cheboi and they have been blessed with three children: Jepkorir (21 years), Kangogo (20 years) and Joseph (17 years). Mrs. C. lives with her family in Pemwai village. Florah is a farmer doing horticulture. She started her farming 25 years ago and most of her clients are residents of Pemwai and its environs. She makes a monthly income of 6,000 Kenyan shillings from this farming business. She describes herself as hardworking and determined.

Florah was introduced to KADET by a friend who was already a client. Mrs. C. has borrowed 80,000 KES from KADET. She plans to use 60,000 KES to purchase fertilizers, maize seeds and other farm inputs for the forthcoming planting season. The remaining 20,000 KES will be used to pay school fees for her children. If this loan boosts her business, Florah intends to plough back the profits into the farm and buy dairy cows. Florah hopes to have a stable income and thus be able to educate her children further.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Adelaida Caw-It Group

texts.en:
Adelaida C. is from the village of Colupan Bajo, Sinacaban. She is  the leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While both members of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member in the case of a default. The official name of this borrowing group is Adelaida C. Group.

Adelaida is 67 and widowed with four adult children. To make a living, she has operated a general store for over four years which brings in approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In January of 2008, Adelaida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Adelaida is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Adelaida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bacilisa

texts.es:
Bacilisa, tiene 46 años, tiene tres hijos (Miguel, Junior y Jairo), es una madre responsable que saca adelante a sus hijos y quiere darles una mejor profesión para que puedan defenderse mejor en la vida. 

Bacilisa es una mujer trabajadora que se dedica a  la venta de comestibles como por ejemplo arroz, azúcar, fideos, leche, etc. Ella tiene una pequeña tienda en su domicilio donde ofrece sus productos. Ya son 4 años que se dedica a este negocio y le ha ido muy bien. 

Bacilisa también se dedica a la venta de pizzas de forma ambulatoria en la avenida principal de la ciudad de Urubamba, la socia vende cada pizzas a 4 soles, ella sale a vender sus pizzas a partir de las 6 p.m. hasta las 10 p.m. La socia nos cuenta que antes tenía un proveedor de pizzas pre cocidas pero ahora la socia elabora sus propias pizza pre cocidas. Ya es un año que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien. 

Bacilisa requiere el préstamo para comprar 20 cajas de cerveza, leche, harina,  arroz y azúcar. 

Bacilisa pertenece al banco comunal “Reyna de los Ángeles”, ella es una de las fundadoras del banco comunal. El anhelo de la socia es abrir un depósito de cerveza y tener su propia pizzería.  

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Bacilisa is 46 years old, and she has three children (Miguel, Junior, and Jairo). She is a responsible mother who gets her children ahead. She wants to give them a better profession so that they will be able to better take care of themselves in this life. Bacilisa is a very hard-working woman. She sells food like rice, sugar, noodles, and, milk, etc. She has a small store in her house where she sells these products. She has been in this business for four years, and it has gone very well for her. Bacilisa also sells pizzas as a street vendor on a main avenue in the city of Urubamba. She sells each pizza for four PEN. She leaves to sell her pizzas at six p.m., and she sells until ten p.m. She tells us that she used to have a provider of pre-cooked pizzas, but now she makes her own pre-cooked pizzas. She has been in this business for one year, and it is going very well for her. Bacilisa needs the loan to buy 20 cases of beer, milk, flour, rice and sugar. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 20 cases of beer, milk, flour, rice and sugar

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline A. is a thirty-one-year-old mother of two children, Abby and Natalie, who are in primary school. Her husband, Charles Owino, is a school principal. Jackline runs a printing and gallery design workshop in Kisumu City, 500 kilometers West of Nairobi, the capital city. She designs some beautiful pieces of artwork and has a talented staff good at these kind of craft pieces, which she supplies to hotels, schools, and other interested customers.  

Jackline loves her job which she has done for the last six years. She is taking out her first loan from KADET Ltd and intends to maintain a good credit history so that she will be considered for subsequent loans. She plans to use the loan to buy raw materials for the craft and gallery workshop and also buy stationery for the printing side of the business. She is looking for a lender through Kadet to enable her expand her business. 

Jackline, a hard-working and ambitious lady, hopes to provide quality and efficient service in order to win more clients. Her dream is to continue being a source of income to others via employment opportunities in her business.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her craft workshop and printing stationery.

loans.name: Maria Francisca

texts.es: Maria Francisa tiene la edad de 67 años. Ella se dedica a la venta de cosa de horno y destace de cerdo, pues siempre ha buscado la manera de mejorar sus ingresos. Esta no es la primera vez que tiene experiencias con financiamientos por lo que sus experiencias han sido muy importantes para el crecimiento de su negocio.  Hace más de 31 años que se dedica a este negocio por lo que dio inicio desde muy joven y fue por iniciativa propia ya que su esposo había fallecido y estaba buscando la forma de generar sus ingresos. Actualmente solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de leña, maíz, queso, mantequilla entre otras cosas. Sueña con obtener otro medio de ingreso.
texts.en:
Maria Francisa is 67 years old. She dedicates herself to selling baked goods and is a butcher. She has always looked for a way to increase her income. This is not the first time that Maria has had experience with financing. Her experiences have been very important for the growth of her business. She has dedicated herself to this business for more than 31 years. She took the initiative to begin the business when she was very young and her husband had passed away and she was looking for a way to generate income. Currently, Maria is requesting this financing for working capital to buy firewood, corn, cheese, butter, and other goods. Her dream is to obtain another source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 32 and married with one child. She lives and farms in Likuyani in Eldoret. She also has a hotel which helps to increase the family's income.

She came to know about KADET through her friend who is also a KADET client. She has been in farming for three years and with the loan she plans to buy maize seedlings and herbicides. Emily’s goal is to improve and enlarge the scale of her farm business.

loans.use: To buy maize seedlings and herbicide

loans.name: Lutengo Development Group 1, Mukono

texts.en:
M. Sauda, shown at the bottom left in the small photo, also appears in the big group photo second from right as the group leader. She is a 50-year-old married mother of nine school-going children. She also has four grandchildren she is taking care of.

Sauda’s business activity is selling coffee. She has been doing this for the last forty years in Lutengo, Mukono district. One of the major challenges she has faced ever since she began her coffee business has been the coffee wilt disease, which she says has incessantly played havoc with her coffee plants. Her plan is to buy medicines to dispense with this problem. She also plans on buying her own mill. This is of paramount importance to her and she is, to all intents and purposes, eager to get a loan to aid her in these plans.

loans.use: To stock more ingredients like bananas, sorghum and yeast for making more brew

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr: Née en 1968 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin, H. Odette vit depuis 25 ans environs à Agbalilamè à sèmè-Podji. Odette est mariée à HOUNGBEMON Rémi et est mère de deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Odette vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Odette vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les charges familiales. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Odette vend des tissus et des dentifrices de façon ambulante. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Odette s'approvisionne. Odette exerce cette activité depuis 12 ans environs et a obtenu antérieurement deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Odette a bien remboursé les deux crédits. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Odette sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1968 in the Sèmè-Podji commune of Benin, Odette H. has been living for the past 25 years in the Agbalilamè area of Sèmè-Podji. She is married to Rémi HOUNGBEMON and is the mother of two children, of which one is attending school. Odette lives together with her children and husband, and assists him in dealing with family expenses. To meet her needs, Odette has been selling pieces of fabric and toothpaste as an itinerant vendor. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. She has been in this line of business for approximately 12 years and has already been granted two previous loans from ALIDé, both of which have been repaid in full. To bolster her activity and increase customer satisfaction, Odette is now requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pieces of fabric and toothpaste

loans.name: Stephen Kimani

texts.en:
Stephen Kimani, 62, is married to Tabitha Kimani and they are blessed with four beautiful children. He lives in Msalaba in Eldoret and he practices farming which he has done for the last thirty-five years. Besides farming Stephen also operates a ploughing business at his place in Msalaba near the Ivugwi primary school.

Stephen was introduced to KADET by another client. Stephen plans to use this loan for farm inputs, like maize seedlings, and for payroll for his farm's employees. 

His dream is to be economically stable and thus also provide the basic needs for his family, including food, clothing, and shelter.

loans.use: Farm inputs and payroll

loans.name: Hope Group

texts.en: For more than 7 years, Mariah F. has been selling charcoal at the New Matadi Market in Monrovia, Liberia. She is 52 years old, a widow, and has five children, ages 22 to 32 years old. She was not able to continue her education past 3rd grade due to a lack of financial support. Mariah sells charcoal in a friendly manner to customers which keeps them returning. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 28,000 LRD group loan to purchase more charcoal bags to sell. Her goal is to improve her business and build a house. Mariah is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "Hope Group". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mariah is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal

loans.name: Kantossowe

texts.en: Kantossowe D. is 59 years old, has one child, and is a widow. She lives in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo, and works from home. She makes and sells a local beverage called tchoukoutou (a local beer) and has been in this business since 1975. This will be her first loan with WAGES, which she will use to purchase necessary items to make this beverage – namely, a grain called sorgho and firewood. These items will allow Mrs. D. to augment her supply of tchoukoutou and keep her customers satisfied.

loans.use: Purchase of incredients to prepare and sell local beverage

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en: Teresia is a diligent and hardworking lady. She lives with her husband and their two children who go to school. She sells clothes in her residence to earn a living. She has been engaged in this business for nine years. She also grows tea and keeps dairy animals to increase their family earnings. Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, her business has improved since she can access loans. She has requested a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more secondhand clothes for sale.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes

loans.name: Tembiapora Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Paraguarí, se reunieron unas emprendedoras mujeres con la idea de acceder al préstamo a través del comité, de ahí se  coordinó la reunión para aclarar todos los detalles sobre el programa, quienes aceptaron gustosas para trabajar ya que toman como una oportunidad la capacitación para mejorar las actividades que realizan   , ademas podrán aumentar su capital de trabajo y de esa manera aumentar sus ingresos.
El comité lleva por nombre Tembiaporä, se encuentran en el octavo ciclo con calificación excelente integrada por 16 luchadoras mujeres, quienes hacen hasta lo imposible para mejorar su nivel de vida  de sus familias. Todas las integrantes son señoras muy emprendedoras, quienes han invertido sus préstamos en sus respectivas actividades.
La señora Mariza quien compró frutas y verduras (manzana, naranjas, piñas, cebollas, tomate, locote) a través de crédito, ya que la misma se dedica a la venta de verduras y frutas, además ella prepara para la venta ensaladas de frutas y jugos naturales bien helado para vender a la gente que pasa por su puesto de venta. Ella esta muy conforme con la actividad que realiza ya que ayuda muchísimo para la buena alimentación de sus hijos y agradece por el préstamos concedido ya que cuenta con muchas ganas de superación.
texts.en:
In the city of Paraguarí, a group of women entrepreneurs gathered together with the idea to access a loan by forming a committee. At this meeting, they clarified all the details about the program and willingly agreed to work because they wanted to seize the opportunity to receive training that would help them improve their businesses. In addition, they could increase their operating capital so that they could earn more income.

The committee is named “Tembiaporä”, which is now in its eighth loan cycle with an excellent rating. Within this group are 16 determined women who try every possible way to improve the living standards of their families. All of the members are enterprising women who will invest their loans in their respective businesses.

Sra. Mariza is a member who buys fruits and vegetables (apples, oranges, pineapples, onions, tomatoes, and peppers) on credit and then sells them. She also prepares fruit salads and chilled natural juices to sell to people who pass by her vending post. Mariza is pleased with what she has achieved because it has been a great help in providing food for her children. She is thankful for the loans that have been provided since they have helped her in her quest to succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits & vegetables

loans.name: Angelita Del Carmen

texts.es: La Señora Angelita G. se desempeña en el bello arte de la costura, ella realiza diferentes variedades de diseño, su negocio está ubicado en el Municipio de Nindirí, con los ingresos que le genera esta actividad logra mantener a su familia, tiene un hijo que está en la Universidad y ella le provee los gastos para su carrera ya que ella quiere que el cumpla sus sueños de ser un profesional. Ella se ha acercado a CEPRODEL a solicitar nuevamente crédito el que lo ocupará para  la compra de tela como satín strech, dacron strech, linos e insumos ella se muestra satisfecha porque siente que le ha ayudado bastante ya que con este dinero puede cubrir la demanda de sus clientes y así poder ella tener un buen nivel de vida junto a su familia.
texts.en:
Sra. Angelita G. engages in the fine art of sewing, producing different varieties of designs. Her business is located in the town of Nindirí. With the revenue that she generates, she is able to support her family. She has a son who is attending the university and provides for his expenses so that he can obtain his degree. Angelita wants him to fulfill his dream of becoming a professional.

She came to CEPRODEL in order to request a new loan to buy fabrics such as stretch satin, stretch dacron, linens, as well as supplies. Angelita is satisfied with the loans because the money has helped her with meeting the demands of her customers and achieving a good standard of living for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabrics & supplies

loans.name: Alcione

texts.es:
Alcione, tiene 33 años, tiene dos hijos (Angela y Emanuel), es una madre responsable que busca a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. 

Alcione es una mujer trabajadora que se dedica a  la venta de comestibles como por ejemplo arroz, azúcar, fideos, leche, etc. Ella tiene una pequeña tienda en su domicilio donde ofrece sus productos. Ya son 9 años que se dedica a este negocio y le ha ido muy bien. Alcione  se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno y limpiar la casa, después ella atiende la tienda desde las 6 a.m. hasta 8 p.m. 

Alcione requiere el préstamo para comprar 20 cajas de cerveza, leche, harina,  arroz y azúcar. 

Alcione pertenece al banco comunal “Reyna de los Ángeles”, ella es una de las fundadoras del banco comunal. El anhelo de la socia es ampliar su tienda.  

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Alcione is 33 years old and has two children (Angela and Emanuel). She is a responsible mother who is always looking for opportunities to progress and, with her daily efforts, give her children a better future. Alcione is a hardworking woman that dedicates herself to selling food products, such as rice, sugar, noodles, milk, etc. She has a small store in her home where she offers her products. She has dedicated herself to this business for 9 years, and it has served her very well. Alcione gets up very early to do her household work such as preparing breakfast and cleaning the house. She then attends to the store from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. Alcione needs this loan to buy 20 boxes of beer, milk, flour, rice, and sugar. Alcione belongs to the community bank, "Reyna de los Ángeles”. She is one of the founders of the community bank. Alcione's greatest wish is to expand her store. She is very thankful for the opportunity offered to her through this loan, and she promises to comply with the repayment schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 boxes of beer, milk, flour, rice, and sugar

loans.name: Women Of Faith Group

texts.en:
Kou K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers named Women of Faith.  Kou sells used clothes, and plans to use her portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more stock for her business.  Kou is 33 years old and married with four children ages 1, 8, 11, and 19.  Kou's school-age kids attend elementary school and junior high.  Kou says that she was never able to go to school due to a lack of support from her parents.  Besides her children, Kou also helps care for three siblings.

Kou has been running her used clothing business for about eight years now, and sells from a table near the Coal Field Poultry Market.  She says she started her endeavor with one bag of clothes, and has built her business since then.  According to Kou, the biggest challenge she faces is stiff competition -- many people in her area also sell used clothes.  Kou hopes that one day she'll be able to grow her business enough so she can open a proper storefront.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kou is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for resale.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Julia tiene 60 años,  es separada, tenía 9 hijos, el mayor falleció, y solo 7 de ellos, ya son independientes y con  su propia familia, por lo que vive ahora con su última hija, en su propia casa, al sur de la ciudad.  Desde que se separó del padre de sus hijos, empezó a trabajar en la venta de especias y condimentos, por lo que lleva 14 años, realizando esta labor. Es así que cada mañana empieza su labor, desde las 7am, instalada ya en la puerta del mercado, quedándose hasta que se consuma la mayor parte de su mercadería, aunque su labor no termina ahí, pues debe llegar a casa a dedicarse a preparar y moler los condimentos, en lo que resta del día hasta las 10pm de la noche. Ella esta muy contenta y satisfecha con lo que hace, ya que este negocio le ha proporcionado buenas rentas, además que disfruta mucho atender a sus clientes, por lo que tiene el apoyo de su hija, quien la ayuda en la venta. Su mayor anhelo de Julia, es adquirir un puesto dentro del mercado, para tener más seguridad de sus productos. Este es su octavo préstamo con MFP, y confirma una vez más, su compromiso de cumplir sus cuotas establecidas, por otro lado, manifiesta que le gusta trabajar de la mano con su grupo comunal, por ser un grupo muy solidario. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de insumos para la elaboración de condimentos y demás mercadería.
texts.en:
Julia is 60 years old. She is separated and had nine children. Her oldest son passed away and seven others are independent and have their own families. Her youngest daughter lives with her in her home in the south part of the city. When she separated from her children’s father, she began selling spices and condiments and has been doing this for the past 14 years. She begins working at 7:00 am every morning, when she sets up at the entrance to the market, where she remains until most of her merchandise is sold out. Her work doesn’t end there. She goes home and begins grinding and preparing condiments until 10:00 pm. She is very happy and satisfied with what she does, and this business has provided her a good profit. She also likes working with her customers and her daughter helps her with the sales. Her greatest desire is to acquire a stall within the market, so that her products will be more secure [from theft]. This will be her eighth loan through MFP and once again she reiterates her promise to make her payments on time. It also shows that she enjoys working with this group because it is very united. She will use the money from this loan to buy ingredients that she needs to make her condiments and other products.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ingredients

loans.name: Lutengo Development Group 2, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Teo, shown at the bottom right in the small photo, also appears in the group photo as the group leader. She is a veteran local brew seller with monthly cash inflow estimates bordering close to 200,000 shillings a month. With an experienced business resumé spanning over twenty years, Teo’s confidence has skyrocketed despite the disparaging nature of her business.

Meet 50-year-old Teo. She is a married woman with thirteen children of her own and five dependents, all under her support.

The continual price fluctuations in the local brew products that Teo sells in Lutengo, Mukono district, have often negatively affected her financial gains. This happens most especially when the prices increase. Despite this, her level of optimism has not plummeted at all. Instead she is one woman who takes a long view of things.

As such, Teo has drawn up future plans to make her business grow to an even bigger magnitude than it is now. Her thoughts for now, though, are focused on obtaining this loan to help her reinvest in this project.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans (containers) and brewing materials

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa tiene 44 años de edad, es separada y vive junto a sus dos hijos, uno de los cuales ya trabaja, en la ciudad de Lambayeque, ubicada a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Hace cinco años empezó a vender productos cosméticos por catálogo, con mucho esfuerzo pudo obtener un grupo de clientes fieles, los cuales le recomendaron ampliar su negocio instalando un puesto de venta en su vivienda. Teresa trabajó mucho para lograr este objetivo y actualmente ya tiene instalado su negocio.

Ella hace los pedidos con anticipación para tener un stock permanente que le garantice satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes en cualquier momento sin necesidad de que estos esperen al fin de mes para que llegue el pedido que solicitaron. Actualmente ella desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más productos de modo que tenga un stock surtido, por ello se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Teresa es una mujer emprendedora y bastante trabajadora. Sus vecinos y conocidos la estiman mucho y la consideran alguien de confianza, su mayor anhelo es seguir creciendo como empresaria.
texts.en:
Teresa is 44 years old. She is separeated and lives with her two children, one of whom is already working in the city of Lambayeque, located 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. Five years ago she started selling cosmetics through a catalog. With a lot of effort she was able to establish a group of regular customers, who suggested that she expand her business and set up a shop in her home. She worked hard to meet this objective and now has her business established. She anticipates her customers’ needs and places her orders in advance, so that she will have the items in stock and her customers will not have to wait until the end of the month for the products to arrive. Now she would like to expand her business even more by buying and maintaining a stock of a greater variety of products. So she is requesting her first loan of 500 PEN ($200) through Edpyme Alternativa in order to help her meet her objective. Teresa is a very enterprising and hard working woman. She is well liked by her friends and acquaintances and they consider her to be a very trustworthy person. Her greatest desire is to continue growing as an entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Allan

texts.en: Allan is married and lives with his wife and seven children.   Three of the children are currently in school.  He has been running a welding business for thirty years to earn a living.  He is also employed as a caretaker. He was employed in a welding business before he invested his money to start a welding business of his own. He has big plans to expand his business. For that reason, he requests a loan of KES 50,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a welding machine.  Allan is in a black coat on the photo.

loans.use: To buy a welding machine.

loans.name: Roubatou

texts.en: Roubatou A. K. is a trained seamstress. She is married to a taxi driver and has two children. She works from home in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo and has been running her business since 2002. She is currently requesting her first loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to purchase 4 hemming machines and use the remainder to buy any haberdashery needed to keep her business running smoothly. This loan will help Mrs. K. support both her business and her family.

loans.use: To purchase hemming machines and haberdashery.

loans.name: Maria Elvira

texts.es: La Sra. Maria es conviviente tiene 4 hijos, dos de ellos viven con su anterior compromiso y dos de ellos con su actual compromiso. Ella cuenta con casa propia de material noble en el distrito de parcona. Ella se dedica  a la venta de ropa como recorredora, tambien tiene una moto taxi el cual lo alquila, su conyugue es vigilante. La  Sra. Maria tiene muchos sueños y objetivos uno de ellos es poder tener mas vehiculos.Con el dinero que solicita invertira en capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Ms. Maria lives is in a common law marriage and has four children. Two of them live with their father from a previous relationship and two of them live with her in her current relationship. She has her own home made of concrete in the district of Parcona. She sells clothes as as a street vendor. She also has a motorcycle taxi that she hires out. Her spouse is a security guard. Maria has a lot of dreams and goals. One of them is be able to have more vehicles. She will invest the money she is asking for in working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in working capital

loans.name: Adilia Gertrudis

texts.es:
La señora Adilia Gertrudis C. P. es soltero tiene dos hijos habita del antiguo banic 4c. al norte 
es  trabajadora del ministerio de salud en el realejos desde hace catorce años como estadística ¨A¨, tiene cinco años de trabajar con CEPRODEL, el cual ha cancelado cuatro créditos demostrando ser una persona responsable en cuanto a obligaciones contraídas.
La señora Adilia Gertrudis C. solicito este crédito para cubrir gastos personales
texts.en:
Sra. Adilia Gertrudis C. P. is single and has two children. She lives four blocks north of Antiguo Banic. Adilia has been working for the Ministry of Health as an “A” level statistician for fourteen years. She has been a client of CEPRODEL for five years and has completed four loans, thus demonstrating that she is a responsible person when it comes to meeting her obligations.

Sra. Adilia is requesting this loan in order to cover personal expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Personal expenses

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy is 33 years of age, single, and has two children who go to school. She has been operating a cafeteria for two years and has two employees to assist her in the business. She was selling used clothes before she ventured into this business.  She previously took out three loans from Faulu Kenya which she used to expand her business and pay school fees to her children. She hopes to build her family a house and improve her living standards in the future. She has requested for a loan of KES 80,000 to buy a freezer and renovate her business premise.

loans.use: To buy a freezer and renovate the business premises.

loans.name: Rhodora

texts.en:
Rhodora C. is a proud member of ASHI in Mambog center of Rizal Southwest Branch (RSWB). During her membership in ASHI, her performance has been noted to be good in repayment and in attendance in center meetings. She joined ASHI to secure supplementary working funds for her sewing business.

Rhodora hopes to expand her business. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of 17,000 pesos to pay for assorted cotton fabric, and other supplies. She requests this loan through ASHI so that she can support the expansion of her sewing business and be able to meet the growing demands of her customers.

With working capital, Rhodora’s business will continue to grow and she will be able to give satisfactory service to her customers. Through the support of ASHI and Kiva, she hopes to witness herself and her family soon changing their quality of living and moving away from under the umbrella of poverty.

Having this loan will allow Rhodora to finally achieve her dreams in life: to have a growing business, to fund the education of her two children, to build a concrete and durable home, and to have a happy family as well.

Rhodora is married to Jeffrey and they are blessed of two minor-aged children. Despite the many challenges in her life, she never gave up fighting against poverty.

loans.use: To pay for assorted of cotton fabrics and other supplies

loans.name: Jose Miguel

texts.es: Don José es un hombre esforzado para lograr un nivel de vida mejor. Tiene 46 años de edad, casado con un hijo de 10 años el cual cursa sus estudios, su esposa es comerciante de venta de prenda de plata el cual ambos se apoyan mutuamente para lograr los objetivos personales. El señor José trabaja en el Ministerio de Hacienda como Responsable del departamento de clasificación de puesto de trabajo, desde hace trece años, el cual ha alcanzado mucho conocimiento. Las dificultades que tuvo fue no lograr terminar su carrera debido a que años atrás no hallaba trabajo lo cual emigro a Costa Rica en donde trabajo en ventas, por ocho años, luego regreso, se caso y decide seguir estudiando, es por eso con este financiamiento lograra pagar el titulo en Licenciatura de Contabilidad Publica, para el un gran objetivo en su vida, nuevas oportunidades de crecer en el ámbito profesional. Contento por este beneficio alcanzado. Sus planes a futuro es poder escalar en su trabajo, y tener mejores ingresos economicos.
texts.en:
José has worked hard to attain a better standard of living. He is 46 years old and has a 10 year old son, who is in school; his wife sells silver jewelry and both support each other in their efforts to reach their personal goals. José has worked for the Ministry of the Treasury as Chief of the Employment Classification Department for the last 13 years where he has acquired much knowledge. A difficulty he has faced is that he was unable to finish his professional career because he had to go to Costa Rica years ago because he couldn’t find work at home. He worked in sales there for 8 years. Then, he returned, got married and decided to resume his studies. He will use the funds to pay for the expenses associated with getting his CPA certification which has been a great life objective for him that will open new opportunities for professional growth. Happy with having reached this benefit, his plans for the future are to continue ascending his career ladder and to have improved income.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for the expenses associated with getting his CPA certification.

loans.name: Blanca

texts.es: Blanca, de 41 años, vive en su casa propia  al lado de su esposo y sus 3 menores  hijos.Desde muy joven empezó a dedicarse a  los negocios, y esto la motivo para instalar una tienda de productos de primera necesidad .Desde hace un año se animó a empezar con el negocio  y actualmente es la mas  visitada  por sus clientes, ya que es una de las pocas tiendas  que tiene su localidad, esta es una gran oportunidad para ella, pues no descuida a  sus hijos y trabaja  desde la comodidad de su  casa. Su trato amable y los precios cómodos que ofrece la ayudan bastante para  garantizar el retorno de sus clientes. En el futuro  Blanca tiene pensado abastecer su tienda de mayor cantidad de productos para poder ofrecer variedad a  sus habituales clientes.Es el 13avo préstamo  que tiene y agradece  a todas las  personas que hicieron posible el crédito que le permitirá seguir trabajando en su tienda, además promete ser puntual en el pago de sus cuotas.Blanca tiene pensado invertir el dinero solicitado en la compra de productos comestibles al por mayor, ya que desea surtir bien su tienda.
texts.en:
Blanca, 41, lives in her own home with her husband and three minor children. She has been a businesswoman since a very young age. She set up a grocery store a year ago and now her store is the most popular with her customers because it’s one of the few stores in her neighborhood; this is a great opportunity for her because she can work from the comfort of her home while watching over her children. Her fair prices and the kindness with which she treats her customers guarantee their return. In the future, Blanca intends to stock her store with a wider variety of products to offer her usual customers. This is her 13th loan and she is grateful to all the people that made it possible for her to continue working in her store; she pledges to repay in a timely fashion. Blanca will use the funds to buy stock items at wholesale in order to stock her store very well.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock inventory for her store.

loans.name: Dennys

texts.es:
El señor Dennys M. M. se dedica a la venta de Verduras en el mercado  del Bisne, sector de verduras, es  casado tiene 5 hijos todos en edad escolar, pero también su esposa tiene otro tramo de verdura en el mismo sector, ambos trabajan mutuamente para sacar adelante a sus hijos. 

El señor M. solicito el crédito para cubrir unas compras de verduras para tener producto fresco y ofrecer a su clientela,  ya que la mayoría de sus clientes  son restaurantes, y comideras del mismo sector, lleva ya 8 créditos con ceprodel y ha demostrado ser una persona muy responsable.
texts.en:
Sr. Dennys M. M. sells vegetables in the produce section of the market in Bisne. He is married and has five children who are all of school age. His wife also manages a vegetable stand in the same part of the market. They both work together in order for their children to get ahead.

Sr. M. is requesting a loan to cover the purchase of vegetables so that he can have fresh products to offer to his customers. The majority of his customers are restaurants and eateries located in the same area of the market. He has already received eight loans with CEPRODEL and demonstrated that he is a very responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fresh vegetables

loans.name: Kiwanga Women's Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Suzan, 3rd from right in the group photo also appears in the small photo at the bottom right as the group leader. She offers catering services in Kiwanga, Mukono, as one of her steady sources of income.

Suzan, a 38-year-old divorcee who also happens to be a teacher, has four children who all go to school. She has an experience in this business that stretches to three years. In a week, she makes a paltry 30,000 shillings. This, combined with her monthly teacher remuneration of 200,000 shillings, is evidently minimal for a woman who wants to give her business a new lease of life.

Suzan has all the attributes to succeed, her hospitable nature being the most predominant. She needs a loan to be in a position to drive her plans into action.

loans.use: To buy more catering equipment like plates and nets and to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Unity Five Group

texts.en:
Oretha T. is the leader of a group five borrowers called Unity Five. She is 38 years old, married, and has a 12-year-old child. She was not able to continue her education past elementary school and for 10 years has been selling dishware at the Red Light Market in Paynesville, Liberia. She always encourages customers to buy from her in a friendly way, which keeps them returning.   Oretha plans to use her portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to purchase more dishware for sale. Her goal is to increase and improve her business.   In the photo that accompanies this profile, Oretha is the one holding the sign. Naomie K. is inset at upper right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more dishware for selling.

loans.name: Álvaro José

texts.es:
El joven  Álvaro José V. M. es trabajador de la Alcaldía de Chinandega, se desempeña como operario de Limpieza, es soltero no tiene hijos y aun vive en casa de sus padres.

El señor Álvaro V. M., solicito el crédito para ayudar un poco a sus padres en los gastos del hogar y otros gastos personales, ya que sus padres son personas de edad y ya no pueden trabajar por su propia cuenta.
texts.en:
Alvaro works as a custodian in the Chinandenga city hall. He is single, has no children, and lives with his parents. Alvaro is requesting this loan in order to help his parents a little with household and other expenses. His parents are elderly and can no longer work.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Assist parents with expenses

loans.name: Lito Salome

texts.es: El Sr. Lito tiene 33 años de edad es conviviente tienen una hija en edad escolar, su conyugue trabaja temporalemnet en fundos agricolas como obrera de campo. El Sr. Lito actualmente cuenta con el ingreso de 2 motos taxis el cual uno lo trabaja , y el otro lo alquila. Tambien han adquirido  recientemente un puesto comercial en el mercado de la Tinguiña, el su esposa vendera verduras. El y su familia viven en casa de su suegros. Tienen muchas metas y objetivos uno de ellos es poder tener el negocio de la venta de verduras. Con el Dinero que solicitan invertiran en el negocio  del puesto comercial.
texts.en:
Sr. Lito is 33 years old. He and his live-in partner have a daughter of school age. His partner works seasonally as a field worker on agricultural properties. Sr. Lito now relies on income from two motorcycle taxis; he uses one for his work and rents the other one. They have also recently acquired a stall in the Tinguiña market, where his partner will sell vegetables. He and his family live in the house of his in-laws. They have many goals. One of them is to have a business selling vegetables. With the money that he is seeking, they will invest in their market stall business.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in a market stall

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is 42 years old, single, and has three children. She has been operating a textile shop where she sells ready-made clothes, fabric, thread, and buttons for fifteen years and has one employee.  She also raises chicken for commercial purposes to earn more money to support her family.  Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, her business has grown tremendously because she has access to working capital through loans. She hopes to open other business outlets and improve her standard of living in the future. She has requested for a loan of KES 60,000 to buy more clothes, fabric, threads, and buttons.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, fabric, thread, and buttons.

loans.name: Carlos Manuel

texts.es:
El señor Carlos Manuel C. M., Habita en el reparto Pedro j. chamorro de Chinandega, es sastre  y además repara Maquinas de coser, el señor posee un tramo en el bisne donde realiza sus trabajos de confección y de reparación.

El señor C. M. es casado y tiene  dos hijos que aun dependen de él, su esposa también posee un tramo de en el bisne donde vende comida, contiguo al de el, ambos son bien trabajadores y luchan a diario para sacar  adelante a su familia.
texts.en:
Carlos lives in the Pedro J. Chamorro neighborhood of Chinandenga. He is a tailor and also repairs sewing machines. He has a workshop where he practices his trades. Carlos is married and has two children who depend on him. His wife sells food next door to his shop. They are both hard workers who work to move their family ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Cesar Silverio

texts.es: El. Sr. Cesar tiene 43 años de edad, es separado tiene 2 menores hijos aquien le pasa una pension de alimentos, cuenta con casa propia de material noble. El se dedica  a la venta de ropa  como recorredor  por los caserios. El tiene  un triciclo y recientemente a adquirido una moto car, con financiamiento de la Caja Municipal. Tiene muchos sueños uno de ellos es poder tener su negocio mas grande.Con el dinero que solicta invertira en capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Sr. Cesar is 43 years old. He is separated and has two young children, to whom he provides an allowance for food. He has his own house, constructed of good-quality materials. He sells clothing as a traveling salesman in the small villages. He has a motor-tricycle and recently acquired a car, with financing from Caja Municipal. He has many dreams. One of them is to have a bigger business. With the money that he is seeking, he will invest in working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in working capital

loans.name: God's Mercy Group

texts.en:
Elsie C. is the leader of a group five borrowers called God’s Mercy.  She is 54 years old, single, and has seven children ranging in age from 19 to 33.  For more than 10 years, Elsie has been selling cooked food such as rice at the Pipelines Community in Paynesville, Liberia.  Elsie prepares her food well and in a good environment which keeps customers returning.  She plans to use her portion of this 36,000 LRD group loan to purchase more rice. Her goal is to own a restaurant and build a house for her children.  In the photo that accompanies this profile, Elsie is the one holding the sign. Nyepan T. is inset at the lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase more rice.

loans.name: Marie Angèle

texts.fr: H. Marie Angèle vit depuis 20 ans à Gbèdjromédé, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Marie Angèle est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Marie Angèle ne vit plus avec son mari. Elle vit seule avec ses enfants et assure leurs charges respectives. Marie Angèle n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins et assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Marie Angèle mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (maïs, huile de palme, huile d'arachide, charbon de bois, etc.) et aussi des cartes de recharges téléphoniques à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Marie Angèle achète ses articles. Marie Angèle est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Marie Angèle souhaite faire un approvisionnement en quantité suffisante pour pouvoir dégager une marge de bénéfice plus importante, mais est limitée par les moyens financiers. C’est la raison pour laquelle Marie Angèle désire obtenir un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Marie Angèle H. has lived for 20 years in Gbèdjromédé, a neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Marie Angèle is mother to two children who are both at school. She no longer lives with her husband but lives alone with her children and covers their respective expenses. Marie Angèle went to primary school only. In order to provide for her needs and those of her children, she sells various products (corn, palm oil, peanut oil, charcoal, etc.) and also telephone recharge cards, all from her home. She buys her products at Dantokpa, the international market in Bénin. Marie Angèle is an old client of ALIDé who repays her loans without incident. She would like to get sufficient supplies in order to make a higher profit margin but has limited financial means. It is for this reason that she would like to have another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of corn, cans of palm oil and peanut oil, and telephone recharge cards

loans.name: Israel Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Israel Antonio M. E., es trabajador de la Alcaldía de Chinandega, se desempeña como vigilante, es casado tiene tres hijos todos dependen de él. 

El señor Israel M. E., además de trabajar en  la Alcaldía se dedica a la agricultura, pues la comarca donde vive es buena para la siembra, el señor M. E. solicito el crédito para reparar un poco su casa ya que no está bien cerrada.
texts.en:
Israel works as a security guard in the Chinandega city hall. He also farms. The area where he lives is good for farming. He is requesting this loan in order to make some repairs to his home which is not very secure.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home repair

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es: Alicia, de 46 años, vive con su esposo y su hijo en una casa alquilada.Desde hace 22 años, se dedica a la venta de comida en su restaurante campestre que construyó en su  casa. Su gran habilidad y vocación en la cocina han logrado atraer a los más  exigentes paladares,de sus clientes que cada día acuden a su restaurante para comer los diferentes platos típicos de su región que prepara. En el trabajo cuenta con  el apoyo de 2 jovencitas  que ha contratado para que atiendan al público, mientras ella prepara los alimentos y administra el local. El tiempo de experiencia le ha permitido ver la rentabilidad de su negocio, ya que ha logrado  mantenerse sin pasar dificultades económicas. Para el futuro tiene planeado ampliar  y mejorar la infraestructura de su negocio.
